content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Different is great and artistic is great, but if you're going to make a game, the interactive aspect of the game medium has to be used. Sadly, the only thing you do in this linear game is hold the W key and point your mouse while the narrator talks. There's nothing to interact with, your actions mean nothing, and exploration is actively punished by an unhelpful terrain and a snail's pace walk. (See something interesting? Well climb down this little hill and look! Oh... Oh, its nothing. Oh well, I guess you'll have to walk back. No, no, not back to where you climbed down, that's too steep. No, go back. Back some more. No, not far enough, keep going. Just a little... no, no that way is blocked, too. Oh there, you go. Now you're back to the start of the trail. Just a few minutes and you'll back to where you were, but wasn't it so much more enriching to have gone over and looked at that ledge with nothing on it? Good job.)The only challenge in this game is holding the W key throughout 2+ hours without your hand becoming a locked claw. I started with my index finger, then to my middle and ring finger and on to my thumb (which didn't work well). I did eventually try holding a spoon down on the key with the heel of my hand, and that did the job nicely. In reality, Dear Ester is a movie (a dull one at that) that makes you hold down a button so as to keep you awake throughout it. This is no more a "game" than a movie with audio but no picture is a "movie". But if you want to go through it, it is at least short and the imagery is very pretty with a nice score. Just bring a spoon. Trust me.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												Explore the serene island around you to discover clues that will help you unlock pieces of a multi-headed storyline, recalling memories in the beautiful moonlight and the warm sun. Sometimes frightening, sometimes sullen, sometimes heartwarming, the experience is memorable.PROS: Peaceful. So peaceful. Beautiful scenery Good exploration experience Amazing soundtrackCONS: Not for everyone (no action/puzzles/etc.)It really can only be described as an experience. You explore the island and, upon finding certain areas or items, will "unlock" part of the narrative ultimately giving you final say at what the story really is. It's not for everyone (if you're looking for action, item collection, etc.), but if you enjoy serene walks through nature to somewhat meloncholy music while talking to yourself with an Edgar Allan Poe voiceover, this is right up your alley!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												A lighthouse. Caves burning with stars. A moonlit bay. Altars of candles. A red beacon in the distance.Dear Esther evokes a sense of morose solitude, of persistent questions and scattered answers that require stitching together, like a gaping wound. It is not difficult to understand, but I found that wandering the island was in and of itself the reward. The reason. The question and the answer.The entire experience is breathtakingly beautiful, punctured by an exquisite score, a soft, dulcet narration, and the insatiable, earnest desire to simply explore. Thanks to the superb atmosphere, you are encouraged to stoke your curiosity. To savour the windswept cliffs, the shifting waters, the fragile moments of peace amidst ambiguity and doom. You will never lose your sense of direction, but you will lose yourself in the wonders of the island. You will want to come back. Dear Esther is, in a word, stunning.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game starts out very slow. So slow, you might want to just close it. Press on. The term "game" is used pretty loosely when describing Dear Esther. It's much less a game, and more an immersive experience. You walk the island you're on, listening to the narrator piece together the story as you progress forward. Things get a little more surreal as you go. I don't want to spoil anything, but it's an experience worth having - like watching a good movie. It's about the length of one too. Unfortunately, like watching a movie (think The Sixth Sense), once you know how it plays out, there's little in the form of replay value. Sure, you might take a stroll again, but this isn't a game that you'll soon come back to, or play over and over. My only real complaint is that you walk slow. Relentlessly slow. There is no option to run or jump, and the game sometimes provides two paths - which are equally worth scoping out - but when you take a path that requires you to then turn around and trek back down the same trail to the fork, it feels like a real grind. That being said, $10 feels steep for the experience, but it IS an experience worth having nonetheless.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Considering this game is often on sale for dirt-cheap (and included in many humble bundles) it might be worth checking out if you're a fan of atmospheric walking simulator games.  However, there are two things I wish I had known going into this title:1). As many have stated in the reviews, it is art not a game.  The only thing you control is movement.  There are no puzzles and there is no challenge whatsoever.  Because of the limited controls, this leads to my second major problem with the game.2). It can be agonizingly slow and tedious.  I understand thechineseroom's decision not to include a sprint button, as this game is quite short and it would feel out of place.  However, a simple fastwalk button (or making Esther walk faster than a drunk snail) would have helped tremendously.  At several points in the game, you find yourself at one end of a HUGE plain or cliff that you must traverse to the other.  You will also make many wrong turns and have to turn around and re-tread these massive terrains.  The game requires a lot of patience and, unfortunately, it fails to deliver.This game does succeed in its gorgeous visuals (easily the selling-point, oddly enough) and the conventional British narrator.  It also has a very open-ended conclusion if that's your sort of thing.  But ultimately I find it difficult to recommend Dear Esther as a good game, if it's even a game at all.  While I'm not bitter about the dollar I probably spent on this title through a humble bundle, I still want my hour and a half back.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												First of all I should say that I have so far found Dear Esther to be an intriguing, if not a lighthearted, experience. I'm glad I bought it, and I'm still discovering new threads to the story. That said, I can understand why some people wouldn't like it - it's not a traditional computer game in any sense. You can't jump, or run, or interact with the environment in any way. There's no guns, no goals, and no achievements. All you can do is wander slowly through a bleak but beautiful landscape, while the narrative unfolds.Dear Esther is a tale of love and loss, of grief and anger, of sickness and addiction, of the disintegration of a personality, and a desperate search for meaning amongst the ruins of a shattered life, of the hope for final redemption... oh, and yoghurt.There is, though, a trick to Dear Esther. The narrative, and various objects visible to the player, change every time you play. If you want to have any understanding of what's going on, you have to pay close attention not only to the dialogue, but also to the items around you - the photographs on the table, the letter on a pile of rubbish, the detritus on the beach. You have to play through it several times, because each time you gather different clues to the story. Whether you think the story is ever satisfactorily explained is a matter for you to decide. It certainly becomes more complicated. I find it fascinating.T : -)

Posted: February 24, 2012
												English------------Deutsch"It can only be a dead shepherd who has come to drunk drive you home.""Dear Esther...", everytime I heard his voice while playing sends a chill down my spine. The whole time you're trying to discover what happend, where you are and who Esther, the person the narrator is always mentioning, is. Very similar to David Lynch movies, like Mulholland Drive. One of the best walking simulators I've ever played. Not really relaxing/calming when you're easy to scare, like me. At the end you've got more questions than answers.++ great narrative++ beautiful and atmospheric scenery/visual effects++ melodramatic, yet still relaxing soundtrack++ no real solution, everyone has it's own theorie of what exactly happend++ voice actor fits perfectly in the whole setting-- linear, missing a few more options or different endings -- limited interaction with objects-----------------------------------------------------------------------"It can only be a dead shepherd who has come to drunk drive you home.""Dear Esther...", jedesmal wenn ich seine Stimme hörte, lief es mir eiskalt den Rücken runter, im positiven und negativem Sinn. Die meiste Spielzeit versuchst du herauszufinden was passiert ist, wo du bist und wer Esther, die Person die der Erzähler permanent erwähnt, überhaupt ist. Starke Ähnlichkeit zu David Lynch Filmen, wie Mulholland Drive. Einer der besten Walking Simulators die ich je gespielt habe. Die Stimmung ist wenig entspannend/ruhig, wenn du, wie ich, jemand bist der leicht zu erschrecken ist. Am Ende bleiben mehr Fragen als Antworten übrig.++ großartige Erzählweise++ wunderschönes und atmosphärisches Szenario/visuelle Effekte++ melodramatischer, dennoch entspannter Soundtrack++ keine richtige Auflösung, jeder stellt sich seine eigene Theroie zusammen++ Synchronsprecher passt sowohl von der Stimme als auch von der Erzählweise perfekt in das gesamte Setting-- linear, mir fehlten mehr Möglichkeiten oder mehr/unterschiedliche Enden-- eingeschränkte Möglichkeiten was Interaktion oder Untersuchung von Objekten angeht

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Off the beaten path.I'm so glad there are developers like The Chinese Room out there, putting poetry into games, creating alternatives to the blockbuster & AAA experiences.  Dear Esther deserves the praise it has received since its modest beginnings as a F2P Source mod.More than one friend recommended this to me yet it was never quite high enough on my backlog of indie titles.  If you have waited on this like me, I urge you to bump it to the top of your list and finish a playthrough - it only takes an hour!  The first few minutes take some getting used to (your character walks slowly, & very little actually happens).This really is a glorified walking simulator with none of the conventional objectives or gameplay, so it does challenge the "videogame" definition.  It is a game though, one you should play & finish if you're in a thoughtful mood & looking for new, different, outside the box.  It's strictly exploration based & tells a (partial) story.  Evidently more of that story is unveiled on subsequent playthroughs, but one is enough to put the picture together.The visuals are phenomenal given what this is.  The audio is also commendable.  Together they create a couple of quietly stunning moments throughout the hour long stroll.  The atmosphere is impressive for something so minimalistic.  I took a dozen screenshots then decided not to post them, because people should just play it and take in the sights & sounds for themselves.The writing was also great; again, I love that the developers decided to go with such a poetic treatment.  My brain enjoyed how the narrator's words initially seem like ramblings but slowly piece together into a kind of sense.I'm eager to see what else this developer comes up with.  Given their methods, the possibilities for interesting stories seem endless.  I recommend.

												This is a fantastic game, more of an interactive book than movie or game. The narrative is poetic, and moving. Graphically, every single frame is a painting and I found myself completely lost in the environments. If you fancy a break from run-and-gun, and just want a treat for your eyes that's easy, relaxing and visually stunning. This is a good shout. content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Understandably there are mixed reviews for this game. Generally people that seek out this game will do so because they have heard something about it that has interested them, or, at least, made them curious.So here are my two cents on some of the discussions that have been had:NO, this is not a 'game' in the conventional sense.NO, there is not any real 'gameplay'.NO, it will not test your skills YES, you are basically walking on an island to some music and narrative exposition.YES, it is slow paced and requires patience (which some may not have time for)YES, it will be art to some, and pointless or pretentious to others.Having got that out of the way, I, for one, loved this game. Again, it feels odd calling it a 'game' because it is basically an innovative way to use the medium to tell a story in a compelling way. 'Story' is pretty much all this is. A story being unravelled. However, in my opinion it is being told in the best medium possible to suit said story. The way I interpret it is almost a 'visual audiobook', that, like any storytelling, will give back to you what you put in.However, to simply call it a 'story' is still fairly vague and not that helpfull. So to provide more of a recommendation without spoiling the experience; to me, this is about grief. Explored through themes of life, death, nostalgia, guilt, isolation, generally through a romantacist exploration of a symbolic island. This was my experience, other's may get something different. If you want more of an idea, perhaps listen to the soundtrack on bandcamp by Jessica Curry.If you do not feel you have the time or patience, or are not in the frame of mind to sit passively and immerse yourself for an hour or two, I would give this a miss. But if you are tired of shooting up hookers, driving fast cars, and ranking up your combos list, and would like your mind to be more involved than your fingers, perhaps you should give it a try :)(p.s. I have no playtime listed as I played it before I had it on steam!)

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												The best way to describe Dear Esther is "different". It's not a game in the traditional sense. No points; no fail-state; no mechanics to speak of, other than walking at a leisurely pace and looking around from a first-person point of view. For the duration of this movie-length experience, you simply look around and listen. For the cynical, this is a walking simulator, or the next logical step in audio-book evolution, or perhaps just an interesting tool for testing the Oculus Rift. For people who expect games to keep pushing into the realm of art, this will seem like a refreshing change of pace.

It's time for you to get some alcohol, dim the lights and wear your headphones to hear about the events that led the unidentified narrator to his despair.Bornt as a free Half-Life² mod, Dear Esther has evolved into a fully-fledged Source "art-game", extremely well optimized, offering a pleasant and fluid experience on basically any hardware.

												  Great game, but ill give you some advices. Although it's a beatiful 'game'  with lots of symbolisms and a great design, it might be really unnerving to some people ( including myself), due to the solitude you may experience, it might even be a little 'depressing'. Also, try to investigate and understand each single part of the island that you are allowed to roam, cause it will add more sense to the story you'll be creating.   I wouldn't rate it, because I don't really consider it a game, but If I had to, AND ONLY JUDGING THE ARTISTICS ASPECTS, I would give it an 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Dear Esther.While playing this, which I was graciously given by a friend, I was captivated by it. Not only did it had a good story line that made you think and put the pieces all together, but it has some of my favorite quotes ever! The voice that narrates this game is perfect for the part, and the text is very relatable, at least to me.Yes, if you did not read the game description or know anything about this game, it is a walking simulator. WALKING. No sprint (which isn't necissary since the scenery is perfect for viewing and exploring by means of a leasurely stroll, not a quick paced jog. walking simulators are meant for walking, not jogging).Even though it is a walking simulator, it is well made, as the graphics are very well done, meeting up with the graphics of Skyrim in a sense. The landscape, as i mentioned above, is gorgeous! Not only that, but the sound design (to which I recommend using headphones as this game has super well done sound design, which helps add to the game's atmosphere) is perfect, with natural sounds mixing and blending well with the somewhat peaceful, yet ambient, background of the game itself.Overall, I would recommend this game. It is very enjoyable and has a rich atmosphere around it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												THE GOODDear Esther is not your ordinary game. In some respects, it is not a game at all. Focusing on environments and atmosphere rather than gameplay and action is a nice way to change the pace, but it will definitely put some people off. If you're a person who prefers Serious Sam and Doom over Amnesia and Proteus, I do not think this game is for you. The sound in the game is, well, not very exciting overall. The intro plops you into the island with explanation of why you are there, if you pay attention. The story is told by a nameless narrator, who talks about the island, his hobbies, and the mysterious Esther. Digging deeper into the story explains more about the characters and the settings, but only if you are willing to look.THE GREATThe game can be frightening and intense if you let it. Beautiful environments are accompanied by the haunting yet calming voice of the narrator, who tells his life to you. While not the best decision for gameplay, Dear Esther provides with an amazing narrative and an atmosphere that is so thick you could wrap yourself up in it. The first chapter is the make or break point in this game.While not looking very stunning, the first part does do its job to set up the second half of the game. Not giving away too much, but not boring you to the point of no return. The end of the second chapter is where it is its best. My aesthetic changes completely, music greets you immediately, and the haunting feeling kicks in. The third chapter is my personal favourite, with the climax of the game leaving you able to interpret it however you please.THE UGLYThere is no gameplay whatsoever. If the developers wanted gameplay, they could've at least given you the choice to turn off and on your flashlight, or maybe do some simple puzzle. Face the facts: You walk extremely slow. Perhaps for pacing, but it can be frustrating whil you spend the whole damn game going 10mph (That's metres, not miles). Also, for a game about discovery, there is very little to discover, not that you'd feel inclined to due the the speed of your walking. It can be quite boring if you're playing it after watching a walkthrough of it on Youtube, TwitchTV, or whatever place you use to watch gameplay videos, so I'd recommend not watching gameplay of Dear Esther before playing it. Also the visuals of Dear Esther deteriorates when it is put into videos, no matter how you set the graphical quality (1080p does NOT do this game justice via video).THE VERDICTThere are two types of people in the world. Type one is the type who prefer Proteus over Dear Esther, and the other type of people prefer Dear Esther over Proteus. I fall into the latter category, for many reasons. If in doubt, get it on a sale. If you like it, great news! If you don't, you spent $5 and 1.4GB 'playing' a game that you didn't like. Personally, I think that the third chapter is the best chapter in this game. For the first two chapters, you explore the island, and at the end of the second chapter, a forced plot point happens which sends you to the most beautiful part of this game. The final chapter wraps it up nicely, and some people will like the final chapter more, so suffice to say the second half f the game is generally liked more. Also, this is NOT a game for children. It can be difficult to understand and there are so many plot elements that are metaphors or relatively unusual.

number of helpful: 56 of 108 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I loaded up Dear Esther on my computer with high expectations. I'm a new gamer and have an arts background, so I have enjoyed exploring some of the indie games instead of the usual gun-blazing brain-blasters that seem to be so popular. I had just finished playing Gone Home and really enjoyed it. From the reviews I had read, Dear Esther was supposed to be an even better narrative-driven game. It wasn't.When I realized you can't DO anything -- no object engagement, swimming, or overcoming the tiniest of obstacles -- I patiently explored the island, waiting for something to happen. About an hour and a half into the game I decided to give up for the day, feeling like I'd seen a lot of stunningly beautiful landscapes, but that's about it. When I reloaded the game on another day, I discoverd I was forced to start from the beginning, and there was no way I was spending another hour and a half of walking an island with nothing happening just to get through the last of the dull storyline.I'm sure the story is great, though the metaphorical and lyrical language that guides the game was pushed too far and comes off a bit pompous-sounding. They tried too hard to be brilliant with this one, and it comes off as unnatural and forced. Skip it.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Recommend, with caveats. Most important: it's not really a 'game', in any meaningful sense of the word. It's more an interactive, beautiful, eerie, atmospheric story. If you think you might like that, it's probably worth a look. However, it is also incredibly short, and while it's not ridiculously priced, if you suspect you'd prefer to spend your money on a longer game... you might well be right. One final note: there is a longish section of the game where the camera angle and moving landscape combined to give me a real world headache, complete with nausea, which has never happened with any other game. It was very notsome, and given the length of time overall it took to play the game (broken up into sittings, because headache)... the headache probably lasted longer. Something to bear in mind if headaches might be a thing for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												I had to play this game for my Game Studies minor, and I have to say that I'm happy for it. We had to compare it to many definitions that humanity scientists have given about games (which fit both video games and board games, for example) and had to write a short essay about why Dear Esther can be considered a game or not, and what this has to say about those definitions or the game. If this hadn't been the case, I would have written Dear Esther off as simply a weird game that was an experience, but nothing more. Now that I have to continue thinking about it, trying to add to the scientific discussion, I realise that Dear Esther is so much more than just a game. It worms its way into the game scene and causes many of us to doubt what we consider a video game, and others become angry at this so-called atrocity. But it has everything a game needs: a goal, immersive scenery, a story that needs telling. The thing is that, in my opinion, the game just doesn't give a damn whether you enjoy it or not; it simply is what it is. You don't get rewarded for rushing through the game in half an hour to see if the end makes sense. You get rewarded for taking your time, going through it multiple times, scanning everything that you see and hear for clues that may or may not give answers. You decide your own reward, because you decide what you do: do you forget about this game, or do you try to figure out what the hell is going on? For some, realisation is reward enough. Others need closure and a credit roll. But this game just doesn't care. And I love it for that cheekiness.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												If you are an artistic person, I'd recommend this game. While the playthrough is short, the game itself offers an interesting way of story telling. And with that in mind, it is an experience that is quite special. The world itself is stunning and looks well done. The music is moving and only adds to the story telling experience. But I would not recommend this game should you not be interested in a short playthrough each time, and do not like the artistic side of games. Because this game is what I'd personally call a work of art. It's a story telling experience and it focuses on this heavily. It offers no gameplay other than exploring the available paths which are rather limited, but still pleasent, and listening to the story which varies each time you play.This is definitely an interesting experience. So if that is your cup of tea, then I do recommend giving this game a try, as it is very well done despite being so short.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2013
												Okay, this game is really only an hour and a half of talking and walking. The gamer has no more agency than a cameraman, and even then very few events take place live-- it's mostly just an observation of a world previously inhabited, and a story already lived. Anyway, whether you'll like it or not, Dear Esther is well worth trying.The question of player agency is one that comes up a lot. To what extent we actually control the games we play, as opposed to merely go through the motions the designer set forth for us. But in much the same way that a fighting game focuses on one mechanic to the exclusion of others, Esther manages to home in on the player-as-observer, that cutscene-less methodology of the Half-Lifes and Portals of the world, and in that way, provoke both thought and discussion on the topic.Plus, those ghosts are amazing.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												Possibly the most visually BEAUTIFUL game ever created.  Not to mention the most subtle "horror" game ever made:  There's apparently quite a number of ghosts to be spotted throughout, and you know how many I spotted on my first playthrough?  ZERO!  But there's plenty of YouTube videos to prove otherwise.     More than any other game I know of, this is definitely about what the player brings to the game.  If you don't like slowly moving through stunning, oddly spooky landscapes in which you MAY spot the occasional bit of activity other than grass blowing moodily in the breeze, this may not be the game for you.  Hell, it's barely even a "game" per se...more like a short (under two hour) journey through some awe-inspiring environments to an inevitably downbeat and haunting conclusion.     Not exactly "scary", and definitely not action-packed (to put it mildly!), this is nonetheless an experience worth indulging if you're the type of person who can get into something which is purely about MOOD and crap-all else.  Definitely NOT for those impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who can't even wait in a Left 4 Dead 2 lobby for longer than twenty-eight-point-four seconds without kicking up a fuss.  Kind of a stop-and-smell-the-flowers experience for the morbidly inclined.  If that sounds like you, you know what to do.Verdict: 8.5/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Dear Esther is a remarkable event. Not a game, exactly. More like an interactive tale.I don't think I'm giving anything away in saying that Dear Esther is not a traditional video game. It is a metaphorical journey, exploring sad themes of loss and regret. Your journey across the island is an evocation of a narrator's reflection on a single tragic event, and how it changed his (or possibly her) life.The story is not direct. It took about half of Dear Esther before the pieces began to fall in place for me, and there were many odd bits that I struggled to fit into the overall story. For example, it's not clear that the narration is all from a single person, or if it's the work of more than one person who experienced that same event. There are, I have learned, threads in the Steam forum dedicated to stringing the meaning of every bit of narration together, as if it's a puzzle to be solved. I'm not certain that it is meant to be solved, though. It's complicated, and it's subtle. I browsed those threads a bit after playing Dear Esther, and I was pleased to learn that there is no grand consensus on the meaning of this game.I suspect that a return trip through the island would make some elements more clear to me, but I am reluctant to take that journey again immediately. The experience of Dear Esther is like a beautifully-wrapped gift: much of the pleasure is derived in opening the package and admiring the craftsmanship; the gift within might not be the best part of the experience.Instead, I will treat dear Esther like a good book. It goes back on the shelf, and in a few years, I may get the desire to experience it again. Will I learn more in a second playthrough? Probably; I do when I read a good book again. But I've let a week go by before writing this review, and I find in reflection that Dear Esther was a powerful experience for me, and I'm pleased to simply reflect on the experience I've had. For now.One more comment: Dear Esther is also, perhaps unintentionally, a testament to the durability of the 10-year old Source engine. The island is beautiful. The vegetation is beautiful. The caves are breathtaking. It only takes an hour (or so) to play Dear Esther, but every moment is wallpaper-worthy. Even if this sort of "game" doesn't appeal to you, the stunning scenery is worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 20 of 38 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												My recommendation to anyone thinking about playing this game is to go into it with the proper mindset. It is not so much a game in the traditionally understood sense of the word. Rather, Dear Esther is an almost entirely cerebral experience. It works on the player in much the same way a good painting will effect an observer who sees in the art not merely a window looking out on our own world, but that same world slightly altered by the surreal, and thus bringing to light things about ourselves we might not otherwise see. That said, Dear Esther, by it's very poetic nature, is one of the most immediately captivating games I have encountered; I do not believe it should be overlooked simply because it does not conform to the usual way in which people have come to view video games.Overwhelming is the sense of solitude on this gloomy, desolate Hebridean island. Heavier still is the desperately sorrowful soundtrack, by Jessica Curry. In style, it is similar to film composer Christopher Young's most sparsely written music, and plays as a more effective voice in this introspective journey than does the admittedly potent narrator. I often find game music lacking in its ability to plunge beneath the fabric of a game and tug to light its individual and vibrantly beating heart, but this is a rare instance where such a feat is accomplished. Haunting as any chamber music has ever been, the score to Dear Esther will probe the emptiness within each of us, and get us contemplating questions most prefer to ignore.This is a relatively short journey, requiring the gamer to simply progress across the island until they have reached a lone radio mast. There are no decisions to be made, no objects to interact with, and the fragmented narration of the main character plays out as you progress. The epistolary narrative renders the intent of the story in a vague light, like a sequence of events seen through shimmering tears. It is debatable what Dear Esther is actually trying to say (and I believe it to have been done that way intentionally), but anyone willing to open themselves to the voices haunting this Scottish island are certain to draw some very strong conclusions.To me, the story deals primarily with unspeakable loss, and how we set ourselves up for even greater heartache (potentially leading even to madness) if God is not our anchor in all things. I, for one, see the issue of personal transcendence (as it is articulated at the end of the game by the main character's leap from the radio tower, who then begins a ghostly flight across the moon-dappled sea, followed by a black fade) to be illustrative not of our ability to achieve such a spiritual shift on our own, but exactly the opposite: There exists within fallen humanity a perpetual, aching cry to be delivered, redeemed--to transcend the shattering effects of our sinful natures.... But humanism cannot accomplish this miracle, nor any form of man-centered religion focusing on personal moral performance or upon the sincerity of their emotions as they are connected to a certain belief system. The blood of the Lord Jesus Christ is the only atonement by which we can be saved from all this death. He is the only peace, the only Truth. The end result of all other efforts at redemption lead only to chilly shadows and vacuous spaces brimming with regret.Hopefully sharing my personal interpretation of Dear Esther does not come across as a clumsy effort to proselytize (if that were the case, I would certainly have given the Gospel in its fullness), but rather illustrates the power and versatility the player can expect to experience by such an unconventional game as this.For anyone looking to plunge beneath the surface within themselves as they embark upon the solitary journey to the radio tower, Dear Esther offers surprising treasures that periodically flash their brilliance even years after the experience has ended.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												It's hard to write a review of this game, partly because whether or not it qualifies as a game is kind of hard to decide, and because it is such an emotional experience. Dear Esther is...well. The visuals are some of the most gorgeous things I have ever, ever seen in a game. There are certain views, different settings, even just the odd angle that absolutely took my breath away. The story is haunting and powerful, with scenes that were really moving. It's the gameplay that is so difficult to describe with any sort of appeal: there's no way to interact with your environment, no pick up/drop/hit/jump, anything. You can move, and you can swim a bit (really, it's just keeping you on the surface of the water), and that's all. You may wonder how any game can get away with that kind of control scheme, but Dear Esther does. It's a very touching story, and I found the ending powerful. Certainly worth the $2.50 I dropped on it for the Steam sale, I would say.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Preface: This is not actually a "game", it could be called a "semi-interactive 3D graphic novel with variable paths", it is not static, but interactions are limited to movement. However, there are opportunities for exploration and random elements.Who is Esther? Who is Donnely? Why are you on an island with old and recent ruins, but no signs of life except butterflies and vegetation? When and why did the seagulls leave? Did you just see something moving across the bay?"Dear Esther" probably answers these questions, but if, those answers are wrapped inside riddles of their own. What you do get, however, is an enthralling and haunting journey across and below the island, struggling to piece together the protagonist's cryptic notes to an absent beloved.The landscape, only a backdrop in ordinary "games", steps up to present itself unharbored by the things that usually clutter it. For an indie product based on an already outdated engine, the serene scenes rival reality itself (unless you look too close at the ground in front of you)Getting into this "game" may be difficult, as the first chapter opens with two somewhat long dead ends you may literally run into (though they technically belong to the story in an optional way) but afterwards, the path becomes more linear, and you stop more often to admire the splendid view than to reorientate.You will experience the story, reflect, and maybe come back at a later time to experience it again, in a different way and with a different view.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												A short, abstract story piece steeped heavily in metaphor.  Dear Esther is one of the more extreme examples of a story-driven game, to the point where it's arguable that it's not really a game and is nothing but a story, albeit one where the delivery changes slightly from playthrough to playthrough.  That isn't to say that I feel ripped off, nor is the quality of Dear Esther bad.  In fact, I'd say this... experience, let's call it, has some of the more well done level design, set pieces, textures, and other resources of games of this era.  In general, the visuals and sound were done very, very well.What Dear Esther will raise the most objections is, unsurprisingly, the gameplay, which as I mentioned is so minimal as to be arguably absent.  You do control a character and wander around, but aside from movement and zooming that is all you can do.  It's not surprising that this is one of the titles which coined the term "walking simulator", though I'd argue that in this case it's not to its detriment.  Could it have been better with some puzzles, more exploration, perhaps a few enemies?  Possibly, but it quite easily could have been worse, too.  Is it bad in its current form?  No, not if you go into it knowing what to expect.Like or hate the choice made about gameplay, it still forces Dear Esther to stand on the merits of its story and presentation.  In that regard, it does quite well.  The story is delivered via letters (real or imagined, we aren't sure) written to the titular Esther (who also may be real or imagined, we aren't sure), read aloud at periodic intervals by the narrator, who may or may not also be the player character, we're not sure.  In other stories this lack of certainty about anything and/or everything might be a detriment.  For Dear Esther it works well, especially given how metaphor-laden the story is.  What is the metaphor and what is the real story... well we're not sure.  Regardless of what is real and what is the metaphor, the letters are read with emotion and meaning, and the circumstances they describe make it easy for the player to find themselves invested in the fate of the narrator.As for presentation, Dear Esther does a wonderful job of setting a mood of desolation, loneliness, and spookiness (for lack of a better word) without being high stress or anxiety inducing.  If anything the overall pace is relaxing; you don't feel like you need to progress to the next area until you are absolutely ready to, not that there's always something to stay behind for. Will Dear Esther be for everyone?  No, definitely not.  But just because something isn't for everyone doesn't mean it's fundamentally bad.  For those who enjoy the "walking simulator" genre coupled with a fair bit of metaphor, Dear Esther is a good choice.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2012
												Less of a game and more of a traditional story, Dear Esther is best looked at like a strange and poetic tale about coping with loss. It eschews traditional gameplay and engagement for a slow and ponderous journey.  Its pacing gives the player the freedom to reflect on the subtleties of this extremely nuanced approach to storytelling.A word of caution: this breaks the mold of what one expects of gaming. Dear Esther can only give what you allow it to give, but to expect much more will only end in disappointment. A great example of gaming branching out into other forms of media.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												Dear Esther,It's been a while since I've felt so lonely. Where did the times of escapist games go? I don't remember the squawks of birds singing to my ears as a clear signal of their hostility, a pathological pointer of performances past. Every time I remember that night, the emotions rush back to me, the feeling that I should have done something lacerating the bones of my body.What should I have done? While I personally cannot vouch for certain, there are voices in my head, advices resounding. They sound like friends, old friends whose judgment I have trusted time before, and should continue to trust time again. I cannot say for sure who they are, but they only say one thing:"Get this game."It's a long shot, Esther, but I might just take it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Dear Esther supposedly transports the player to an island off the West Coast of England. The minimalistic pianomusic and the beautiful graphics stir an eerie feel of being lost in a desolate, deserted environment. As a game, Dear Esther is the sort of interactive medium that transcends the genre. Much like a great David Lynch movie should never be approached the same way one would approach a Star Wars, and is better to be perceived as a piece of art one gets to experience first hand. It hits home on a profound level without feeling the need to comprehend nor to put your finger directly on the heart of the matter. While information is seeping through in a disorderly way, it's only after the first play-through you start to analyse and put things into perspective, There's a reason the final cut scene is followed by a black screen you can only 'escape' from with said key. Still you'll be left with many questions and if you don't want to put hours into figuring it out, I srongly recommend the great youtube analysis on the game's story and events. For anyone who might get more thrilled by The Stanley Parable than Assassin's Creed, and prefers a good Kubrick or Lynch over an action packed blockbuster.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2012
												This is not a game.It's astoundingly, breathtakingly pretty. But it's not a game.That's not a criticism, it's fact. Not a game. Games interact with the player, this does not. It's quite literally a walk-through storybook. There is no interactivity of any kind, no puzzles, nothing to figure out. It has exactly the same level of interactivity as a ride through Pirates of the Caribbean at Disneyland. You can choose where to walk, but that's almost entirely linear, so you're really only choosing where to look while you're walking there.That said, it's still fairly interesting. I went fairly slowly, exploring everything I could, though none of that makes any difference because there's nothing to find. At a slow pace and as indirectly as the game allowed, the entire thing took under 90 minutes from start to finish.It was interesting, but at full price ($10) that comes out to more than ten cents per minute... so I'd at least recommend waiting for a big sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Rarely does a game have such impact on me. The word game is a stretch, its hard to even describe despite it despite being so simple. In most games you the player have an impact on the world. In this game the world and the narrative seem to impact the player. There are no goals, puzzles or quests. Only you and the experience and trying to make sense of the story and narration. In fact you could say its relaxing in a solitary and depressing fashion. Melancholy is a good word. The pensive and slow music, the sound of the violent ghostly wind and the cloudy depressing skies.  If you want action this is not the game for you. If you wnat to escape your real life and experience a profoundly emotional story through the exploration of a darkly beautiful deserted island, then this is for you.Some say 10 dollars is too much. But what price can you put on an experience that moves you and makes you feel and think? If nothing else, it shows that computer games can be so much more by being so much less, if that makes sense. I look forword to more game developers who follow in Dan's footsteps.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												A short, abstract story piece steeped heavily in metaphor.  Dear Esther is one of the more extreme examples of a story-driven game, to the point where it's arguable that it's not really a game and is nothing but a story, albeit one where the delivery changes slightly from playthrough to playthrough.  That isn't to say that I feel ripped off, nor is the quality of Dear Esther bad.  In fact, I'd say this... experience, let's call it, has some of the more well done level design, set pieces, textures, and other resources of games of this era.  In general, the visuals and sound were done very, very well.What Dear Esther will raise the most objections is, unsurprisingly, the gameplay, which as I mentioned is so minimal as to be arguably absent.  You do control a character and wander around, but aside from movement and zooming that is all you can do.  It's not surprising that this is one of the titles which coined the term "walking simulator", though I'd argue that in this case it's not to its detriment.  Could it have been better with some puzzles, more exploration, perhaps a few enemies?  Possibly, but it quite easily could have been worse, too.  Is it bad in its current form?  No, not if you go into it knowing what to expect.Like or hate the choice made about gameplay, it still forces Dear Esther to stand on the merits of its story and presentation.  In that regard, it does quite well.  The story is delivered via letters (real or imagined, we aren't sure) written to the titular Esther (who also may be real or imagined, we aren't sure), read aloud at periodic intervals by the narrator, who may or may not also be the player character, we're not sure.  In other stories this lack of certainty about anything and/or everything might be a detriment.  For Dear Esther it works well, especially given how metaphor-laden the story is.  What is the metaphor and what is the real story... well we're not sure.  Regardless of what is real and what is the metaphor, the letters are read with emotion and meaning, and the circumstances they describe make it easy for the player to find themselves invested in the fate of the narrator.As for presentation, Dear Esther does a wonderful job of setting a mood of desolation, loneliness, and spookiness (for lack of a better word) without being high stress or anxiety inducing.  If anything the overall pace is relaxing; you don't feel like you need to progress to the next area until you are absolutely ready to, not that there's always something to stay behind for. Will Dear Esther be for everyone?  No, definitely not.  But just because something isn't for everyone doesn't mean it's fundamentally bad.  For those who enjoy the "walking simulator" genre coupled with a fair bit of metaphor, Dear Esther is a good choice.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2013
												Game, Art, Storybook Novel?  Many Steam members have problems with Dear Esther - first of all it being a Free Mod and now is $10 on Steam and secondly the fact that this does not play out like a game per se at all.  In reality yes you just move forward and hit "w".  Sometimes (if your like me) you just need a break from all the blockbuster in your face action packed complex games that are available and Dear Esther for me fills that void.This interactive story shows off some incredible detail using the Source Engine.  I cranked the detal to all High and it looks sweet, really great scenery and environments.  The lush landscape is great - some of the best grass and water effects I have ever seen.  The textures are vivid and appear so realistic, in the caves portion surfaces look all wet - way cool.  The game comes with an interesting soundtrack that is a good balance and mix for the overall tone.There is no sense of direction in the game, you simply explore the somewhat linear path as pieces of the puzzle and narrative are revealed to you.  Again in case your not aware - there is no combat or anything it is a simple exploration story game.If your looking for a game to add to your casual game library then Dear Esther is  ✓Recommended for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												It's somewhat a rarity that I say this, when it comes down to walking simulator type games, but Dear Esther was quite a joy to play. With a fairly good story that has a sad but slightly uplifting ending, but I'd rather not spoil it. The island you explore throughout the game, although I use that term loosely, is somewhat beautiful and enchanting. There are mysterious caves to explore and quite breathtaking coastlines adorned with shipwrecks. As you explore the island you also quickly realize you are not quite alone. Strange figures stand watching you from a distance giving you a slight sense of unease. The game itself isn't all that long, taking just over half an hour to complete, that is of course if you don't go off exploring. There are several landmarks dotted around the island which serve little purpose other than to take screenshots of. But really it's best to stick to the main trail.Overall the game follows a fairly interesting narrative and combines it with a quite beautiful setting. It is of course a walking simulator and so there is very little to do other than explore the island, but if walking sims are your cup of tea then go ahead and give Dear Esther a go. But I only recommend it for those who enjoy narratives and exploration. Good day!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Dear Esther is an odd duck. This indie title screams, well, "indie".Artsy? CheckAmbitious? CheckAmbiguous? CheckBrief? CheckLacking Mass Appeal? CheckTo describe the game too well would spoil the experience. You begin on the shore of an island, with a narrator who may or may not be the voice of your character spouting difficult to follow lines with no context. You can wander (slowly) about the island, but you cannot jump or climb, and invisible walls keep you on the winding paths for the most part. You cannot interact with your environment, and there are no puzzles or challenges to overcome anyway. The only element of agency the player is given is the freedom to slowly walk about the island within the confines of the limited walkways.If that doesn't sound like much of a game to you, well, its not. Its not quite an interactive story either. Trying to piece together what the whole thing is all about is the only point to the experience. Once you have completed the game, you'll likely spend a few moments trying to piece together all the narrator's lines, and you might even consider playing through again so you can understand it all better. But if you do, you'll quickly realize there is simply no substance to the experience. The only motivation you had for progressing the first time around was to discover your motivation.It should probably be said that Dear Esther's environments are stunning and the haunting score is top-notch. But for all the beauty of Dear Esther's levels, you may feel resentful that you have no choice but to painstakingly amble through them without ever really feeling like you got to explore the place.Is Dear Esther worth the ticket price? Probably not for most of us. If you're a staunch patron of the indie devs, you probably already have it. For the rest of us, Dear Esther is a strange experiement or an unusual distraction, and not a feature worth shelling out for. But if you love wierd, high-brow indie titles, maybe Dear Esther is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Dear Esther has a beautiful narrative. Boasts glorious graphics. And a fantastic sound design.So is the game perfect? No, no game is perfect. The problem with Dear Esther is that it's genre is "first person experiment/art". It's not that experimental. It didn't change the way games are played. It didn't even go as far as trying to emulate Myst, which is what I first thought of when I heard about this game being about a character stranded on a mysterious island. But is he actually stranded?Well. The game is certainly mysterious, but the island is not. It's the player character who traverses across the island to reach the radio tower's mast. And while doing so, sees candles already lit, beautiful caverns, painted stones and hallucinates an accident on a UK highway. There were a few times when I asked myself, "Is this a dream?"From what you gather from the narrations, which are usually different each playthrough, is that the main narrator was in a car accident and his wife, presumably Esther, died. The context is slim, but you gather this much from the narration and the objects laid out across the island, like car parts, white paint cans, tires, letters, and abandoned boats.If I could call the game one word, it would be surreal, because it certainly doesn't abode as right. For the man supposed washed ashore this island following an accident on the mainland. That's surreal and unlikely.But it's sure as ♥♥♥♥ interesting and makes you wonder why the devs went with this game design and ploy. I liked it for what it is, mysterious and warranting a second playthrough based on the wonderful narrative.8.0/10

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												How do I explain this...Dear Esther is a story portrayed as an expierience. For those of you that want something with guns and monsters and jumpscares you'll be disappointed. This isn't that game. If you're looking for something that wil make you think, and requires more than just one sitting to get the point, THIS IS the game.The game takes anywhere from 50 (If you're rushing) minutes to 1 Hour and 10 (if you're really paying attention and trying to figure things out.) It does take about 4 playthroughs to get ALL the commentary, as it is Semi randomized for the purposes of immersion. And it IS immersive. You'll WANT to know who this guy is, you'll want to know what the island is about, and you'll WANT to hear the entire story.9.5/10. Not 10 out of 10 because there is no Sprinting, so it progresses slowly. Hence the hour long play time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												To call this a game would be almost entirely inaccurate; Dear Esther is more of a poem about the degradation of the mind, rather than a game itself. An engaging story of a man struggling with the death of his love, abandonment, guilt and his ultimate delve into insanity at the hands of an unforgiving, desolate island. The visuals, the weather, the sounds, the music and the narration all came together to bring an experience that was as immense and gratifying as the best of most genres. Dear Esther is a successful experiment and a singular experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												In a word, perfection.  It's not a game in the traditional sense, not even close.  But, it is an experience that you won't forget.  You'll hit the screenshot button so many times at first due to the beautiful lighting and atmotsphere.  Eventually, I forgot to take screenshots because the story, the island, and the musical score drew me as I explored the caves.  Drawing your own conclusion is the "point" to this "game."Lighting is incredible and gives the island a dream-like feel.  Narration is spot-on although some later lines were done by a different narrator than you usually hear, which was annoying as their speeds of reading lines are very different.Note:Turn up the graphics under Options\Advanced Settings.  The increase in graphic settings didn't seem to effect my fps at all but it definitely made the game look a lot better.Also, you may get annoyed with the speed at which you move and the lack of "sprinting" ability.  But remember why you are meant to move slowly: to take it all in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												Technically classified as a game, although there's hardly any gameplay involved. Dear Esther is an interesting concept that provides beautiful vistas and a captivating tale. Jessica Curry's musical score paints the somber and desolate theme wonderfully, which helped most of the game's graceful moments. That being said, it's freshing to witness game design that has a focus of showcasing artistic design for the gamer's interpretation, and providing a thought-provoking story, rather than traditional gameplay. If that at least vaguely interests you, despite its flaws, the game's two hours is definitely worth to experience. It's exciting to just know how there will be future games that'll follow suit of this concept, which will enhance the medium of storytelling in video games with minimal gameplay. Because it's artful.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												A single review can't do this game justice.If you asked me to assign a numerical score to Dear Esther, I would be at a loss. The depth and significance of the ideas here are beyond any kind of quantification or simplistic analysis.I don't mean the thematic ideas: I mean the ideas for what video games can be, how they can rise beyond the pedestrian realms they have almost exclusively inhabited until recently. It's a very rare game that can take me out of myself, give me a truly emotional and intellectual experience.If you care about video games at all, you owe it to yourself to play Dear Esther.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Dear Esther supposedly transports the player to an island off the West Coast of England. The minimalistic pianomusic and the beautiful graphics stir an eerie feel of being lost in a desolate, deserted environment. As a game, Dear Esther is the sort of interactive medium that transcends the genre. Much like a great David Lynch movie should never be approached the same way one would approach a Star Wars, and is better to be perceived as a piece of art one gets to experience first hand. It hits home on a profound level without feeling the need to comprehend nor to put your finger directly on the heart of the matter. While information is seeping through in a disorderly way, it's only after the first play-through you start to analyse and put things into perspective, There's a reason the final cut scene is followed by a black screen you can only 'escape' from with said key. Still you'll be left with many questions and if you don't want to put hours into figuring it out, I srongly recommend the great youtube analysis on the game's story and events. For anyone who might get more thrilled by The Stanley Parable than Assassin's Creed, and prefers a good Kubrick or Lynch over an action packed blockbuster.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Difficult to recommend this game because in general, I have little time for indie games at all.I'm willing to make an exception here, on the proviso that you all understand this isn't strictly speaking a game, rather a mildly interactive short story.   A rather dark story with a gloomy atmosphere.Regardless, the graphics are impressive for an indy game, running very smoothly at 4K with a respectable set of customisations.    Narration is tasteful and effective.Atmospherically, the game hits the mark square on.   I won't go too deeply into it, because I recommend the curious should follow the grim story themselves, perhaps late at night with the lights turned down and a comforting glass of red.  The gameplay doesn't go on for long, which is appropriate, it's a novella, but the price isn't particularly high, either.Thumbs up for hitting the mark, doing something worthwhile, although I should stress this isn't a game in the classic sense, featuring only limited interaction with the environment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Short review about this game:The game is a small piece of art that is both appealing and boring at same time. The scenario is that you are stranded on a forgotten island and are free to explore its corners while a voice of a narrator accompanies you on your quite short journey. The island seems really beatiful in most places, especially having amazingly interesting caves with great artwork and gorgeous landscapes. The well composed music fits into the atmosphere and makes the journey relaxed, but still concentrated on the story.If you let yourself become part of the narrator's story and truly breath in this short but beatiful piece of art work, then im sure you will have some thoughts after the game about what actually happened, who's story it was and what can you learn out of it for your life. Maybe philosophical, maybe melancholic, but for sure enjoayble few hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												Where do I start. Let me begin with telling you that this is not a game. It's a story.It's an experience, and quite frankly nothing like I expected or ever encountered before. The way Dear Esther has been built up, has made it the most immersive storytelling I've been through. It unfolds as you make your way through a, quite possibly the single most beautiful, virtual island. It is truely unlike anything I've ever "played", and though I picked it up at the Steam Sale for just a meager €2 it is in fact, already the most valuable item in my Steam library. I don't just recommend this, I urge you to try this. It's not just a story either - visually it is by far the most impressive thing I've seen crafted with the source engine, possibly one of the prettiest game environments made too. Then there is the soundtrack; looking back at it I should've bought the game bundled with that soundtrack - it touches you right where it wants to. To all still reading this, make time to play this pearl.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												It's amazing that a game in which the only gameplay mechanic is walking can be so engrossing, let alone provide such a deep psychological impact. Your journey will take you across beautiful landscapes that provide a strong sense of solitude, while incredible voice acting will reveal bits of the mysterious story. This game is best played in one sitting. All of the scenes blend together and prepare you for an ending that will send shivers up your spine. All that said, the price is a bit steep for the playtime.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												You start out on the docks of an island. The only thing that you know is that your name is Esther, and that someone is reading his letters to you. Playing in first person, you wander around a breathtaking environment, discovering the truth behind the island's infection and the fate of its inhabitants. While you walk, the narrator keeps informing you about what happened in the past, while you absorb the landscape's natural beauty and unveil a mystery on an island lost in time and space.The game is divided in 4 different chapters of short length. Dear Esther's goal is not to glue you in front of the screen for hours of challenge. It is to make you feel like you are taking part in a story that is narrated according to the letters and at the same time depicted on the effects of your surroundings before your very own eyes. The graphics are challenging for your pc but also extremely immersive for you as a result, and the soundtrack is magnificent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												if you're anything like me, truly enjoying this game will require you to abandon your gamer instincts and play the game in a way which goes against what other games have taught you.  at the heart of this game is simply the wonderment of exploring this surreal island.  when i play a game centered on exploration, it's only in my nature to want to find hidden things.  to that end, i would often try to go against the grain.  i would try to find the less obvious path in the hopes that it would lead me to some enlightening secret.  if this sounds like you, abondon that thought process immediately.  the best way to enjoy this game is to simply trust it to lead you where you need to go.  the game has a certain flow, and it's in your best interest to go with it in order to have the most cohesive experience possible.  the game merits, and in some ways even requires multiple play-throughs, so keep that in mind and don't let yourself get too obsessive about seeing everything the first time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2013
												First off, this is not a game. If you go into this with those expectations, you'll be disappointed from the get go. Rather, this is an interactive experience.You may complain that you can't even run in this game, but that can be argued back as being a deliberate choice on the developers' part, one for keeping the pacing the way they want it to be able to tell you the story, and two, so you don't have to blitz through it, as this is quite short. It rewards exploration, as specific parts in the island will give you some lines from the fine narrator giving you tidbits of information about what may or what may not have happened here.It won't hurt your eyes either. Visually it's beautiful and just sucks you in with its richly done environments, managing to further immerse you into the story, which in the end, is what all of this is about.However this is hard to recommend. It's most definitely not for everyone, you could either absolutely love it, or hate it the second you start it. But it is very unique and good at what it ultimately does. Definitely pick it up in a sale to be absolutely sure whether or not this is your cup of tea. You may run into a gem here.

It is more of a interactive art book, featuring how beautiful the Source Engine can be when its pushed to its boundaries.Throughout the 'game', you simply walk, can look at objects and from time to time, the character tells parts of a letter. Randomized through each playthrough, it can be replayed when one wants without hearing the same thing over and over.The other thing this game has, is a very nice, calming game soundtrack that captures the feeling of the game perfectly.So, this is a true recommendation. IF you know what you are buying. Don't buy it not knowing anything about it. Don't expect violence. Don't expect explosions. Don't expect enemies. It is a interactive art book wherein you walk and can freely look, made with the Source Engine.I liked this little game, hopefully many others can as well. :)A definite 8/10 at least.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2012
												A quiet, reflective piece of art that is more of an interactive narrative than a game. As you progress through the landscape, the environment and narrative reveals your past and gives you clues as to who you are and why you are on the island...and what the island is. This game is like one of those short stories you had to read in English class. I happen to love interpreting metaphors and symbolism in literature, so this is a great pickup for me. But since it is so short  (I beat it in an hour), I suggest waiting until it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												This is not a "game", but an interactive art story that follows the footsteps of a dying man, telling the haunting tale of the loss of a loved one. There are no enemies, no NPCs, no towns, no items, no skills--just you, the solemn Hebrides Islands, and the memory of a woman turned opaque.The premise is simple: you explore, and at certain checkpoints the narrator recounts his regrets. Remember that this game is meant to be art, so there's no extensive gameplay involved--only a sobering experience to be had. There's no rush here--you take your time, knowing that you will soon be together with Dear Esther.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												Alright I'll write a review. Never done this before :(The game 'Dear Esther' started as a HL2 mod that recieved great praise due to completely leaving behind traditional gameplay mechanics, and instead focusing on you, the player, and how to form a relationship with the game. Shortly after development restarted in order to release it as a full game. The overhaul tooks a few years but in February of 2012, it was finally released.STORY:The story is randomly generated with new input being given from a narrator. He is the only human thing that you will encounter throughout your exploration on the abondoned island. The story get's a dramatic boost due to how the atmosphere draws you in, and with different readings being read to you from each playthrough, the more you re-enter 'Dear Esther' the better the story gets. It get's more mysterious each playthrough and leaves you wanting so much more, but never fully delivers. This leaves it open for speculation from the players, but that's what makes it so great. Everyone has an opinion and it can be further developed with subsequent playthroughs.The lack of a firm story may be ugly for some people, as the story pushes for you to think and put together the pieces of the puzzles and form your own opinion. However one this is for sure: you will be thinking about the story for days after playing 'Dear Esther'.GAMEPLAY:There really isn't much gameplay to talk about. You move at a walking pace and are confined to one button that zooms in ever-so slightly, but it doesn't feel enough. Every now and then when you enter a dim crevice, a flashlight will automatically turn on to help fill the area with light. If you are looking for a game that you want to control, rather then said game controlling you, this isn't the game for you. It's a bit difficult to bring yourself into the slow pace of the game, and it should have done a segmant to get the player in the mood (like old movies and how they play music for like 5 minutes before it actually begins, to get the audience in the mood of the movie) and it may allow the game to be more inviting to newcommers. You need to enter the game with an open mind, or you won't finish it. Simple as that.GRAPHICS:Compared to the games that are out, it lacks in quality. However, in comparison to games running on the Source Engine, it is breathtaking. The game is stunning, you will stop just to look  at the hills and mountains in the distance. You can see the formations of waves around the island and how they collide with the shore. You can count the clouds and watch how they manipulate the sky. The graphics contribute to the game's atmosphere greatly and make you sincerely appreciate how much work the developers put into the game. Be prepaired to get goose-bumps from the very beginning all the way to the end! There are some issues though: the 2d animated sprites for the bushes get distracting and are a bit annoying, considering how many are placed around the game. This issue is resolved when entering the cave segmants, but I wish the developers would have used a less distracting method to fill the landscape.SUMMARY:'Dear Esther' simply took my breath away and I'm still thinking about the game, months after I played it. The mystery that surrounds the island and your character is stunning, and it makes you want to really know the people that you are told about. The atmosphere will give you goosebumps and you will find yourself staring at greatly-detailed things that most games overlook. Overall, if you are willing to endulge yourself in a game without being immature, this is a great game for you!9.0/10

content:
Posted: February 25, 2012
												Hey guys, a lot of people have been asking me to tell them what I think of this game, so I'm going to write a review.  This "game" is definitely not for a majorty of people who regularly play games in general, but it's more for the people who want a short story where they can explore.  The pacing is incredibly slow, but it's mainly because of the limitation of your walk-speed (it's slower than crouchwalking in most FPS games nowadays).  It took me 1.1 hours to fully complete this game, and I was exploring everywhere I could and even got stuck on two parts!  It's a very short game, but the last half really impressed me with the music and the visual treats that you would have expected if you were following anything about this game.  I like artistic things like this, so I enjoyed it a bit, although I really honestly didn't like the first half and thought it was the most boring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t ever, but every game has its flaws.  Don't expect anything other than a visual treat with a story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												if you're anything like me, truly enjoying this game will require you to abandon your gamer instincts and play the game in a way which goes against what other games have taught you.  at the heart of this game is simply the wonderment of exploring this surreal island.  when i play a game centered on exploration, it's only in my nature to want to find hidden things.  to that end, i would often try to go against the grain.  i would try to find the less obvious path in the hopes that it would lead me to some enlightening secret.  if this sounds like you, abondon that thought process immediately.  the best way to enjoy this game is to simply trust it to lead you where you need to go.  the game has a certain flow, and it's in your best interest to go with it in order to have the most cohesive experience possible.  the game merits, and in some ways even requires multiple play-throughs, so keep that in mind and don't let yourself get too obsessive about seeing everything the first time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2013
												First off, this is not a game. If you go into this with those expectations, you'll be disappointed from the get go. Rather, this is an interactive experience.You may complain that you can't even run in this game, but that can be argued back as being a deliberate choice on the developers' part, one for keeping the pacing the way they want it to be able to tell you the story, and two, so you don't have to blitz through it, as this is quite short. It rewards exploration, as specific parts in the island will give you some lines from the fine narrator giving you tidbits of information about what may or what may not have happened here.It won't hurt your eyes either. Visually it's beautiful and just sucks you in with its richly done environments, managing to further immerse you into the story, which in the end, is what all of this is about.However this is hard to recommend. It's most definitely not for everyone, you could either absolutely love it, or hate it the second you start it. But it is very unique and good at what it ultimately does. Definitely pick it up in a sale to be absolutely sure whether or not this is your cup of tea. You may run into a gem here.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Dear Esther is a strange game.If you're looking for action, it's not for you. This is a quiet way to spend an hour. Just wander through a story.It's not a long game (you're unlikely to need more than an hour and a half to play it all the way through unless you spend forever trying to make out every little detail), but it looks beautiful, and has some wonderful music (which makes the version with the soundtrack worth getting if you like slow and atmospheric stuff).Seriously, this is a game you buy for the visuals (especially in the more surreal parts of the game). The fact that the story changes a little each time you play gives you an excuse to go and look at them all again.I break it out for a relaxing afternoon every now and then, and recommend buying it for just that purpose.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												"Dear Esther" is a simply astonishing indie game that enchants you with its vibrant fluorescent colours, its calming and mysterious ambience and of course its slow but driving story. The story really makes you feel like you are in the game itself, you are the character, you live on that island. The map is somewhat open, although it somehow makes you go a certain path which leads you to always new exciting or somehow sad places that always connect to the storyline in some way. "Dear Esther"'s soundtrack is one art for itself though. It always plays the right calming and chilling music and underlines the storyline perfectly. You may have many questions towards the story like "What is this, I'm used to open worlds and dragons!?" The real question that you ask yourself once you see the island for the first time though is: "How did I get here and what exactly am I doing here?"

												Before playing the game, you must realize, you do not interact whatsoever... it's basically like a first person movie if anything. If i'm honest, the first 5-15 minutes of the game were spent me walking around mindlessly, not really interested in the story and not at all understanding where to go, as that was never said. Though, roughly 30 minutes in I began developing an interest in the story. The ending (trying to keep it spoiler free) is very sad, although, this may be because I am very empathetic, and I can understand how some people might not have the same feelings towards the game.Now onto the graphics/art... me being very fascinated by art and different types of scenery, this game was jaw droppingly beautiful. I couldn't stop admiring the art as I played. Some may see such a thing as a destraction, but this really added to the story. Overall, great game, i'd recommend to anyone who is willing to sit down for a story from time to time.
