content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Dear Esther is one of my favorite games, and it's one that is greater than the sum of its parts.Let me start off with the basics. The game seems boring. You're a guy walking on an island. No enemies, no challenges, no explosions. However, the game makes it work. You're looking for something: Memories? Esther? Salvation? The atmosphere pulls you in, the music coaxes you along. You have this beautifully rendered island ahead of you, composed of somber hues. The red, blinking eye of a radio tower beckons on the horizon. The sun is setting.I'll admit, my description probably isn't very compelling, but the game is stunningly beautiful, if you give it a chance. The poetic narrative piques your curiosity. The musical score is both ambient and thoughtful and fits the game perfectly. The voice acting is stellar, and even though certain lines do get wordy, it works. Finally, every playthrough is slightly different. Now, that's probably not enough incentive to get you to play through the game again, but I'm glad I did. Something happened in my second playthrough that made it completely worth it. To be honest, it took my breath away. Here's my bottom line: 90% recommendedGameplay: 6/10 - There's not much to the gameplay. After all, you are essentially walking through an incredibly well disguised set of hallways. They are really well disguised though. Story: 8/10 - The minimalist storytelling could get frustrating if you're someone who hates BS. You have to let yourself get swept up by the aesthetics of the moment to really get the most out of it. The "bits and pieces" storytelling is neat, though. You almost feel like you're walking through the hallways of your mind, slowly discovering old memories. I gave it an 8 for the artistry. Graphics: 9/10 - Some of the most impressive Source engine graphics I've seen yet. They just work.Sound: 10/10 - The music is definitely one of my favorite parts about the game. It just does its job so well. Additionally, the ambient sounds such as the ocean waves and the wind seem very organic. They're very well done.Acting: 10/10 - Very convincing. A worse actor would not have been able to pull off the artsy dialogue.Controls: 10/10 - Simple. WADS to move, mouse to look. It allows you to focus on the game instead of on the buttons.GUI/Menus: 10/10 - Unobtrusive, elegant. What more can I say?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2013
												Game, Art, Storybook Novel?  Many Steam members have problems with Dear Esther - first of all it being a Free Mod and now is $10 on Steam and secondly the fact that this does not play out like a game per se at all.  In reality yes you just move forward and hit "w".  Sometimes (if your like me) you just need a break from all the blockbuster in your face action packed complex games that are available and Dear Esther for me fills that void.This interactive story shows off some incredible detail using the Source Engine.  I cranked the detal to all High and it looks sweet, really great scenery and environments.  The lush landscape is great - some of the best grass and water effects I have ever seen.  The textures are vivid and appear so realistic, in the caves portion surfaces look all wet - way cool.  The game comes with an interesting soundtrack that is a good balance and mix for the overall tone.There is no sense of direction in the game, you simply explore the somewhat linear path as pieces of the puzzle and narrative are revealed to you.  Again in case your not aware - there is no combat or anything it is a simple exploration story game.If your looking for a game to add to your casual game library then Dear Esther is  ✓Recommended for you!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												"Dear Esther" is everything but a video game and it most certainly should not be referred to as a "game". A interesting debate can spiral from here, regarding how the lack of differentiation from "Third/First Person Virtual Experience" and "Video Game" has torn assunder gamers and industry, but that is not what you need to know. You need to know that "Dear Esther" is a superbly executed, brilliantly written, beautiful and cinematic piece of interactive poetry that is not for everyone.If you are interested in a game, skip this. If you are interested in a emotional experience that will leave your soul wandering a inner abyss - embark. Lacking in interactivity, void of an actual goal and crafted for those of us who seek to the higher ends of the potential art in the gaming experience... If anything or everything written here excites you, you need to feel this. If not, carry on, but do come back on a later age, because it is worth trying.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2012
												It contains beautiful scenery, but more than that it makes you feel like you are actually there. Not in a cheap realism kind of way, but in the way the atmosphere starts to fall over you and draw you in. The storyline winds and fades in and out so that you piece together what you can. It feels like the island itself is somehow responding to your figure slowly making its way across it, changing as you pass. The intricate, sideways comments somehow talk about life and death more directly than most other stories have.  Don't pass this one up. It is beautiful, something you will remember for years to come, and the like of which cannot be experienced anywhere else. You will feel peace. You will feel loneliness. You will feel sadness. And you will feel awe. Once you have played it for yourself, you are welcome to hear my recording of my thoughts as I passed across the island myself. https://docs.google.com/leaf?id=0B32VpC9sVMpNZWU5MDI1NDEtZDY2Mi00ZmYwLTg5NjQtYWIxMDQzYWMzNGJm

												a dripstone cave ♥, bioluminescent fungi, phosphorescent moss, crystals, candles in nature, a full moon, a lost stormy beach and grassy hills... Dear Esther is a spiritual experience. it is visually poetic, profound in form and content, and absolutely magical.it starts quite plain but with a captivating atmosphere and slowly develops into an almost otherworldly, mystical journey. yes, you do have to do a lot of (slow) walking and, eventhough i am a quite slowpaced person, i first wasn't sure if i wanted to continue. i'm glad i did, because the journey concludes in a touching and extraordinary experience { - the cave - } which is open for a lot of interpretation. the last chapter had an emotionally healing effect on me - i have never experienced something as powerful in a videogame before.take your time "playing" this, maybe even at night. it is pure beauty.

												You wander about an uninhabited island, observing and listening to segments of letters the narrator wrote to Esther.  Firstly, this is a story, not a game. It is only slightly interactive, you can not influence the outcome, but you can vary what you hear depending where you wander.  But there is nothing to solve and you can reach the end of the game without visiting all the places. I really don’t know what to make of this “game”.  It is a sad, haunting tale that is rather depressing.  Certainly, this is not one to cheer you up.  I think overall I have to recommend it, because it's just so well done, but I am afraid I am a happy ending type of person and had I known how haunting this little tale was going to be, I would not have bought it.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												It's basically a walk and explore game. You wash up on a deserted dock and start exploring an "abandoned" island. Graphically beautiful and with a strong story that the player simply uncovers by moving from location to location, this is a very relaxing game. Sounds, freedom to explore however you like, no complicated puzzles, beautifull graphics and smooth rendering environment and superb game mechanics. The sound Track is by Jessical Curry (and available separately.)Exploring the island is really a metaphor for the struggle in your mind as you mull over a motorway tragedy and you are left with the task of unpicking the guilt, the loss of what happened as well as why. If you complete this game without digging out any skeletons in your own closet, do let me know how you did that.5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												I've had this experience in my library for a while now and it's taken me quite a while to decide whether or not to recommend this experience to the steam community.  I call it an experience because that's essentially all it is.  There's no real gameplay element to it aside from exploration and reflection.  This is essentially why I've had such a hard time deciding how to approach my recommendation (or possible non-recommendation) of this title.Now, I've never experienced the original mod that this solo release is based off of, so I'm submitting my thoughts as a result of only experiencing this particular version of "Dear Esther."  I view "Dear Esther" as an artistic experiment of immersion and subtle and vague storytelling where the user who experiences it is free to interpret it in their own way and come away with their own tailored experience.  Exploration is the main focus of "Dear Esther" and I mean that in a physical and verbal sense.  The more you explore of "Dear Esther's" world, the more of the story is shared with you.  It's exploration in a mostly linear sense, but there is still some illusion of freedom given to the user.  You'll likely find yourself looking everywhere and "touching" everything to try to shed more light on what is actually going on.  In a more clear sense, "Dear Esther" will likely make you feel as though you've stepped into a physical representation of the narrator’s journal, and essentially, that's the point in its design.  Total immersion.  There's no fighting.  There's no inventory management.  There's no health/mana/energy to worry about.  It's a story where you control the pace by moving through a world that's designed to expose more exposition eventually leading to realization and ending on the climax interestingly enough.  The resolution is left to you to decide, and that's not to say that "Dear Esther" is a complete cliff-hanger.  It's certainly not.  There is a solid and clear end, but the end is not a resolution.  You'll have to decide for yourself what, exactly, you just experienced, and what the ending means to you.Does it sound pretentious?  It should, because it most certainly can be if that's how you judge your experience.  If you're willing to reflect beyond the potential pretentiousness of it all, you may find something you like, possibly quite a bit.  I decided to go ahead and recommend this title because I believe it is an important experiment in how video game engines can be used to tell stories in an interesting way.  That's not meant to discount how well video games already tell stories, but I found it interesting enough to advise people to experience a different approach to virtual storytelling.  I'm sure a lot of "gamers" will dislike this title, but I honestly think a majority of Steam users will see the value in "Dear Esther" and what it represents.  For me, it was worth the cost as I enjoyed the experience (I'm the type of player that's always exploring and clicking on everything anyway.  Seriously, my play through times for RPGs are just silly long).  So yes, I've decided that "Dear Esther" is something I can with good conscience recommend to the Steam community.  It may seem niche at first, but it truly is made for a wide audience by design.Edit:  Repaired a few skipped words.  Added a sentence to the second-to-last paragraph for clarity's sake.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												I love these kind of games. Dear Esther is an interactive poetry.A man lost within his own world, represented as an abandoned island. As he walks, he studies the traces of his own past, in search for hope. All you do in this game is walking and listening to the narrator. But if you let yourself be taken by the narrative, the experience can be amazing. This game is really special to me, because it helped me think about my own situation of loss and confusion.The character starts walking on a familiar place, then he finds signs of a something terrible, that left marks on him. He is compelled to walk to another place. On the way, it seems to recite a letter to a woman. He also finds symbols of chemical elements and mysterious phrases.There are deep emotional scenes that makes you think: Is suffering necessary to find peace?Dear Esther is an emotional game, it requires patience. Do not expect any challenge. The challenge is to pay attention to details and assemble your own experience from the elements that are given. How much time do you decide to spend in a certain place, looking for a particular sign? What are you looking for? These elements will form the final narrative. So it all depends on you, really.Dear Esther is like a mirror. What do you see? I see a man going in and out of the cave, finding hope amid the rubble of his own life. So it was a worthwhile experience for me. It will not be for everyone. But that's the difference between a work of art and an entertainment product.Positive points* Amazing deep emotional moments.* Incredible graphics and sounds.Negative points* There is no challenge, it can't be played as a conventional game.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game has been sitting in my library for well over a year and today, for some reason or another, I finally decided to sit down and play it. I was very glad that I did. Dear Esther is a short, but extremely well done experience perhaps best compared to a vaguely written, but atmospheric short story. The visuals have retained all of their original beauty and the voice acting tells the story quite well. The pacing and pathing through the environment allowed me to ponder each portion of the story and the environment always made sense with what was happening or what had happened. I enjoyed the ending as well which if you are like me, may cause you to check the internet to make sure that your copy of the game isn't broken. Don't worry. It isn't. The ending is intentional and a smart change to the standard formula. Completely worth the 1 to 1.5 hour playtime and well done enough to deserve your money.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												One of a kind game. Or, "game", rather - it's a story, really. For those of you who seek a game experience, you will likely end up disappointed; the rest of you, you are in for an experience like no other.It's been quite some time since I first played this game, and over the years, I've found myself repeatedly returning to it and, more importantly, its narration.I'll try to refrain from spoilers and just throw it out like this: once you're through, extract the audio files and try to arrange them in order. I believe you have little chance of appreciating the full beauty of this...thing...without doing so.And, once you think you've got THAT figured out, look up the authors' notes for translators, where they make a point of explaining their intentions and thoughts behind each and every line.Once you've done that - well, you're welcome!

Posted: December 2, 2013
												Dear Esther is interesting. It's not a game though. You simply walk through the place, looking at the pretty scenery and strange objects whilst listening to a story you have no context for. I've been told that the narration is randomized, so you might hear a different story on subsequent playthroughs.I suppose you can get really into it, trying to look for all the little details that might hint at clues to some big mystery, but I just didn't care all that much.This game can be worth it if you pick it up for very cheap, but not full price. It is definitely worth pulling up a YouTube video and checking out Dear Esther's beauty.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Certainly atmospheric and relatively pretty, this was an interesting title. The way the story is presented is a nice break from the linear chronology of games attempting something similar, and there are a few secrets to be found on the island which add a little flavour to the story and gives you the means to some personal interpretation. However, the map itself is disappointingly linear and could be greatly enhanced by more secrets and accessories to the story. I gave this a couple of playthroughs to discover whether the remixed chronology of the narrative actually change the story, but unfortunately my experience was essentially the same. Points given for visuals and storytelling, points retracted for lack of creativity and the overall feeling of incompleteness. [4/10]

												I recommend this game with big reservations.  It's interesting to play once for the experience, and the cave section is simply beautiful.  However, after all of the praise I heard about it, I was expecting an amazing story and it left me rather underwhelmed.  The walking speed is extremely slow, so rather than replay it to get the alternate dialogue, I simply read the full dialogue blurbs online after I completed it to make sure I read all of them.  The story wasn't bad, but I thought there would be more to it, and the alternate dialogue comments didn't add as much as I thought they would.  I might have felt differently if I had played the game when it came out, but I've played some more recent "walking simulators" first which had much more detailed stories so that raised my expectations.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2013
												Dear Esther in one word: fascinating. It's a fascinating little gaming experiment that just scratches the surface of what I feel could be the most perfect form of storytelling since books. Legit. It really does feel like you're playing through a novel, albeit a very short one, which is its only flaw; it's waaay too short. Despite that, if you enjoyed the design and overall feel of Amnesia, but not the constant fear of death, then this is right up your alley. It's also one of the most visually stunning games I've ever played, even now with games out that factually have better graphics than this, I still think this looks better simply for its incredible visual (and also audio) design. But should you buy it for the full $10? No, unless you're a huge poetry, art, and video game enthusiast. Should you buy it on sale for $2.49? Maybe, I did and I think it was worth it, but (if you know me in person) I'd rather just have you play it on my laptop.

This made me not want to explore, because it also added several minutes of painfully slow, unnarrated walking to return back to the fork.The story also seemed oddly predictable to me; it was just presented nicely with meandering, obtuse metaphors that just obfuscated the inevitable outcome.Finally, it felt unfinished. content:
Posted: March 18
												What can be said about Dear Esther that hasn't already? The game is wonderfully atmospheric, featuring a nonlinear story that's engrossing as hell. The narration is spot on, with the narrator's posh British accent slowly becoming more and more deranged and frantic. The island itself is wonderfully detailed and gorgeous, despite the limited graphical power it was built from. It seems to be trendy as of late to hate this kind of game, but Dear Esther engages on ever level, and is an honest cornerstone in gaming history.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2012
												Dear Esther isn't so much a conventional video game as it is an emotional and aesthetic journey through the limbo of ones mind. In the vein of walking simulator type experiences, Dear Esther keeps you strictly confined to a set path; without the ability to jump, interact with items, and so forth. The visuals are absolutely stunning, the narration absorbing, and the hauntingly beautiful score spectacular. Dear Esther's story unfolds within the protagonists mind, which after a life altering event is left reeling in limbo. The narrative is the progressive element to the story, with the terrain (visuals), reacting and representing concepts accordingly. Dear Esther is a truly beautiful and emotional experience, and although incredibly short, praise must be given to it's clearly very passionate developers.

I admit I was unimpressed with the dead-end meandering that I ran into during my first short shot at it, but once I put some thought into it, I was enthralled. As the story unfolds in its uniquely quiet, subtle, and shy way, and as the lush (and, at times, surreal) landscape reveals itself, you will not be capable of finding reason or ability to stop until you've reached the end. It's almost a boon that it will only take as long as a couple of hours to play; otherwise, you might just have to call off work, family life, and everything else until you've finished.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												As you will likely have read elsewhere, Dear Esther really stretches the notion of what is traditionally called "a game." This is a very good thing. This work is a real boon to the argument that video games can and should be considered a form of art. It is anything but pedestrian, and that is what makes it so special and so well loved.Dear Esther is visually astounding; journey deep into the island's caves and you will be utterly in awe of the beauty you find. The music is also noteworthy, always appropriate in intensity for the situation, and never overwhelming it. The semi-randomised narration contributes significantly to the player's emotional state while traversing the island: his rantings, musings, rage, and despair all help lend colour to the landscape, and keep the player firmly rooted in the world before them.Whether you would define Dear Esther as a game or not, it is without a doubt an experience you will not regret.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I got this game because I had heard complaints that it was more of an interactive novel than a game. That kind of thing is right up my alley - it's the story I'm interested in. I had also seen some of the beautiful screen shots, and was eager to explore this little world.I was disappointed by both the story and the exploration. The world is, indeed, beautiful, and there are details like crushed cigarette packages on the ground and flowers waving in the breeze. The problem is that there isn't much more to it than what you can see in the trailer. After you've had a good look at the shack by the lighthouse and its surroundings, there's nothing new to see until you get to the caves. The caves are gorgeous, but again, once you've seen the first one, they all look more or less the same. And there is no real exploration. You really are just playing a story, and the railroad tracks are firmly installed. Now and then it might appear that you have a choice to make, but you don't. There's always only one way you can go - split paths always quickly meet back up again.The narrative is very poetic, often beautiful, sometimes touching. But there just isn't very much of it. The game description claims the audio, visuals, and "events" (not sure what events they refer to) are randomly generated, but I played through twice and they didn't seem to be. There was some slight variation in the order that you hear the various fragments of text, but not enough that I'd call it "random." Once you've played it through once, which takes about an hour, maybe 90 minutes if you really take your time and poke around a lot, there's not much of any reason to play through again. It seems meant to convey a feeling about a singular event more than to tell an actual story, and that only really works the first time through. Once you understand what's happening, it loses most of its emotional effect. I suppose if you have some personal connection to the event in question, it might be more significant, but I think most people will find it a bit too distant to have a lasting effect.Overall, the game is not *bad*, it's just lacking. If you want to spend an hour or so wandering through an eerie environment, listening to poetic voiceovers, then it's just fine. But don't expect any more than that, because that's all there is, really.If you can get the game at a big discount, or as a gift from someone, then it might be worth a play through. The price tag of 7 euros, however, seems awfully high for such a small amount of content.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Dear Esther is the most beautiful game I've seen use the source engine and has done immersion better than any game I have played before it. Although that may be it only lasting all of 40 minutes from start to finish. This isn’t a bad thing as the game does so much in its short time with the colors and amount of detail in each of the four sections throughout the island of Dear Esther giving this sense of wonder and mystery that is well accompanied by the sound design and haunting music all going towards creating this immersive and serene experience.  Its like that moment you have when you're just sitting there looking at or listening to the ocean, a thunder storm or whatever you find relaxing and it just recreates that moment of you have of peace but for an extended period of time, as a “Walking simulator” on this artful island with a story that is, well, forgettable compared to the rest of the game. It doesn’t detract from the experience it supposed to keep it moving forward but for me it was my interest in the island and what was waiting in the next few steps. The presentation of the games graphics and sound design is what made it for me but the story was just an afterthought and I find myself thinking more of the wonderful architecture to Dear Esther rather than the ending or the bits of narration leading up to it.

content:
Posted: February 9
												Another old play, late review piece of mine, for which I am really ashamed of, because Dear Esther deserves all the praise it can get.First and foremost: Dear Esther is not a game in a traditional sense, but rather an experiment on interactive storytelling. If we go out from Chris Crawford's (the mind behind the research on interactive storytelling), however, Dear Esther can't be even accounted that - it is more like an audiobook, where you are given the opportunity to look around and "read" the story in your own pace and the chapters in whatever order you wish, depending on which places you visit first. "Walking simulator" is a fitting cathegory, if you need to put it somewhere.*You take the role of a lonely, nameless male protagonist while re-visiting the island he used to live on, and which is now abandoned. While exploring the - otherwise beautifuflly depicted - island, you listen to his thoughts, telling you the story of what this place once was and what it means to him. As said, depending on where you go first, some "chapters" may come sooner or later, but overall, it is a complete story with a sudden - albeit somewhat expected - twist at the end. Dear Esther has beautiful graphics and captivating atmoshpere, the scenery is absolutely astonishing sometimes. I remember spending extra time just drinking some parts in, like the caves or the little path among the cliffs, with small flowers - in a sense, it is really romantic, actually. The music is soothing and somewhat chilling sometimes. I like to listen to it to this day - it still gives me goosebumps. It was one part for which the game won an award, after all.Dear Esther is not a long experience, so I highly recommend it to anyone who is short on time, but needs a little relaxation and stretching your senses beyond your worldy woes, be it studies or work.*Pardon my note on interactive storytelling, this is what I wrote my bachelor thesis about, and I included the game in it as an example of what an interactive story could be.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Dear Esther opens with the beginnings of a letter. As the game's protagonist sets foot onto a deserted island, he starts the game's morose, floridly allegorical narrative with the titular words, "Dear Esther". This letter written to Esther contains a rich story whose open-to-interpretation-type narrative makes multiple playthroughs of Dear Esther equally lurid and enlightening, despite the game's somewhat tedious gameplay elements. When paired with Dear Esther's ethereal environment, this narrative creates a deeply mournful and intriguing walking simulator.The player's journey up the island begins in the day time, beneath ominously gathered clouds and amid rolling hills of withered plantlife. The atmosphere of Dear Esther is filled with tragic elements that add to the story's themes of suffering and grief. During the first half of the journey, the player will pass by grounded ships and abandoned cottages. As the game continues on, the day will grow darker and soon you're plunged into the fantastical darkness of a cave that is illuminated by the rising moon and studded with chemically inspired, glow-in-the-dark paintings and lines of scripture. The environment of Dear Esther grows stormier and more otherworldly as it approaches the climax of the game.The astounding scenery of Dear Esther is paired with frequent pieces of narration from the story's main character. The character's letter to Esther is one filled with metaphors that will depict incredibly abstract images while instilling terrifically tangible emotions in the player. The style of the letter swings between a solemn sadness and a bitter rage, and often the contents of the letter are vague and disjointed—almost as if there are multiple letters and the player is only getting pieces of each one. Each sections of the letter unveils another piece of the story behind your character's climb to the beacon, while leaving enough room for you to speculate about some of the game's more ambiguous plot points.Completing more playthroughs of Dear Esther reveals more pieces of the game's shadowy plot; each piece of dialogue the player receives is one of many potential speeches delivered by a supurb voice actor. Untangling the mystery of Dear Esther's story is a slow and thoughtful journey that, with a little bit of patience, could leave you thinking about this game in moments when you least expect it. Dear Esther's literature quality writing and thought-provoking style of gameplay earns it a steady recommendation from me.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I first heard about Dear Esther in late 2011 while browsing the steam "Coming Soon" section. The music and poetic narrative of the trailer immediately caught my attention. The description of the game also spoke about "random" elements which greatly intrigued me. However closer to release I became less and less interested. I can't exactly remember why this was, maybe another game occupied my thoughts or I wasn't ready to pay the £6.99 for a game that took about 60 minutes to finish. Having only just played and completed Dear Esther for the first time it's a shame I lost interest and didn't purchase when it came out in February 2012.I won't get into the argument about whether Dear Esther is a game or not, I want to leave that to angry people on the internet. I will simply talk about what I thought.Five minutes in, the poetic narrative brimming with metaphors (and numerous other poetical devices) tells me I shouldn't follow the narrative too closely. For if I were to try and understand every word I would only get confused and muddled. Each paragraph of narration is somewhat like a standalone poem and only with all of them put together can you actually patch a story together. This works nicely as you can still enjoy the narrative as standalone pieces if you don't understand or miss the previous paragraph.That said I'm pretty sure the story of Dear Esther is purposely vague and confusing, designed partly for the sake of speculation and discussion. For some this could be frustrating as you aren't really supposed to understand anything clearly in the first few play-throughs. That doesn't mean you don't get anything out of the first play-through, but Dear Esther is definitely better suited to those very fond of analyzing the deeper meaning of literature and poems. After going through Dear Esther twice many aspects of the story still remain confusing but that's why I like it. There is a great element of mystery about the island, some details of which I will never understand. I adore that, but like I said earlier, others will find the lack of detail annoying.While there may be a lack of detail in the story, it would be a crime to say the same for the look of Dear Esther. The texture quality is disappointingly low but like a painting, standing back and looking at everything at once is breathtaking. The environment feels eerily natural, there were times I could swear I wasn't looking at a computer screen. The level design is clever too, it gives the illusion of wide open spaces and many possibilities while in reality being very linear. Not to mention the final area sent shivers down my spine continuously for longer than I've ever experienced.Definitely not for everyone, but well worth a try if you're interested.I give Dear Esther a "Looks pretty damn good and brought a tear to my eye, out of 10".Originally written for my blog over at: http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/02/my-thunks-dear-esther.html

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Dear Esther opens with the beginnings of a letter. As the game's protagonist sets foot onto a deserted island, he starts the game's morose, floridly allegorical narrative with the titular words, "Dear Esther". This letter written to Esther contains a rich story whose open-to-interpretation-type narrative makes multiple playthroughs of Dear Esther equally lurid and enlightening, despite the game's somewhat tedious gameplay elements. When paired with Dear Esther's ethereal environment, this narrative creates a deeply mournful and intriguing walking simulator.The player's journey up the island begins in the day time, beneath ominously gathered clouds and amid rolling hills of withered plantlife. The atmosphere of Dear Esther is filled with tragic elements that add to the story's themes of suffering and grief. During the first half of the journey, the player will pass by grounded ships and abandoned cottages. As the game continues on, the day will grow darker and soon you're plunged into the fantastical darkness of a cave that is illuminated by the rising moon and studded with chemically inspired, glow-in-the-dark paintings and lines of scripture. The environment of Dear Esther grows stormier and more otherworldly as it approaches the climax of the game.The astounding scenery of Dear Esther is paired with frequent pieces of narration from the story's main character. The character's letter to Esther is one filled with metaphors that will depict incredibly abstract images while instilling terrifically tangible emotions in the player. The style of the letter swings between a solemn sadness and a bitter rage, and often the contents of the letter are vague and disjointed—almost as if there are multiple letters and the player is only getting pieces of each one. Each sections of the letter unveils another piece of the story behind your character's climb to the beacon, while leaving enough room for you to speculate about some of the game's more ambiguous plot points.Completing more playthroughs of Dear Esther reveals more pieces of the game's shadowy plot; each piece of dialogue the player receives is one of many potential speeches delivered by a supurb voice actor. Untangling the mystery of Dear Esther's story is a slow and thoughtful journey that, with a little bit of patience, could leave you thinking about this game in moments when you least expect it. Dear Esther's literature quality writing and thought-provoking style of gameplay earns it a steady recommendation from me.

Posted: January 17, 2013
												How do I even begin to describe Dear Esther?Well I'd say that it is interactive story telling, but that would be a lie because there is absolutely no interaction at all. For that matter I don't even think it is technically a story either, as it was only a series of letters read aloud in the third person not really containing any cohesive theme. I'd be hard pressed to even call it a video game as it contains not a single gameplay mechanic other than simply walking very slowly on an extremely linear path. Now all that being said I really enjoyed every minute of the experience, because that is all that it was, just a memorable audio/video experience.This is simply a stunning piece of motion artwork set to an amazing soudtrack. It was immersive, inflective and above all absolutely gorgeous. If you are looking for an exciting game keep looking. If you have ever wondered if video games should be considered as an independant art form, BUY THIS GAME.For what you get I wouldn't pay more than 5$ but it will be a money well spent if you do.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												Dear Esther is a beautifully poignant game, telling the story of a man's guilt with excellently written semi-random dialogue. Each playthrough gives you a unique set of clues hidden within the island, or spoken by the narrator. You piece together your own interpretation. The flawless environmentals and attention to detail, coupled with music that leaves you feeling melancholic, gives this game a slightly eerie atmosphere. You are not alone in this island. If you play this game expecting it to conform to what the majority would think a "game" is, then you will be sorely disappointed. Those who appreciate the arts would enjoy this game beyond negative criticism that it's "boring". It's excellently made, and I very much enjoyed the story. It's like plunging yourself into someone else's dream.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I only got 2.4 hours out of this according to Steam, and that was with a lot of backtracking (read more about why below, which might be considered a spoiler*) and stopping every few minutes to argue with racists on Twitter. Comparing with and contrasting against Gone Home, which I liked a lot, there's way less to do here. No interactivity (at all), a very unemotional delivery from the narrator, and just... not much to do. I get the point of walking simulators, but compared to GH, this is severely lacking. Even at £6.99 it feels steep.It's very pretty, no doubt, but that's not enough to save it. There are far better walking simulators (Gone Home) and far better ways to throw small amounts of money at smaller studios (Inside, Ori).*The game has a seemingly-deliberate habit of presenting multiple potential paths at several points, which if you're anything like me and want to make sure you've seen *everything* means you'll head off down one, get far enough that you believe that's the way you're supposed to go, then backtrack to the junction and explore the other route(s) first. All at an incredibly slow pace. It does this far too many times to be anything other than a deliberate attempt at lengthening playtime.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2012
												I played and completed "Dear Esther" within in 1.5 hours. The game tells a confused and chilling story amidst the Hebridean Isles. The graphics are amazing and beautiful, the soundtrack is really quite good too. The story, however, for the price of £6.99, falls short.The game has little to no replayability. I'm told by my friend Zoey that you can replay the game to unlock additional "narratives", but this, at best, is flavour. By the end of the game you "get" the story. I rather enjoyed it. However, I feel that if I had paid full price (and not picked it up in the Summer Sale for £1.75) I would be greatly disappointed.Don't go into this "game" expecting a game. It's more like an interactive novel. It wont provide you with action and guns and girls, but it will provide you with a unique little story, told in a desolate and beautiful landscape. Worth checking out; if it's on sale.-Nilesy

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												A pretty stroll around an island, intersected at times with semi-random narration vaguely fleshing out your situation (which may change slightly each playthrough).It is decisively not funny. When you get down to the story, it's rather angsty if not outright depressive. Art at its finest, eh?I'm somewhat on the fence with this title. In real life I certainly enjoy solitary walks in an unfamiliar area, especially if it's nature oriented rather than industrialized, surrendering to my thoughts. And in video games I often enjoy dropping main storyline to just mess around and explore, if given game lends itself to it at all. But there's always a choice in the matter and other things to do as well along the way, not just sightseeing and meditating.Whereas Dear Esther is pretty much only the latter. A virtual piece of art, painting/installation with smidgens of verbal narrative, but with zero interaction other than just walking around, pressing forward to push story a bit, see more, and get mind screwed. Even flashlight turns on automatically. It's painting in the medium of video games, but itself is not really a video game at all.In the end I'd still recommend it, just to experience something different, but if you're not feeling particularly artsy you likely aren't going to enjoy it on any level. However, I am certainly looking forward to reliving it once VR becomes a thing, as this title lends itself perfectly to the whole notion. Really nice scenery porn.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												A game taking place on a deserted, dismal Hebridean island, housing a peculiar, unobtrusive wandering, promptly sounds like the concept of an experiment. Given the complete absence of interaction between the player and the game, as the nameless player's protagonist without visual identification strolls through the mist, while the release of random sound recordings of letters read out loud to a woman named Esther, it is indeed in fact an experiment. The identity of the woman is unclear, as is the relationship between the two of you; however, as you progress through the windblown beaches, the moors, the deep caves as well as the lighthouse - towards the peak of the island - detached diary notes depict the outlines of a tragic accident, and a ghostly tale appears.The story of Dear Esther is utterly obscure and abstract. Cryptic biblical quotation is occasionally displayed on the surroundings, and out of the sound recordings the history of the island surface, along with the hints of a freeway, the disclosure of a fatal car crash, and three personalities; a shepherd with syphilis, an explorer whose infected wounds made him mad, and a broken man with guilt involving the mentioned car accident. However, the dividing line between them becomes blurred, and depending on how you interpret the course of the events, they may ultimately not be three different individuals.Considering the game (or not-game) strongly emphasizes the suggestive approach, excluding any specific details and concrete clues, I hardly see it as a puzzle to be pieced together. Through the looking glass, I believe Dear Esther is neither a search for an answer, nor even for a meaning, but an experiment with the senses and emotions. It is a lonely, guilt-stricken journey through morbidly beautiful emptiness; an emotive smorgasbord of sight, sound, implication and metaphor, aimed to generate a feeling of purposeful despair. The world is quiet, uneventful and subdued, the atmosphere isolated and melancholic, and one chapter in particular - namely the cave - might be the most strikingly beautiful achievement ever presented on a monitor.The only interaction Dear Esther provides is to look at it, to experience it. To react to what my own mind evokes in response by the emotional implications and occurring subtlety, not to on-screen prompts or physical reflexes. It is a lonely, slow 90-minute walk of purgatory dealing with sorrow, loss, shame, faith and sickness, but also love, hope and atonement. One look at the washed-out hillside, the empty and devastated houses, the constant twinkle of a distant radio mast, and the harrowingly lack of any other life whatsoever (except an eerie silhouette along the horizon and the occasional bird) tells me, however, almost all I need to know; the night slowly falls, and it falls with a sinister reason. The approaching call to that perceptible, mystery mast is inevitable.It is a simulator of subconscious introspection that pretty much can be associated with walking along an empty road along the coast at night and where your mind went at that time. But at the end of the day, Dear Esther doesn't need to tell me anything, nor does it really attempt to, despite the minimalistic events that is self-evident enough through implication alone; it only needs to make me feel something, and indeed it does. The meaning I create for myself, both early on and during the resolution, is more than that could ever be - yet it is nothing concrete or even describable. The devoid of clarity is strangely enough satisfying.Robert Briscoe's uncompromising game design combined with the dark, sensitive tones of composer Jessica Curry's rewritten soundtrack of haunting strings and piano, the island's quiet ambience and underlying emotional depth has the qualifications to profundly affecting the player. Game scientist and lecturer Dan Pinchbeck, who originally created the game back in 2008, has proved that violence and puzzles and logic are not necessarily required. The narrative alone can be just as essential.8.5 / 10

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												When I first bought this game I assumed I was paying $1 for a forgettable horror survival game. Turns out I was very wrong but I was by no means disappointed, at least not when I finished the story. I was upset at first when I discovered what I had bought but I decided to give it a chance all the same. It took me a while to warm up to it but after I did it became one of the top 5 most memorable of my 133 Steam purchases. The soundtrack is so soothing and amazing, it was so good I put it on my iPhone. Combine the music with the amazing storyline and beautiful art style and you have a true masterpiece. I recommend this game to every one of my friends because I truly think anyone can enjoy Dear Esther. Don't think of it as playing a game, think of it as walking through a dream while awake. At least that's what it felt like for me.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Dear Reader,I’m writing to you today for I wonder at the thoughts you would think, and the words you would utter, if you could see what I have seen. Hear what I have heard. Experience what I have experienced. Would your thoughts and opinions mirror mine as Narcisuss’s visage was reflected back to him from the water of a pool?Or will my thoughts be as a cherry blossom falling to the ground? Seen but lost among the countless number of facsimiles. Remembered for a second, but forgotten and swept away for all eternity.I wonder…Dear Esther is an interesting experiment. It is a game devoid of action, violence, sex, and interaction of any kind. You are on a deserted island with a disembodied voice for company as you explore. No more and no less. Or so it would seem.As I wandered over the island, the voice read excerpts from a letter to a woman named Esther. Over time, I began to wonder about Esther, the voice, and two men named Donnelly and Jakobson. All are mentioned frequently throughout the game yet there is much that requires explanation.The game uses Valve’s Source engine, which continues to hold up well despite its age. The island might be devoid of life but the views are lovely if somewhat grim. As I made my way to a lighthouse I observed rolling hills of grass, walked along a beach, spotted derelict ships beached upon the shore, and saw other sights. There is a section of the game where I found myself in a cave that took my breath away. Stalactites, stalagmites, glowing objects, gems, waterfalls; this area has easily become one of my most memorable locations for a video game.To read the rest of my review visit Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-dear-esther/

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Dear Esther 

			Views: 2,207		

			A review of Dear Esther by Senior Reviewer Trent Dear Esther is available on Steam for $9.99 Be sure to subscribe and comment! You can follow us on Twitter at https://twitter.com/analogreviews		

Opening with your in front of the Lighthouse with your character delivering a soliloquy, after which you are left to explore your surroundings. There are no objective markers, no text prompts, no intrusive and hideous HUD to obscure your view of the world. Exploring the nooks and crannies of the surrounding area occasionally prompts random statements from your character. In these letters are few of the Island's former inhabitants are referenced repeatedly. There are also several themes that emerge from these excerpts and astute players will notice those themes reflected in the environment. A glowing red beacon on top of a radio tower is almost always present and, like a moth to a flame, is compels you to seek it out. Paths split and merge around the island and it's easy to find your way forward. This set up wouldn't be engrossing for very long if it wasn't for the visuals. Dear Ester benefits from an excellent graphical presentation and art direction. Textures are rich, dust picks up, leaves blow around, the foliage is dense, and landmarks dot an otherwise open landscape. Warm candle glow contrasts with cool night skies and somehow Dear Esther manages to make caves, often the most drab environments found in games, rather breath taking. Rock walls are scrawled on with luminescent goo, and the rocks form awesome structures with stalactites and stalagmites jutting from the bedrock forming nefarious teeth. Rivers flow through the cave's interior terminating in grand waterfalls. It is perhaps here that the game's setting can be most clearly seen as a metaphor. To deride Dear Esther for it's lack of actual gameplay is to remain oblivious to it's excellent adaptation of literary devices to tell a simple interactive story. It's a story that places you not just in the shoes of the protagonist but in his mind and soul. Its an introspective tale which is remarkably rare for a video game. To discuss any more of the plot would undermine the experience and the mystery. Allegory, allusions and metaphors are all present. Dear Esther explores new territory for narrative in an interactive media. With it's lack of a defined structure and a devilish desire not to be too explicit with its plot points Dear Esther's yarn will displease some an accusations of pretension will likely ensue.   There have been games in the past with exquisite narratives and there have been games that have extraordinary gameplay and mechanics. The biggest challenge is getting these two aspects of a game to work together harmoniously—to have game mechanics that fit into narrative themes. Mechanics and gameplay elements that reflect the subtext of the narrative itself. In many games story and gameplay exist in almost separate bubbles. Actual narrative often bookends levels and takes a backseat while the player controls their character. It's an antiquated formula that only a handful of games seem to have shaken. The way The Chinese Room engages the player without traditional mechanics is through simple exploration. By making discoveries in the world you are treated to a bit of exposition. Symbols, diagrams, and writings can be found in the world to reflect elements of the exposition. A book or film could never deliver the level of immersion that Dear Esther offers. The experience only works because the player can choose to see or not to see things in the environment. The ability for the player to set the pace of the story and be given the opportunity to discover the details makes Dear Esther work.Dear Esther has had a remarkable journey from Half Life 2 mod to independent release. It's an exercise in adapting literary conventions to an interactive experience and it's an exercise worth taking part in. The excellent soundtrack and visuals hold your attention while the plot takes shape. The conclusions will stick with you long after the hour and a half it takes to see it through and it's likely that you will want to revisit Dear Esther to soak in it's finer points.

												It's pretentious as hell and I completed it an hour, taking my time along the way. Yet, the ride was enthralling and the feeling I got in the end was rather unique and hard to explain. number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Ever noticed how, very occasionally, you will play a game, listen to a piece of music, watch a movie or whatever, and you know, as soon as you've finished that it will stay with you for a long time?I'm getting that right now.I've just played through Dear Esther twice and I find it to be time and money VERY well spent.This is not a game in the conventional sense.If your fix is usually space marines shooting aliens, this might not be for you. It is very unorthodox.It has no enemies, no other characters, no items, no object interaction at all. All you do is walk and explore as the back story unfolds through often dreamy monologues.But therein lies its strength. It really does try something different, and it pays off.It really is beautiful. It's a couple of years old now, but if you crank the settings up to full it really shines. This is due in large part to the actual art direction and creation of the island setting. It looks very natural with no copy and paste going on and it all takes place in dusk or night time so it looks moody and washed out.Seriously, take time to look around at the scenery.The sound is completely perfect and enhances the experience no-end.The musical score is haunting and perfectly timed to coincide with epic scenery or other happenings. The narrator (the only voice in the 'game') does an excellent job as well.It's a strange thing that a game in which you do so little can have such an impact, but that really is the case for me.This game is as beautiful/haunting/mysterious as it is unorthodox.It won't be for everyone, but if you are open to something different, put those headphones on, turn out the lights and go for a walk :-)

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												It's the story of a ship wrecked man who finds the belongings and writings of another ship wrecked man... though what you will see may surprise you. The trails and splatterings of his or your own hand lead you through memories and emotions from a tragedy relived in the lonliest of places. Do you know this man whose footsteps you follow? Have you been here before? Do the things you find in dark corners hold meaning to you? Are the stories you're told true? What will you say when you find this man at the end of the line, or will you find nothing at all?

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Dear Esther is a really wonderful experience. I wouldn't call it a game, per se, since it involves no problem solving and very little active user interaction. Really it's a unique use of interactive media as a storytelling device. You walk through the setting to trigger narration and to progress between chapters. The graphics are gorgeous, the atmosphere is exceedingly lonely and evocative, the music is good, the writing and narration wonderful... It adds up to a beautiful, tragic, and slightly surreal exploration of grief that is worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, but it just fell short of my expectation.  I was hoping that it would more of an emotional type of game, but I just didn't feel anything there.  I personally thought that I'm more of a sensitive type of person, that I can be emotional if I let myself to be.  Perhaps my heart was made of stone the day I played this game(or maybe I should have played the game with lights off,  and with some wine and scented candles, then maybe...just maybe...I might like this game.)I can tell that the developer focused all the effort in the writing/narration, game environment and the presentation of the game.  I admit that the writing of it is beautiful, combined with as beautiful game environment. However, I felt that the game is trying too hard to be poetic or artistic.  And in my humble opinion, I think it was a bit too pretentious.  In fact, I don't think I have play any other game that actually made me feel this way.One of the other things that I didn't like about this game is that there is no instant or manual save option. I understand that this type of game is best to be played in one sitting, but it is still nice to have that option.  The first time I played this game, I played about 20 minutes. I got to a different area in the game, it was after the loading screen; and I had to stop playing the game, thought that it had auto-save. But it didn't auto-save, so I had to play the game from the beginning again.  So the next and last time I played this game, I had this constant unpleasant feeling behind the back of my mind, wondering when this game is going to end, and hoping that it would end sooner; because I sure don't feel like starting the game all over again.There are only a few things that I like about this game.  I like the atmosphere of the game; I enjoyed walking around the seaside, cave...etc.  Some people complained about the walking speed being too slow, but I thought that the speed is just fine for me. I also like the soundtrack, suits the game very well.  For a first person POV game, it was a good thing that they  actually added controller support, that's another minor thing that I appreciate.All I can say is that this game is still a good enough experience for me.  So, l won't say that I want that couple hours of my life back; but overall, I won't say that I recommend this to everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												Dear Esther: I tried to see you, at the end. The island is capricious; as like a siren, she lures hermits to seek the inaccessible--trapping them in waters that ignore the swim key. I have spent hours drowning in search of you. I am drowning in you, still.Dear Esther: At last, night has fallen, and I have caught sight of the moon. I shall follow its light, that it may lead me to our reunion, and to my end.Dear Esther: I have fallen between a ramp and two rocks. Esther, do you remember that time I got kidney stones? Or how I never learned how to climb rocks or jump over things as a boy? I am pinned. Oh, to be ruined by so trifling an obstacle.I'm afraid this is it. I was to become an aerial for you, but the island's designs wouldn't allow it. Esther...goodbye.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												While this is more of an interactive story than a game, it is well worth "playing", if only for the amazing scenery and breathtaking soundtrack.  The story is intriguing.  It isn't perfectly elucidated but leaves the interpretation to you.  As you discover notes, locations, and clues, you will learn more of the story bit by bit and in a different order depending on how you explore the island.  This changes how you may interpret what's going on.  It's fairly short and will only take a matter of a few hours depending on how much you stop to gawk at the landscape.  It's a poignant piece of art masquerading as a game and my only regret is how long I waited to get it.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												There are no bad guys to kill, obstacles to dodge or jump scares. The only button aside from movement is "zoom in". If that's a deal-breaker, this isn't for you.I got completely lost in the atmosphere of this game. After playing it for the first time, I immediately played it two more times back to back. Each time there were different voice-overs and changes to the environment of varied significance.The environment is immersive and expresses the mood throughout. As for "gameplay", the story itself is the game. You have to interpret and piece it together, and the game won't walk you through it or tell you if you've won. Maybe it's not a "game", but whatever it is, I wish there were more.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Had been intrigued with this "game" for some time. Having played and liked Gone Home, I thought it might be a similar kind of atmospheric game. But read some reviews where people called it boring and pointless. I'm into this kind of artsy stuff but to a certain limit only! At the point when art starts to become self-indulgent I get put off, be it films, books or games. So basically, was on the fence about buying it and finally couldn't resist picking it up for very cheap as part of a Humble Bundle. Dear Esther had been sitting in my library for a while now. I had a few hours to kill today so finally decided to check it out. First 10-15 mins, I was like "Uhh...this is going to be a little boring. Where do I have to go? There are so many paths and routes. Is there any marker or any maps to show me the way? Do I just stare at the vast ocean and the foliage throughout the game? This is confusing!" I have to admit that initially I was beginning to see what all those bad reviews by gamers meant about it being just a walking simulator. Even so, an hour later I found myself still playing and completely in awe of the game's atmosphere especially the gorgeous cave section. And the music...oh god, the music is mindblowing! I think its the music that really sets the mood for this game. In fact, its not really a game in my opinion...its a journey...a piece of interactive art. If you go in expecting to play a game...you will hate it! But if you let yourself be taken in by the environment its trying to create for you...you will have a mesmerising experience.I simply cant get that hauntingly beautiful soundtrack out of my head. And the part where you fall into the water and see images of a motorway and a couple of cars...that part blew my mind! Everything is just done so well. The detailing, the character building, the lighting, the environments...its pure art!Bottomline, I know many people thought of it as pointless and a waste of time - but I really enjoyed it. I would like to try out some similar stuff and am open to recommendations. The Stanley Parable is next on my list...that demo I played was just fantastic!

												Can't possibly recommend it at this price. It's a 2 hour linear walking simulator through some rather pretty scenery, accompanied by (at best) average prose. It just tells you to shut up, walk, and listen for 2 hours straight while it drones on and attempts to tell the story in the most roundabout way possible to fill in the time it all takes. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Be aware - This is not an action packed thrill ride.  Nor is it a graphical marvel.  It is not a multiplayer extravaganza, nor a brain draining puzzler.What it is - Its a heart wrenching story, written masterfully and with a light touch.I have read review after review, saying that they 'wish they hadn’t wasted their money'.  I wholeheartedly disagree.  While it is not the most graphically advanced of games, it is not about how pretty it looks, or whether it contains that "new fad" that’s going around in the gaming industry.This is a game that crosses many boundaries.It assumes that you have a brain (something that is in short supply these days).  It also assumes that you will figure things out on your own.There are no superfluous controls, there is no need.  This is a story.  When you accept it as such, you get swept away on a tide of emotion.  I think this is the intention of the developers.  Allowing yourself to feel what the writer(s) feel is the whole point.The graphical game is not the 'story', it is the vusual cue that provides a more visceral sensation to the 'story'.If you dont like a good novel, you wont like this game.I personally think it is spectacular.  I recommend this story to anyone who has a heart.  You wont be sorry.Easily a 10 out of 10.

												Dear Esther was an interesting art project and not muxh else. There is no real gameplay to speak of other than walking through the world itself (at a snails pace I might add), waiting to hear nonlinear pieces of the plot. Though there is no reason or incentive to do so as there is nothing to collect or achieve other than hearing other small snipets of the story.  And even that is diminished by fact that the story itself is simply not that engaging or interesting.  Overall, Esther has many interesting components but  ultimately fails to bring them together into a meanful experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Dear Esther breaks so many gaming stereotypes. Your character doesn't grow stronger as the game progresses - the game doesn't even have a levelling system of any kind. It doesn't require lightning reflexes to dodge that impossibly fast saw blade or platform your way across a valley littered with spikes. You don't get to kill anything or destroy stuff - the game has no enemies to speak of. You don't get to construct mega cities or craft up a storm of items. You don't get to roleplay either - there is no customization, no assortment of loot, no impulse to power level or item grind.What then, does Dear Esther let you do? It gives you space to think, provides you with the opportunity to reflect. It encourages you to take a stroll (quite literally) down a path few have travelled, and piques your curiousity with a brilliant unfolding of the plotline by the nameless narrator. Your path is often carefully crafted out for you - I was initially disappointed with the lack of alternate routes, given the wide expanse of the island you find yourself on. But eventually, that was washed away by the excitement that was quite simply "Hey, that's where I want to go, too!" in response to the game's subtle tugging on my sleeve. The score and the accompanying concise commentary complete the audio-visual sensory overload. The grand, vivid surroundings - especially the excellent usage of space and scale - are the perfect juxtaposition to the nagging feeling of loneliness and sense of longing.Very little is explained (the repeated cryptic chemical/electrical scribblings on the walls definitely do you no favours), and probably even less is ever concluded by the time the journey ends, but unlike most adventures, Dear Esther does not seem to be too concerned with finding a solution; it is not rushed into making conclusions or finding meaning. Instead it is very content in simply existing. Some claim Dear Esther to be nothing more than emotional manipulation, and I find that rather unfortunate. As much space as Dear Esther can potentially create, like all content with emotional investment, the return you get out of it depends on the amount you are willing to put in. No two players will get the same experience from playing this, and this is the strength of Dear Esther - a game which allows you to create a journey, an adventure, and meaning for yourself.

												Dear Esther is a game of art and emotion driving exp. The game may not have any goals, other than walking around and figuring out what is going on; but the game takes you on a journey of wonder. The game has simple controls, you either walk using the arrow keys or WASD keys, and the mouse to look around. You can click the mouse button to zoom in on detail but other than that, that is it in controls.There are 4 levels in this game, and each level is a story. Everytime you play the game, more random storylines are told, so the replayability is high. This game could be called a narrative game. It is a great work of art via audio and visuals. Each level is done so beautifully it takes your breathe away. I love just playing the game slowly, listening to the audio and enjoying my time in the world. This game might not be for everyone, because all you do is walk, listen, and enjoy at your own pace, but it is fun and the art talent is very good in this game. It is by far my favorite game.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
"THERE ARE HEADLIGHTS REFLECTED IN THESE RETINAS, TOO LONG IN THE TUNNELS OF MY ISLAND WITHOUT A BOTTOM. THE SEA CREATURES HAVE RISEN TO THE SURFACE, BUT THE GULLS ARE NOT HERE TO CARRY THEM BACK TO THEIR NESTS. I HAVE BECOME FIXED: OPEN AND STARING, AN EYE TURNED ON ITSELF. I HAVE BECOME AN INFECTED LEG, WHOSE TRACKING LINES FORM A PERFECTMAP OF THE JUNCTIONS OF THE M5. I WILL TAKE THE EXIT AT MID-THIGH AND PLUMMET TO MY ESTHER."There's a line between game and product. There's a line between thing and art. Art is just a word and everybody considerate art different. So with this game. It has tossed a line between game and product and also between thing and art. That means somebody will hate this game because of statement like "You can't do anything there". Few months ago I did a complex review at certain website which took around 5 pages and reactions were as I expected - hateful. This game is POLARIZED. That means this game has only high and very low ratings. Or even no ratings at all. Dear Esther is a game, but on the other side it's like book, movie and game in one.We can sum it up in one sentence - You will travel through unbelievable, amazing, awesome and beautiful locations, and listen to one hell of a story of a man who loved the Esther. Bonus Point: IslandRating: N/A

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Quite decent graphics, a confusing but yet captivating story and an amazing soundtrack. This game was really worth the few bucks on Humble-Bundle and I was surprised by the overwhelming atmosphere that this game creates. Especially the place where it takes place is catchy, the developers created such a beautiful island that it feels like you are on the real Hebrides. Though I was amazed by this games depth, I would not recommend this game to everybody: It is not like any other game, its a new concept of entertainment and those who like action and seek adventures wont like this game as much as those who like to try something new and enjoy a good story over action or extreme graphics. Its quite short (I think it was something like 2 hours) but its like reading a good books combined with a journey to the Hebrides (at least thats what I thought after playing it).

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is based on a mod that I have not played, so for the purposes of this review it will not be considered.While it's easy to criticize the gameplay (a word that hardely applies to this game) or the linearity of Dear Esther, this completely ignores the focus of this game, which is story telling and exploring. While the exploration is somewhat limited and definitely pre-determined, the atmosphere and visuals are so well done this hardly matters. During the game, the player finds himself so captivated by the contrasting bleakness and vibrance of the world and it's atmosphere, that he finds his every action and every thought hinged on the next line from the narrator or the next scene, dissolving away the percieved limitations which are so often used to criticize this game. If you are looking to get more out of your game experience, a step above the typical "shoot-kill-earn point" mechanics that are so popular in today's games, I'd recommend Dear Esther. Otherwise your better off with one of the more popular games which stimulate neither the mind nor the imagination.

Open yourself to this game and you'll understand it, but most important, you may understand yourself.I strongly recommend this game for all those who face depression and understand its nature.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This game is very odd. It certainly won't be everyone's cup of tea. I definitely enjoyed it and felt it was quite beautiful.It's a game in which you explore an island and slowly piece together somebody's memories. Whose memories these are, why you're on this island, what things the narrator is actually talking about are not explained outright. It will stick in your head for days after you finish it, but I really like that.It's not stupid, but it does try a bit too hard to be clever. I'd rather that than stupid though. While there are some very helpful ideas online about the story of the game, I'd heavily recommend not reading those until at least a couple of days after you finish the game - I really enjoyed making my own mind up about things. Though it was certainly good to experience another person's take on things, and I was able to incorporate some other things into my experience.So it's not at all a traditional game. There's not really much challenge to it at all. An interactive story would probably be about right. But it's very pretty and very sad, and I found it enjoyable if a little too try-hard. Not for everyone though. If you want a short thinky experience, I would definitely recommend giving this a go.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												 I'm relieved to see Steam add a negative reviews option just so I can bash the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this ♥♥♥♥ing game.  Well, "game." Dear Esther isn't much of a game, it's more like reliving a painful school trip where your legs hurt like♥♥♥♥♥♥ the guide was a boring ♥♥♥♥, the teacher wouldn't stop asking questions and your crush didn't show.  Many people will say this game is beautiful. Many people will say the voice acting and the writing is superb. Many people have incurably bad taste.  While some of the visuals in this game are alright, it's nothing special. There are a lot of indie games that do a far better job of establishing an atmosphere. Hell, if you want to look at pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ you're better off jerking your eyes over a modded TES than this thing.  On to the story and the writing -- it's ♥♥♥♥ing drivel. There's nothing enjoyable in the monotone voice acting, nor in the workaday lines being read. Whatever they tried to accomplish, it failed; quite miserably.  The two monumental issues that plague this game however, are its linearity and the speed of progression. For the most part, you're stuck trudging down the same track like a moron. That wouldn't be so positively mind-blastingly painful if you weren't forced to walk at the same ♥♥♥♥ing speed throughout the entire game. I mean even using the word 'speed' in this paragraph seems wrong, it's like roleplaying a ♥♥♥♥ing slug caught in some lab experiment while your edgy teenage owner is practicing his reciting for the drama course.  Please, kill me. I don't want to risk even having to watch this being played ever again.  Monumental thumbs down.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												If you're expecting an interactive experience, don't play Dear Esther, you will be disappointed. There is no combat, no puzzles, no NPCS, no skill trees, no multiplayer, no buttons, levers, or computers.. not even a door to open.However, if you are interested in hearing a great story and seeing gorgious environments then you will love this game. The game would be best described as visual storytelling. You walk around a quiet and mysterious island. As you walk around you will hear well written and spoken narration of the story as it unfolds the further you explore. These bits of narration often coincide with any landmarks you happen to be near. While sometimes it can be tedious trying to walk around some of the larger areas due to the slow movement speed, for the most part the environments will keep you engaged. These environments are jaw-droppingly beautiful, in particular the caves caused me to walk around saying "whoa" with every new room. To think that they managed to harness this level of beauty out of the Source engine is nothing short of amazing.Overall, the game will only last you about 1 hour for a playthrough, but it's definitely a must to experience at least once.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dear Esther is not a game. It is an interactive experience. It's also quite depressing and - despite some beautiful visuals - quite dull.More of an art experiment, "Dear Esther" has you following in the footsteps of a would-be suicide as he mournfully regrets the loss of his deceased wife. It's neat how the game randomly picks parts of the narrative to play  to you as you wander the moors; no run through will get exactly the same experience. Unfortunately, that narrative is dry and uninteresting. The moors are pretty but there's nothing to do there except marvel at the graphics. And the end is entirely predictable. Frankly, I'd have been better off just looking at the screenshots.
