content:
Posted: February 4
												It was quiet when it ended, I was quiet. I looked back to the beginning of the journey, how uninterested I had started and how mundane it all seemed. Bright colors and a light splatter of words with so low context that I deemed them forgettable. How it changed as I continued, each selection of words put a hook on me. A light hook that went unnoticed, as unnoticed as the lack of freedom I deemed I had. Such a lie, a notion dispelled slowly as visual clues and words finally intertwined in a dark quiet crash. I understood halfway what this journey was, what it represented and what I would depart it with. I let it take me by the hand, surrendering to the journey. It was guided by rails, like street lines silently stating my bounds. It was quiet when it ended, I was quiet. I looked back to the beginning of the journey, how uninterested I had started and how mundane it all seemed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2013
												This is a story. Not a game, not something that will bring you excitement, but more a sad solace. It will kick you and break you until you're little more than a shivering wreck of tears and sobs. And it's amazing. I still can't get over how riveting it was, and is, to play.Now for the game review:The actual "play" of Dear Esther isn't much. You walk at an unusually slow pace around a mostly linear path until the end, with little interaction by you. So, yes, it lacks there. If you want to speed up the gameplay, you can use the normal Source debug commands to quicken your pace. I suggest watching some gameplay videos to see what Dear Esther is like, and if you can stand it.I personally loved the story. Many people, however, can't connect with it. The whole plot revolves, at first glance, around an unnamed author of spoken letters to an "Esther," who was apparently killed by a drunken driver named Paul. The lines between these characters start to blur, and some details are mixed, until an obscure, hard-to-understand message formulates. I won't say more, as I suggest you find out for yourself.You'll need an open, hard-working mind, a high level of patience, and the ability to draw your own conclusions when you take that Hebridean stroll that is Dear Esther.

												Graphics 9/10 - Story 10/10 - Gameplay (N/A) - Controls 8/10 - Overall 9/10Let me start with, yes, I do recommend this game. However, most people who play games these days are not like me, and may feel bored by a game like this. 												More a visual novel than traditional video game, the description of Dear Esther being a "walking simulator" is probably apt.  But I found the (admittedly strange) narrative engrossing, and the pairing of the wonderful soundtrack combined with the excellently created cave sections were well worth the price of admission for me. 												Dear Esther is not a game, in the conventional sense. There is no gameplay, no interactivity, no weapons, no enemies. You walk through it, listen to it, and follow the story through occasional narration. It is a true work of art, both a visual and literary masterpiece, with gorgeous scenery and interesting, if a bit grim and sad story you're left to interpret on your own. It is like playing a book or a poem. It is no game, but it is a beautiful thing.

												I can't generally recommend this game, as unless it's specifically what you're looking for, odds are you won't find it enjoyable. Dear Esther is a first-person perspective visual novel, where you walk through various surroundings while listening to narration. The exploration, such as it is, is where the interactivity comes in, and some of the surrounding visuals are interesting, but ultimately the game seems to fall short of what its initial goals were.Dear Esther is divisive, and is honestly almost worth playing just to see what the controversy is all about, but if you're going to get it, wait for a sale. There's a little less than an hour's worth of gameplay.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2012
												Dear Esther is not a game, in the conventional sense. There is no gameplay, no interactivity, no weapons, no enemies. You walk through it, listen to it, and follow the story through occasional narration. It is a true work of art, both a visual and literary masterpiece, with gorgeous scenery and interesting, if a bit grim and sad story you're left to interpret on your own. It is like playing a book or a poem. It is no game, but it is a beautiful thing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												This game was both simultaneously interesting, enraging, and absolutely baffling. Having spent exactly an hour to get to the end, I'm conflicted as to whether or not I actually enjoyed the experience. Your surroundings become increasingly odd and surreal as you progress through the 'story,' with the tidbits of narrative you trigger forming most--if not all--of the plot involved. These are more or less random as to which you recieve, so how much of the story you actually have at the end, regardless of how thorough you were, can vary in each playthrough.Unfortunately the game provides no way of tracking how many events you've witnessesd/triggered, which is what puts me off from replaying. Unsure as to whether I have half of them, or 1% of them, I don't want to slog through several more hours of walking just to repeat the same (admittedly excellently narrated) blurbs over and over again.By now everyone has heard that it is THE walking simulator, and I'm just echoing that when I say you... just walk. There's limited interaction, and by limited I mean you have the ability to look at things. That's about it. There are some definite 'creep factor' moments in the game, but they're often distant and easy to miss if you aren't looking for them. That said, if you get it cheap or free, or this sounds EXACTLY like the sort of experience you want to have (and it does make you think, which I believe is a good thing, so surrealist fans might flock here) go for it. I wouldn't pay full price for it, however, as neither the gameplay or visual designs provide much that you can't get elsewhere and better.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												I can't generally recommend this game, as unless it's specifically what you're looking for, odds are you won't find it enjoyable. Dear Esther is a first-person perspective visual novel, where you walk through various surroundings while listening to narration. The exploration, such as it is, is where the interactivity comes in, and some of the surrounding visuals are interesting, but ultimately the game seems to fall short of what its initial goals were.Dear Esther is divisive, and is honestly almost worth playing just to see what the controversy is all about, but if you're going to get it, wait for a sale. There's a little less than an hour's worth of gameplay.

												This is a beautiful game that keeps you thinking and wondering till the end, as you explore the island you learn about a story about a couple and their journey together. There is no shooting or puzzles be had, there is nothing that is really a challenge in this game, all you do is explore and enjoy the scenery that is around you. The graphics and physics of the plants and movement of the water is amazing and very well done. The music is relaxing and peaceful to listen to. The story is captivation and makes you want to know more. The game of Dear Esther has a very nice pace to it. It is calming and doesn't take long at all to beat. I highly recommend this gem to anyone who wants a change of pace and wants to just walk around and look at things while hearing a story. This is a great game and I've really enjoyed it from beginning to end.

Well I made it to chapter 2 and decided I need a break (holding "W" for 2 hours was taking it's toll) and I left the game. When I came back, there was no save file. Every time you start the game you have to go from the beginning. In the menu there is even a chapter select menu but they never unlock even after you reach the chapter.The story had lost me anyways, this book that calls itself a game isn't even worth a dollar.

content:

												I bought this game knowing full well there would not be much in the way of gameplay. I knew this would be more an interactive story than a game and that's fine. I really enjoyed "Gone Home" - another interactive story of sorts - so I thgouht I might enjoy this too. I was wrong.The only interactivity of any sort is slowly pacing along a set linear route while a voice speaks to you. I would love to be more clear but the plot was so stuffy I was left not knowing what really happened. The heavy use of metaphors sometimes made the plot feel a little streched thin over the time period and also helped to confuse me greatly as to what the speaker was actually on about. Sometimes it just felt like the writer was trying to get the most value for money from their newly bought thesaurus. On the plus side the soudtrack is quite nice and the scenery was at times beautiful.Pros:-cheap-beautiful setting-soundtrackCons:-Story is too stuffy/wordy-walk incredibly slowly-barely qualifies as interactive

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Not quite a game but a neat expericne none the less.  Just make sure you know what your getting into.This is one of those "Art" games where the point is more to elisit a reaction rather than deliver a full gameplay experice and if your into that sort of thing Dear Esther delivers.You find yourself on a deserted Island with no explination with who you are, whats going on, or what your goal is.  As you wander around a narrator will give you fragments of a strange tale at set loactions.  And thats really it.  Theres just enough story to make inturpertaion as to what happend and who you are but never straight out tells you.  The enviroments is at once lonely, haunting, and relaxing.  The music is pretty and atmospheric.  And you'll likely find yourself getting pulled into the game sort of like Myst minus the puzzles.  The game is short but doesn't overstay its welcome.I'm not sure if this "game" is worth the full release price but its gone down since its release and well worth grabbing during a sale.  Just understand what it is your buying.  If you want somthing different and layed back and enjoy experimental indy games that are more about light exploration and evocking emotion rather than game play, or if you just want to feel alone (and i mean that in a positive way) than give it a look.  If not you'll likely get bored really fast.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This game is very odd. It certainly won't be everyone's cup of tea. I definitely enjoyed it and felt it was quite beautiful.It's a game in which you explore an island and slowly piece together somebody's memories. Whose memories these are, why you're on this island, what things the narrator is actually talking about are not explained outright. It will stick in your head for days after you finish it, but I really like that.It's not stupid, but it does try a bit too hard to be clever. I'd rather that than stupid though. While there are some very helpful ideas online about the story of the game, I'd heavily recommend not reading those until at least a couple of days after you finish the game - I really enjoyed making my own mind up about things. Though it was certainly good to experience another person's take on things, and I was able to incorporate some other things into my experience.So it's not at all a traditional game. There's not really much challenge to it at all. An interactive story would probably be about right. But it's very pretty and very sad, and I found it enjoyable if a little too try-hard. Not for everyone though. If you want a short thinky experience, I would definitely recommend giving this a go.

content:

												Finally got around to playing this. I recommend playing through without the subtitles unless you really don't understand his accent. The text kept breaking the immersion for me. Visually very beautiful, and I recommend using some nice headphones and turning the lights down to get the full effect. Controls were very simple move, look, and zoom. I spent a little over an hour walking around till the end just taking everything in.Overall it was very interesting. I enjoyed the branching directions which always left me wondering if I should go back because I had missed something. There were also some various strange situations that gave me the impression that I was not alone. I kind of had an idea of what might happen at the end as the story felt it was shifting in tone but it still left things up in the air for the player to decide what the actual meaning was.Definitely recommend playing it once if you ever get a chance and have about an hour to kill.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												The island presented in Dear Esther is simultaneously beautiful and bleakly desolate. It sets the tone for rest of the game instantly, weaving a spell that hides the flatness of foliage and uniformity of every rock. The mystery inherent in the sporadic narration can't take the full blame for this witchcraft any more than the oddly stunning visuals or the sweetly melancholic instrumentation can as - over plucked heartstrings aside - very little can be pulled out of its impenetrable vagueness. The player is as hopelessly unable to effect change as the protagonist himself. There's no jumping, no crouching, no pressing of this or pulling of that; only endless walking. That's the height of input the player can provide; explore freely and listen as one random landmark or the other conjures a stray thought from the nameless protagonist. But as odd as it may sound, games with hundreds of pages of instructions leave behind less of a feeling of control than a game that won't even allow the player to turn on his or her own flashlight.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
"THERE ARE HEADLIGHTS REFLECTED IN THESE RETINAS, TOO LONG IN THE TUNNELS OF MY ISLAND WITHOUT A BOTTOM. THE SEA CREATURES HAVE RISEN TO THE SURFACE, BUT THE GULLS ARE NOT HERE TO CARRY THEM BACK TO THEIR NESTS. I HAVE BECOME FIXED: OPEN AND STARING, AN EYE TURNED ON ITSELF. I HAVE BECOME AN INFECTED LEG, WHOSE TRACKING LINES FORM A PERFECTMAP OF THE JUNCTIONS OF THE M5. I WILL TAKE THE EXIT AT MID-THIGH AND PLUMMET TO MY ESTHER."There's a line between game and product. There's a line between thing and art. Art is just a word and everybody considerate art different. So with this game. It has tossed a line between game and product and also between thing and art. That means somebody will hate this game because of statement like "You can't do anything there". Few months ago I did a complex review at certain website which took around 5 pages and reactions were as I expected - hateful. This game is POLARIZED. That means this game has only high and very low ratings. Or even no ratings at all. Dear Esther is a game, but on the other side it's like book, movie and game in one.We can sum it up in one sentence - You will travel through unbelievable, amazing, awesome and beautiful locations, and listen to one hell of a story of a man who loved the Esther. Bonus Point: IslandRating: N/A

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dear Eshter.It is my regret that I am incapable of writing anything nearly as beautiful as the letters meant for Esther. Letters stained in brilliant lines by the love poured over them from a man in grief.Dear Esther is a very slow burning story that many people would easily find to be dreadfully boring. But in the same length of time in which you could watch a feature length film, you can simply wander through overgrown paths on an island and traverse the gorgeous caves beneath. The scenery is stunning but empty except for some cryptic clues; equally as cryptic as the haunting narration that accompanies them.Rarely have I cared so much to understand an allegorical story. and never have I come out of one with at least three distinct theories as to its meaning, narrative, past, and conclusion. However, the most unfortunate aspect of trying to delve in to the deepest parts of the story is the inevitable realization that, unknowable details aside, the circumstances of the events are not very interesting; they just tug at a few emotional strings. One of the few things that sets Dear Esther apart from Proteus is the fact that there is a story and there are actually some things on the deserted island that garner attention.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2013
												It's very hard to describe something which is not considered a game yet it claims to be one. Dear Esther brings up the whole discussion whether video games can be a form of art or not, I honestly believe I can but this case feels somewhat different for me. In Dear Esther the character you play as narrates an interesting and compeling story which comes with very great music, despite lacking most of the times. Not only that but you are able to witness some really beautifull landscapes and underground sections which probably were the most enjoying part for me. This leads to the a great question, is Dear Esther really a game? As far as I see it doesn't really offer any gameplay at all, you just walk around, it's basicly like watching a movie where you are the camera man per say. It's really hard for me to talk about these so called "games" but yet I think that Dear Esther offers a great and wonderfull experience, please do bare in mind that this is not for everyone.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This was one of the most thought provoking experiences I've had in gaming. And before I say anything else, this won't be for everyone, this is not a conventional game, more an "interactive" experience. No spoilers but this game focuses everything on exploration rather than any sort of interaction, hence the quotation marks earlier. With that said, it is still an amazingly immersive experience. I started the game at midnight and finishing it just after 2am, yes I'm aware that that is a lot longer than most people took to finish this, but I walked around and tried to explore as much as I could. The graphics are pretty fantastic and the sound and music and lighting adds so much to the experience. This is a story driven game, and yet it is all up to you. The narration, which is very well done, only hints at things and it is up to you to make up your own mind about what is happening. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												A full three seconds into watching the trailer, I determined I would perchase the work of art that is Dear Esther.The music of the trailer sets such a mood for the experience that unfolds, it is hard to imagine a game begining this good to be capable of stumbling in execution. And the product does not disapoint. The enviroment is exelent, as it must be to fill the void  left by any form of "gameplay" in this work of artistic sotrytelling.And Dear Esther must be clasified more generally than a game as a "work of art". To call it a game is missleading; a game is filled with game concerns, traps, puzzles, obstacles, and oponnents, and Dear Esther has only the obstecle of your enviroment, an obstecle which you have no ability to overcome, having not even the ability to jump. If you come looking for a game, you will be disapointed.And yet it is this simplicity of presentation that gives Dear Esther its most poignent value; it diverts, if you will let it, your attention from "finding the right soloution" to "finding your own path to follow". It confuses the audience at first, as you atempt to find the correct way to an assumed goal and realize that all the paths lead to the same destination. For example, whenever the game presents the audience with a new enviroment or vista, there is allways a rather obvious main path and several more or less secluded side paths. These will either eventuallly set the audience back on track or abruply dead end, often with a unique dialouge log at the end. But when one turns around in slight fustration that you will have to retrace the same path to get back on track, you realize that there is a second path back, diverging off in a different direction with new a new route to the eventual ending. Level design is Dear Esthers strongest virtue when judged as a "game", containing excelent and intuative, if slightly constaining, paths to the eventual goal.And this constriction is fine in a long and winding journey. Consider the Half Life series. When compared with an open world enviroment, the levels of Half Life are terribly constricting in their layout. They are intricate, but they are constrained to be mostly linear. The games overall, though, do not suffer from this lack of expansivene options becaues of their extensive length. The alternitive form is to have a shorter direct story but a larger and much more open world to tell it in, as games like Skyrim do.Dear Esther, though suffers on it's first playthrough becaues of its length. The game is over far too quickly, leaving the audience with the feeling that it might have done so much more with the world it set up. It is almost fustrating to think about how much bigger the game could have been, how much more could have been explored and experienced, how much longer the game might have been.To understand this feeling, consider the construction of the Stanley Parable. Dear Esther shares many charachteristics with that more popular title, Nonlinear sotrytelling, a seemingly short storry on fist playthrough, and an omnicient narrator talking to a powerless player. The differences lie in the execution of each. The Stanley Parable focuses on the concept of choice, of free will, on examining through repeated playthroughs the nature and impacts of choices the player makes. Dear Esther is a game wholy absorbed in it's story, in atempting to pice together the charachter of the narrator, or even if the narrator is only a single person. Over it's short playtime one constantly rediscovers the core of the game, which evolves rapidly as the story progresses. Many complain of the game being too long and borring, but I think it suffers from just the oposite. It is incrediably short if played straight through, leaving you with almost a sense of disapointment that you did not get more out of it, just as when you play the Stanley Parable following all the narrators instructions for the "happy" ending. To truely enjoy Dear Esther, leave no path unexpored, no audio log unheard, and play againBut while the Stanley Parable is comic, Dear Esther is dramatic, which is a great deal of why many dislike the game for being "slow". It is the same reson many dislike 2001: A Space Odyssey for being "slow"; you must look harder to discover the meaning. In the same way that for some the ending the 2001 is "disapointing" for being anticlimactic after the buildup of the last part of the movie, so is the end of Dear Esther "disapointing", for the most profound part of each is the jouney, not the destination.It is incredible to jouney through Dear Esther, and while you may be left wanting something more than the game provides, what it does provide it does exceptionally well. And prehaps this supports one of the many ideas the game hopes to imbune, that there is nothing more to tell of the narrator's storry, for there will always be mysteries that cannot be unraveld.After the game's ending, which is as suprising as everything else in the jouney you have been on, the game fades to black with the sounds of the sea, looping ever onwards, leaving the player to think about the voyage they have been on, and eventually realize that now they must press escape, select exit, and leave the world of the game for their everyday lives.In short, If you want a darker, more dramatic Stanley Parable, then this game is for you. If you appriciate ambiguity in your art, this game is for you. If you are interested in level design and game story telling, this game is for you. As long as you do not expect a game with gameplay concerns, and instead are content with an exceptional story of the struggles of the human mind told in a modern visual poem, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2013
												Be ready, you W key is about to get rapped.Visually this game is incredible. Seriously. I was completely amazed by some places i saw. Some of them are currently my desktop wallpaper.The soundtrack is also great and together with the visuals make this "game" a really nice experience.The story makes no sense whatsoever on purpose, and i think is also a strong part of the game. You never know the full meaning of what you are seeing/being told. And that for me is good, in a way that the "game" is always making you wonder and assume things. The meaning for the story and things you see is the one you want to give to them.Now, the weak parts.Despite the good things i mentioned above, let's not forget that the game is extremely linear. You walk to where the game wants you to walk, that's it. You have absolutely no choice. (To press or not to press W it's not really a choice, is it?)I enjoyed the game overall, but i should not hide the fact that the game had some boring parts, where you are only asking yourself "will this end anytime soon?". Usually you are then given a new place to go and another piece of excellent narrative, that helps to obfuscate that, but you will probably feel bored some times.I do not recommend the game for full price, but if you catch it on sale, i would say to give it a shot.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I was not engaged by the story, the most raved-about aspect of this game. The narrator has a fine voice, and delivers his lines well, but all too often the lines themselves are pompous and intentionally confusing.The game doesn't confine itself to normal rules, but offers you a chance to explore as you like. The trouble is, exploring takes far too long. Not being able to run or jump may serve an ultimate purpose, but I found it to be detrimental to exploring the island. Numerous times I wondered what was around a corner or up a hill, only to realise that invisible walls or faulty polygon detection would get in my way halfway through the journey and I'd give up.I do not have a problem with the length of the game in comparison to the price. However, I expect the emotional impact to be that much more potent. This did not deliver anything close to an impact.I would not recommend this game, but would definitely be interested in the developer's second attempt at a game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Dear Esther is the kind of game you play entirely in one sitting, that feels short and that makes you question what you just experienced, but that leaves a giant mark on your appreciation of passive narratives and video games as an art form.In a way, each playthrough is different, as some parts of the story are chosen at random between a pool of possible happenings, but the core of the story stays the same in all playthroughs, which kind of make you want to play again and again to see what the other elements of the story end up adding to your understanding of what happened. The entire time the way you're supposed to go is fairly obvious, but at some points you have to explore a bit to know where to go. "hile I'm not really a fan of linear paths, this one felt like it was deserved, as if the character you're playing know this path, has walked it thousands of times.The story in itself is something that's hard to describe and understand. If you look online, you'll find countless blog posts, forum discussions, professional and amateur analyses and theories about what really happened. Things like this make the game feel more like people describing and discussing themselves having walked through a book rather than be discussing a video game, and I mean this in the best of ways.If you're the kind of person who likes easter eggs as well, this game will fulfill that craving for you. There are things that if you aren't careful enough you'll miss, which add to the stories and the theories, and seems to be just as much a part of your experience and the narrative as the narrating.PROS:Great storyAmazing atmosphereTo this day the community is trying to understand the deeper meaning, you can be part of that community too!Beautiful scenery, you can tell the creators took their timeA sense of wonder I've yet to experience againCONS:Lots of downtime where nothing happensThe atmosphere can be very creepy at times, putting you on edge even though this is one of the calmest games ever.At some points it was difficult for me to know which way to go to advance the gameWould I recommend this?Absolutely. This game is one of the games that I will never forget in my life and that I will continue to mention time and time again.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2013
												An interesting experiment that's more interesting for what it attempts to do than what it actually accomplishes.  Playing "Dear Esther" I couldn't help but feel like video games were taking a small step forward in terms of what they could do, which is admirable, yet the game as a whole never really stopped feeling like a disjointed story awkwardly slapped on to some (really, really, beautiful) level design.Still, the first silent film to start using camera pans and tracking shots wasn't that great either, so I'm ultimately more hopeful that "Dead Esther" will lead to better things than it achieves on its own.  And playing it really made me realize how readily adaptable some modernist novels would be to "Dear Esther's" style of first person gameplay (someone please loan me a million dollars so I can adapt Virginia Woolf's "To the Lighthouse" to the Source engine.  It would be AWESOME!).

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Absolutely incredible... Assuming you can appreciate a more 'artistic' take on gaming. In truth there isn't much gaming here, it is more like an interactive movie... Or book. The game is a slow walk around a gorgeous island while an elequent, but verbose, narator reads from letters he will never send to Esther. The graphics are amazing (no teslation or anything but very high resolution textures and advanced lighting and reflection). The island is rendered beautifully and the story is interesting enough to hold your attention. The biggest down side is that I 'beat the game' in a little over an hour. I am pretty cheap, I buy almost everything on sale in Steam and somehow this was worth it at $10 for 1 hour.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
Is Dear Esther a good game?Since there are no decisions to make, nothing to interact with, nothing to win, and no way to lose - I don't think it's fair to judge it as a game when it's not even trying to be one.so then...Is Dear Esther a good experience?From purely audiovisual standpoint it's competent, but models and textures are clearly showing their age, and what little music there is sounds good but forgettable. If you were hoping to just wander around and explore - you'll only find yourself limited to a few linear paths, and even those don't offer much beyond some pretty vistas. There's little to find, and what you do find can't be interacted with in any way whatsoever.Most importantly, story (or something resembling it) is so fragmented and buried so deeply in metaphors that I couldn't make much sense of it. Perhaps it's truly something great if you figure it out; Maybe there's a deep message worthy of appreciation. Whatever it is - it's hidden well, and nothing about Dear Esther makes me want to keep looking.

												Dear Esther is an "art game" where you play from a first-person perspective and explore a mysterious island. Unlike similar games like Gone Home, which actually let you manipulate objects, the only real interaction you have in Dear Esther is your movement through the environment. As you explore, a narrator occasionally speaks, each time adding more to the underlying story of the island, and helping you understand the journey you're taking.Dear Esther is one of those gaming experiences that you have to want to have to really enjoy it. The world is interesting and at times, truly beautiful. The music is haunting. And the story, ultimately, is worth the 1-2 hours the game takes to complete.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Edit: Alright, so I finished it, and it's much more interesting toward the end. The game gets off to an extremely slow start, but find your way around, get off the beach areas, and endure 'til later, and your experience will greatly improve. There's a lot more to see once you're off the beach. I wouldn't pay full price for this game, but if exploring games are your thing, you could give this a try.---------------------------One hour into the game:I guess it's pretty, if desolate, and the narrator has some poetic lines (once in a while, when you find where you're supposed to go), but the majority of my experience so far as been... frankly, uncomfortable. I find myself wishing that you could move faster instead of walking so painfully slowly, and it's extremely off-putting that you can't jump or climb. At all. At this point I feel like I'd jump for joy if I could just get to the top of this mountain. If you get lost easily like me, it's going to be difficult in the beginning. There's a lot of backtracking, and I'm not quite sure where to go, ever. The narrator is completely unhelpful when you're trying to figure out where to go next, and this self-guided tour is starting to feel pretty oppressive. I find myself desperately wanting to leave this abandoned beach.First-person exploration games are probably not for me, but if they're your cup of tea, it might be worthwhile to try this. If you're got an eye for detail and enjoy analyzing your environment to help supplement/piece together a storyline, maybe this is for you. As for me, I think I need more direction and structure in my games...

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It is hard for me to explain exactly how much I disliked this game. For reference I enjoy exploration games and am more than familiar with the world of fine art and have a very high threshold for "artsy" things in general. I'm convinced that the only reason why this game got good reviews from so many people is because it's obtuse enough that they figured it must make them seem smart to say they liked it. The main character moves painfully slowly which wouldn't be an issue if the environment were more enjoyable. The addition of random statements that do not tie in with the environment actually take away from the game. Most of it seems like someone came up with some interesting looking areas and some cryptic statements and decided that throwing them together at random would be a lovely idea for a game. Every so often the statements will line up with the environment and there's a moment of clarity about what is going on. Unfortunately those moments of clarity were not interesting enough to make me care in the slightest what was going on. I think I would have enjoyed this slightly more if no one had tried to tell me it was good first. That and if the bits of dialogue were not randomized in an attempt to make it different or if they were written so that it pieced together better regardless of order. There are ways of making your audience work that are effective and enjoyable, this game doesn't use any of them.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												If you're expecting an interactive experience, don't play Dear Esther, you will be disappointed. There is no combat, no puzzles, no NPCS, no skill trees, no multiplayer, no buttons, levers, or computers.. not even a door to open.However, if you are interested in hearing a great story and seeing gorgious environments then you will love this game. The game would be best described as visual storytelling. You walk around a quiet and mysterious island. As you walk around you will hear well written and spoken narration of the story as it unfolds the further you explore. These bits of narration often coincide with any landmarks you happen to be near. While sometimes it can be tedious trying to walk around some of the larger areas due to the slow movement speed, for the most part the environments will keep you engaged. These environments are jaw-droppingly beautiful, in particular the caves caused me to walk around saying "whoa" with every new room. To think that they managed to harness this level of beauty out of the Source engine is nothing short of amazing.Overall, the game will only last you about 1 hour for a playthrough, but it's definitely a must to experience at least once.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dear Esther is not a game. It is an interactive experience. It's also quite depressing and - despite some beautiful visuals - quite dull.More of an art experiment, "Dear Esther" has you following in the footsteps of a would-be suicide as he mournfully regrets the loss of his deceased wife. It's neat how the game randomly picks parts of the narrative to play  to you as you wander the moors; no run through will get exactly the same experience. Unfortunately, that narrative is dry and uninteresting. The moors are pretty but there's nothing to do there except marvel at the graphics. And the end is entirely predictable. Frankly, I'd have been better off just looking at the screenshots.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												 I'm relieved to see Steam add a negative reviews option just so I can bash the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this ♥♥♥♥ing game.  Well, "game." Dear Esther isn't much of a game, it's more like reliving a painful school trip where your legs hurt like♥♥♥♥♥♥ the guide was a boring ♥♥♥♥, the teacher wouldn't stop asking questions and your crush didn't show.  Many people will say this game is beautiful. Many people will say the voice acting and the writing is superb. Many people have incurably bad taste.  While some of the visuals in this game are alright, it's nothing special. There are a lot of indie games that do a far better job of establishing an atmosphere. Hell, if you want to look at pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ you're better off jerking your eyes over a modded TES than this thing.  On to the story and the writing -- it's ♥♥♥♥ing drivel. There's nothing enjoyable in the monotone voice acting, nor in the workaday lines being read. Whatever they tried to accomplish, it failed; quite miserably.  The two monumental issues that plague this game however, are its linearity and the speed of progression. For the most part, you're stuck trudging down the same track like a moron. That wouldn't be so positively mind-blastingly painful if you weren't forced to walk at the same ♥♥♥♥ing speed throughout the entire game. I mean even using the word 'speed' in this paragraph seems wrong, it's like roleplaying a ♥♥♥♥ing slug caught in some lab experiment while your edgy teenage owner is practicing his reciting for the drama course.  Please, kill me. I don't want to risk even having to watch this being played ever again.  Monumental thumbs down.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												An unusually well-polished example of minimalist game design, Dear Esther puts you in control of a dying narrator as he explores an abandoned island (as well as his own miserable past and the histories of those who walked the island before him). The voice-acting is top-notch, the writing is excellent (if a bit too heavy-handed at times), and the island's design nails the experience together perfectly, sending the mood from merely gloomy in the beginning to stunning and hallucinatory as time goes by and the pacing escalates. Unfortunately, it also tends toward a bit of directionlessness; particularly in the first chapter, I found myself doubling back after spending several minutes exploring a meaningless fjord or accidentally returning the way I came.The gameplay also suffers for this. Your controls are limited to the standard movement of an FPS title with no jumping, crouching, or running enabled. You can't interact with the world around you in any way beyond wandering around and a simple zoom function you can activate with a left mouse click. Oh, and I suppose that there's a Don't Commit Suicide button (Q) which you can use to swim to the surface after "accidentally" falling into the ocean. The near absence of gameplay is necessary to the story, really, but it still felt as though it hurt the overall experience. All the same, it's absolutely worth playing if you feel like filling a couple hours with something different for cheap.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dear Eshter.It is my regret that I am incapable of writing anything nearly as beautiful as the letters meant for Esther. Letters stained in brilliant lines by the love poured over them from a man in grief.Dear Esther is a very slow burning story that many people would easily find to be dreadfully boring. But in the same length of time in which you could watch a feature length film, you can simply wander through overgrown paths on an island and traverse the gorgeous caves beneath. The scenery is stunning but empty except for some cryptic clues; equally as cryptic as the haunting narration that accompanies them.Rarely have I cared so much to understand an allegorical story. and never have I come out of one with at least three distinct theories as to its meaning, narrative, past, and conclusion. However, the most unfortunate aspect of trying to delve in to the deepest parts of the story is the inevitable realization that, unknowable details aside, the circumstances of the events are not very interesting; they just tug at a few emotional strings. One of the few things that sets Dear Esther apart from Proteus is the fact that there is a story and there are actually some things on the deserted island that garner attention.

												It's very hard to describe something which is not considered a game yet it claims to be one. Dear Esther brings up the whole discussion whether video games can be a form of art or not, I honestly believe I can but this case feels somewhat different for me. In Dear Esther the character you play as narrates an interesting and compeling story which comes with very great music, despite lacking most of the times. Not only that but you are able to witness some really beautifull landscapes and underground sections which probably were the most enjoying part for me. This leads to the a great question, is Dear Esther really a game? As far as I see it doesn't really offer any gameplay at all, you just walk around, it's basicly like watching a movie where you are the camera man per say. It's really hard for me to talk about these so called "games" but yet I think that Dear Esther offers a great and wonderfull experience, please do bare in mind that this is not for everyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												A full three seconds into watching the trailer, I determined I would perchase the work of art that is Dear Esther.The music of the trailer sets such a mood for the experience that unfolds, it is hard to imagine a game begining this good to be capable of stumbling in execution. And the product does not disapoint. The enviroment is exelent, as it must be to fill the void  left by any form of "gameplay" in this work of artistic sotrytelling.And Dear Esther must be clasified more generally than a game as a "work of art". To call it a game is missleading; a game is filled with game concerns, traps, puzzles, obstacles, and oponnents, and Dear Esther has only the obstecle of your enviroment, an obstecle which you have no ability to overcome, having not even the ability to jump. If you come looking for a game, you will be disapointed.And yet it is this simplicity of presentation that gives Dear Esther its most poignent value; it diverts, if you will let it, your attention from "finding the right soloution" to "finding your own path to follow". It confuses the audience at first, as you atempt to find the correct way to an assumed goal and realize that all the paths lead to the same destination. For example, whenever the game presents the audience with a new enviroment or vista, there is allways a rather obvious main path and several more or less secluded side paths. These will either eventuallly set the audience back on track or abruply dead end, often with a unique dialouge log at the end. But when one turns around in slight fustration that you will have to retrace the same path to get back on track, you realize that there is a second path back, diverging off in a different direction with new a new route to the eventual ending. Level design is Dear Esthers strongest virtue when judged as a "game", containing excelent and intuative, if slightly constaining, paths to the eventual goal.And this constriction is fine in a long and winding journey. Consider the Half Life series. When compared with an open world enviroment, the levels of Half Life are terribly constricting in their layout. They are intricate, but they are constrained to be mostly linear. The games overall, though, do not suffer from this lack of expansivene options becaues of their extensive length. The alternitive form is to have a shorter direct story but a larger and much more open world to tell it in, as games like Skyrim do.Dear Esther, though suffers on it's first playthrough becaues of its length. The game is over far too quickly, leaving the audience with the feeling that it might have done so much more with the world it set up. It is almost fustrating to think about how much bigger the game could have been, how much more could have been explored and experienced, how much longer the game might have been.To understand this feeling, consider the construction of the Stanley Parable. Dear Esther shares many charachteristics with that more popular title, Nonlinear sotrytelling, a seemingly short storry on fist playthrough, and an omnicient narrator talking to a powerless player. The differences lie in the execution of each. The Stanley Parable focuses on the concept of choice, of free will, on examining through repeated playthroughs the nature and impacts of choices the player makes. Dear Esther is a game wholy absorbed in it's story, in atempting to pice together the charachter of the narrator, or even if the narrator is only a single person. Over it's short playtime one constantly rediscovers the core of the game, which evolves rapidly as the story progresses. Many complain of the game being too long and borring, but I think it suffers from just the oposite. It is incrediably short if played straight through, leaving you with almost a sense of disapointment that you did not get more out of it, just as when you play the Stanley Parable following all the narrators instructions for the "happy" ending. To truely enjoy Dear Esther, leave no path unexpored, no audio log unheard, and play againBut while the Stanley Parable is comic, Dear Esther is dramatic, which is a great deal of why many dislike the game for being "slow". It is the same reson many dislike 2001: A Space Odyssey for being "slow"; you must look harder to discover the meaning. In the same way that for some the ending the 2001 is "disapointing" for being anticlimactic after the buildup of the last part of the movie, so is the end of Dear Esther "disapointing", for the most profound part of each is the jouney, not the destination.It is incredible to jouney through Dear Esther, and while you may be left wanting something more than the game provides, what it does provide it does exceptionally well. And prehaps this supports one of the many ideas the game hopes to imbune, that there is nothing more to tell of the narrator's storry, for there will always be mysteries that cannot be unraveld.After the game's ending, which is as suprising as everything else in the jouney you have been on, the game fades to black with the sounds of the sea, looping ever onwards, leaving the player to think about the voyage they have been on, and eventually realize that now they must press escape, select exit, and leave the world of the game for their everyday lives.In short, If you want a darker, more dramatic Stanley Parable, then this game is for you. If you appriciate ambiguity in your art, this game is for you. If you are interested in level design and game story telling, this game is for you. As long as you do not expect a game with gameplay concerns, and instead are content with an exceptional story of the struggles of the human mind told in a modern visual poem, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2013
												Be ready, you W key is about to get rapped.Visually this game is incredible. Seriously. I was completely amazed by some places i saw. Some of them are currently my desktop wallpaper.The soundtrack is also great and together with the visuals make this "game" a really nice experience.The story makes no sense whatsoever on purpose, and i think is also a strong part of the game. You never know the full meaning of what you are seeing/being told. And that for me is good, in a way that the "game" is always making you wonder and assume things. The meaning for the story and things you see is the one you want to give to them.Now, the weak parts.Despite the good things i mentioned above, let's not forget that the game is extremely linear. You walk to where the game wants you to walk, that's it. You have absolutely no choice. (To press or not to press W it's not really a choice, is it?)I enjoyed the game overall, but i should not hide the fact that the game had some boring parts, where you are only asking yourself "will this end anytime soon?". Usually you are then given a new place to go and another piece of excellent narrative, that helps to obfuscate that, but you will probably feel bored some times.I do not recommend the game for full price, but if you catch it on sale, i would say to give it a shot.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												People have told me that this is a breakthrough in video game storytelling. Honestly, I find that incredibly insulting. Fallout, Planescape Torment, Chrono Trigger... These are what I consider prime examples of storytelling in video games. Something that takes the player into account, where not only are you the center of the game's world, you also have a say in its fate. Good interactive storytelling is just that; interactive. It should take advantage of the medium the author chose and how much potential it has to make something truly unique and expansive. Dear Esther squanders this in almost every way. It is a brief, bland episode of nothing but walking down a narrow pathway, observing the static environment as the author reads aloud his bad poetry. And yes, the poetry itself is bad, at least I think it is. If you think Dear Esther is good poetry, that's fine. I won't think any less of you for it. Just don't call it a good video game. It isn't one.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2013
												This isn't a game so much as an interactive work of art. The only thing you can do is walk around looking at things while you listen to the narrative. It's like walking around inside an audio book. The movement speed is frustratingly slow unless you hack the ini files (which you should).The story is very good and emotionally gripping. You won't hear the whole thing on a single playthrough. Each playthrough tells random snippets of the story, and the game leaves you to piece together the rest. This makes for fun conversations when you discuss the plot with your friends but there's not enough variety for more than a couple replays.Game length is about an hour, but there's enough content to stretch that out to two hours through a second replay. Worth playing for the novelty - there's not much else out there like this.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Dear Esther is more of an experience than a game.  And that experience is one where you will need to peel the onion to see what lurks below the surface.  The experience is rich in layers of perception and one which varies from player to player and even for the same player, if he or she repeats any of the chapters of Dear Esther.  Usually in a game we would expect some combination of: * A set of rules* Interactions with NPC's or other players* The ability to interact with the environment; e.g. pick up stuff, move things, shoot things, etc.* Quests* Achievements* In-Game RewardsYou won't find any of that in Dear Esther, at least not in the way you might expect, if at all.  Rather in Dear Esther you can only move along some fairly well defined paths using directional controls.  With a controller, the left stick is directional for  movement and the right stick is directional for view.  That's it. You can't pick up an item to examine it.  There is no interaction with any other player or any NPC's.  The only quest would be your exploration of the location following a linear path where certain points trigger narrator readings of text  in what is presumably meant to be letters to Esther, who may or not be real and who you never meet and who you suspect is dead, if she lived at all.So if this isn't a game, what kind of gamer would want to fire up Dear Esther and wander around to see what there is to offer in the virtual environment?   I suspect that there isn't any one personality type that one would have to be to enjoy this, but it would appeal most to a person given to introspection, who likes to patiently collect clues and peel them away to try to uncover the real story and not be particularly upset, if the answer is that there isn't necessarily an answer or that there are many answers that all may have some degree of validity.  In other words it is a mind game, if it is a game at all.  And one where you are left to try to discern meaning amid chaos and confusion in an imperfect world where your questions are not always answered.The experience runs between an hour and half to twelve hours depending on how fast you proceed and whether or not you go back to replay and see what you missed.  And yes, you can miss a great deal the first time through - either because it wasn't there in the first place or because you were tuned in to find it.  For example, there are as many as ten ghostly appearances and you may only see one or two the first time through Dear Esther.   I say this based on what I perceived in my playthrough and what others have reported in their playthrough(s).  The Celtic music is absolutely haunting and makes the game superb.  If you don't get goosebumps, you're not paying attention.  The visuals are stunning and the narrative readings are full of emotion and maybe more.  All of it works together to cause you to feel a lot of emotion while causing you to start asking more and more questions about what it is that you are experiencing.  So by now you are probably saying, "What the heck kind of review is this?  You are talking in circles and driving me nuts."  If so, I understand.  The answer is that this really isn't a game in the traditional sense and instead an experience where you are given clues in the environment and narration to piece together after which you are expected to use a healthy dose of imagination, layer peeling, and deductive reasoning to shape your own idea of what the story really is.In truth of it is that Dear Esther is one of those things where you may get more out of it by discussing it with friends and other players than by just playing it through. If you decide to have a run at Dear Esther, you might be well advised to constantly ask:*  Is what I'm perceiving real?*  Is there symbolism here?*  Is this place real or imaginary; e.g., is this a memory, a dream, some device, a real location, or some combination?*  Are the names of people given in the narration separate real individuals, creations of a fractured mind, representations of something other than a person, etc.In the end you may ask is this a simple sad story of withdrawl from the world and madness following the death of a loved one, or something entirely different?At this point I must apologize for a review that has taken longer to write than it took to run through Dear Esther itself.  So now it is probably time to close with a few thoughts.Dear Esther got me to put my thinking cap on and see many possibilities, which is sometimes a good thing.  And perhaps that's the point of Dear Esther to get people to examine perception and meaning.  I suspect that Dear Esther's value is more in the discussion than in the playing.If you do play Dear Esther all the way through and come out with more questions, than answers, I recommend a look at the guide at 


Dear Esther: Secrets and More 
A Guide for Dear Esther
By: mrmusicallion

			Although this game might be (far) less interactive than many - garnering criticisms that it is 'merely a walking simulator', there is more to Dear Esther than what many seem to recognise.		


.  But don't look at it until you have exhausted your play-through.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Dear Esther is a somber promenade in the chronicle of a morbid lover -- an opaque, emotional, restless, slightly fatalistic fever dream, if fever dreams were ever digitized. It's not a videogame; there is no interaction, save for the narrator's cues. It's more of a semi-cinematic, semi-literary, three-dimensional painting for the player to wander semi-aimlessly. If you dispense with any notion of depth and allow yourself to be absorbed in the beautiful world (beyond question, the best-looking application of the Source engine to-date), Dear Esther provides a truly unique experience for the jaded appetite.

												I really wanted to enjoy this game, and there was a little part in the middle that was memorable, but the rest of game (which clocks in at about 60-80 minutes, depending on how much you explore the hallway the leveldesign is.) was not very embracing.There is no gameplay except walking and the story is told by a single VA. number of helpful: 47 of 94 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Imagine a real-time 3D version of Myst, except the environemnt isn't as interesting, there is no real story, the only action required by the player is that they follow the intended story path without trying to get too creative, there are no puzzles of any kind, and some dreary, bitter-sounding british guy talks incessantly and cryptically about something that happened in his past that he is apparently upset about.I hated this, and wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy. If for some reason you still give a ♥♥♥♥ about this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game and plan to play it, I guess I should warn you that there are spoilers ahead.This game is such boring, pretentious, fart-sniffing crap that I have difficulty organizing my thoughts about it. Anyone who tells you that this game is creative, revolutionary, ground-breaking, or "worth playing at least once" is a complete ♥♥♥♥ing moron who you should probably avoid talking to ever again. The visuals are bland and repetitive, as there isn't much on the island, and the graphics are dated (think HL2 on medium). There's no real story, unless you count the ramblings of a depressed british guy. Apparently the VO is semi-random, but never changes enough to lend the game any replay value (an impossible feat anyway, since the game has no value in the first place). As you progress through the game, it may or may not be vaguely hinted at that the depressed british guy is upset about his girlfriend having been killed by a drunk driver. In the end you kill yourself by jumping off of a radio tower. In true fart-sniffing form, just before your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ character does the world a favor by pancaking at terminal velocity, he turns into a bird and soars away (?!?!?!) as the music gets all dramatic and the credits roll. It's never really clear if you are the depressed british guy or what (does he just walk around this crappy island muttering to himself? Is he a voice in my head? Was he a bird all along? If so, why doesn't he just fly to the radio tower instead of wasting 2 hours walking there?). Honestly, the biggest problem this game is that it isn't really a game. The ONLY story progression occurs in the form of your character TALKING TO HIMSELF, the actions the player performs are boring, and don't contribute to, or in any way seem to relate to the actual story, which might as well just be a radio show since it's all told in voice-over as you hold the "progress" button until the game ends.  This game so completely misses the point (pick any point, it misses them all) that, like Star Wars Episode 1, I don't even know where to start telling anyone how seriously awful it is.

Adding even more depth.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												A jaw-dropping visual experience that's sadly wasted by an extremely disappointing storyline followed by a catastrophically pretentious and insubstantial ending that lacks any real meaning. If you're looking for a good philosophical adventure with elements of exploration and discovery, I recommend you completely ignore Dear Esther and instead play something like The Stanley Parable or Alan Wake.The "gameplay" of Dear Esther (for me) went from a giddy awe-inspiring exploration, seeking clues and adventure within an incredibly immersive environment full of realistic atmospheric soundscapes, but slowly transforms into a tedious illusion limited by frustratingly erroneous boundaries compounded by the inability to run or jump or interact with anything.There was allot of potential for this to be an amazing experience that rewards exploration with a genuine philosophical mind-bending story, but I was sadly left with an abysmally hollow sinking experience made infinitely worse by a lackluster storyline and ending, which somehow manages to get even worse by drowning persistence and curiosity with a black screen that perpetually does nothing and goes nowhere.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												A pathetic attempt at profundity and a complete waste of time. To be clear, I love experiemental, explorative, and narrative games. Gone Home is great, I even appreciate The Graveyard. But Dear Esther is like someone got really high, read ten pages of Melville, and tried to write a novel in his style. When he looked and realized it was only two pages long, he decided to make it seem longer by dispersing two paragraphs at a time while you walk across a hill. The characters are nothing more than names, there is no emotion to speak of, and the mystery is answered by another mystery- why you even played the game at all. It is utterly without substance or redeeming value of any sort.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												"Dear Esther" is not a game.  It's a demonstration in poorly designed camera movements.  There are only three actions you can take in this "application."  (1) Mouse-look around.  (2) WASD Movement.  (3) Right-button click to Zoom.  That is the entire experience.  You cannot manipulate anything in the game except for the camera and the story makes very little sense.  The entire experience is about enjoying the view and the narration, and nothing more.  This is not a puzzle game, this is not a first-person shooter game.  Spend your money elsewhere.I'm actually very disappointed in Steam for marketing this as a game.

												This is a walking simulator. There's no way around that. I don't know why people call this an "explotarion" game. There's no exploration to be done, the game is as linear as anything can be, so you are not actually exploring but merely walking (very frustatingly slowly) across pieces of land and whatnot.The story may be ok, but I'd rather see it in a video. The game is extremely boring and all you want to do is finish it fast enough to stop your suffering (which becomes more painful than that of the protagonist). I, unfortunately, couldn't finish the game. I paid a little bit more than a dollar for this and I still feel it's one of the worst spent dollars in my life.If this game were to have any achievements it would only need one and that one should be unlocked just for installing and running the game (does anyone see the irony in "running" this game?). number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Dear Esther,I find myself wandering this metaphor for of my personality at one quarter speed, desperately pecking about my keyboard for a dash button, least a toggle to run. Lo, there is none. Like a frozen water hose beckoning to its spicket to writhe in freedom as though it where a snake in a sandbox, my path is locked in linearity. Oh how my heart aches at the thought of back tracking but a single step.I find myself growing paranoid, fearing the tepid sound of my own stair. Fear, causing me to spin about, nonexistent sword at the ready, like a cocktail waitress of low breed in a seedy club who felt a dactyl retraction on her posterior. For an instant, from the corner of my mind’s eye, I see a saber tooth stalking me. It is only when I have spun and became prostrate that I realize, I am not in Tamriel. For you see, dear Esther, I suffer an affliction of the soul. Post Traumatic Skyrim Disorder.Deep into the depths of the danky and dark I do dive. Driving like a drinking drunkard of a drunk driver doused with dreary delusions of deft direction. You see? It was not some guy who may or may not be me or you or someone we know! It may have been some abstract things such as the paint on the road that caused something that has turned me totally emo!Oh how I bore of this. Though the landscape it beautiful, like a popular actress to an affection starved, near sided pauper who increases the likelihood of the furthering of his lineage by the systematic decline at which is screens potential mistresses.. Alas, it is lacking in not the smallest of margins from compensation. I find myself lobotomized, autonomous. Being startled by the sudden outburst of my own pompous and over articulated voice whose only purpose seems to be the attempt at making the narrator sound superior to the listener in learning and culture. Taking simple concepts and over complicating them with a wondrous and not so whimsical weave of extra words. To say things such as my overly denied self-realized need to disregard those of the fairer gender whom would by polite social custom find me by the barest of criteria a potential suitor and dedicate my time and energies to acquiring and building the means for the business of collecting currency is copious sum.I find myself no longer looking for items or clues. No longer reading the scribbles of madness upon the walls of reality. The only emotion left in my numb heart is the feint hint of offense such a beautiful landscape has been defaced with graffiti. I do not even ponder what three eyed creature lit all of these candles I find in the caves who’s luster has long since been lost to boredom.. Wait! Yes dear Esther! I do long, oh do I have such a longing! Like a mopey drunk clinically depressed lemming swimming at the bottom of a glass of whiskey chasing Xanax bars that promise his salvation from this world he was thoughtlessly forced into, I look to the radio tower. Perhaps it would offer gravity enough acceleration to break more than my femur? Perhaps it would serve as more than a muse to my desire to return to my desktop and take a nap? Would my feet be fleet like yours Mercury? Would they dash from the highest point of that tower and deliver me to my sweet liberation of this beautifully rendered travesty?No, they would not. As I plummet to the sweet portal of freedom clad with granite below, I open my arms and smile a sweet smile as light hearted as a opiated ferret in a warehouse filled with small reflective objects that look as though they are valued highly by someone else. But a mere instant, an infinitesimal point in time before I reach Nirvana, the laws that govern our physical world of frozen energy take a 90 degree bend and hurl me over a miniature representation of the Gulf of Mexico ,filled with symbolic paper boats of discarded waste.Dear Esther, I am not even greeted by credits. Only the need to push every button on my keyboard until I find the magic one that allows me to end this game without having to tab out to task manager.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												Dear Esther ReviewThis game is boring.This is a personal review, meaning if and how I enjoyed the game.  Although I give a blue thumb up I really didn't enjoy it.  It does deserve a thumbs up becuase it accomplishes what it intends to.  However that goal is simply boring.  I'd have more fun reorganizing all the loose files and documents in my room (which I really should get to), or you know, playing a better game.The first user-defined tag for describing Dear Esther:  Walking Simulator.  Really?  Us gamers are so afraid of lifiting our asses off our couches and seats we need a walking simulator?  Your character literally does nothing but walk around the whole game (and swim through water a few necessary times).  By walking I mean a crippled grandma kind of walk.  There is no picking up items, no environment interactions, no switches to flip, no vehicles to control, no jumping, no weapons, nothing.  Just press forward and walk where you need to.As you move forward there will be narration by a British guy.  I just finished the game and still have no idea what the hell he was talking about.  I don't know if it was the character you are controlling, someone who has been at the island before, if he is talking about someone who has been left back home.  There are messages on the walls here and there but they are so blurred and hard to read that I started to completely skip them at some point, having lost interest.  If I wanted a story I'd read a book.I'm not joking when I say I started to fall asleep playing this.  I kept having to jolt myself awake to trudge through.  The character you control walks horifically slowly.  Like, if you go into prone position in Call of Duty and go forward, even that speed is faster than what you control here.  If it is supposed to simulate normal walking, it fails miserably.  Though I haven't checked and really don't care to, I don't know of any achievements or collectables or anything.  Supposedly there are ghosts that wander around and you can see them but I'm certainly not playing again for that.I'll try to say good things about Dear Esther.  At least the soundtrack is good.  Of course the good parts only kick in every so often.  The rest of the time you'll be hearing minimal undertones of music or just plain wind and waves ambience.  It is more of an art than a game.  But it's a boring piece of art.  It's like if I present to you a nice painting, but chances are as much as you like the painting you don't want to stare at it for ten hours.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Okay, before getting quick conclusions of my thumb down I suggest reading the whole thing 'cause I'm aware I'm writting a subjective view of the game and I'm sure that some of you will like it...... but that's definately not me. As you may have read already from here, this game can be called a "walking simulator" since ALL you have to do is walking through an island while a voice is reading some sort of diary on the journey. It's ok, I do not always play videogames to have a dynamic gameplay. After all, I strongly enjoyed games like Walking Dead or To the Moon, and they're not that far from this main idea. It's not the fact that you don't need to do anything in order to beat the game. It's the story itself. I might not be clever, but I haven't understood a single damned thing once I reached the credits. But anyway, I played this game with my girlfriend who enjoys these kind of "conceptual-persona-ultra-indie video games" more than me, and she was very confused too. I like complex stories where you might even need to surf the internet in order to get the whole thing, but... A WHOLE GAME!? I had to check EVERYTHING on the net to ensure myself that this game makes some sense. When you reach this point of "personal game" I'm not sure it should go on the public market. And after all, the story wasn't good at all. I believe that the ending itself was improvised since I've seen that not even the developers could give a proper explanation to that. The only nice thing you can rescue from this game is the graphics. Maybe. I wasn't surprised at all 'cause... what developers doesn't use that software?In conclusion: this game is 2deep4me. I enjoy difficult storylines but this was totally out of the context. Hopefully some of you will find its beauty because I really wanted to like this game.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Pretentious purple prose spoonfed to you by a posh prick as you plod along a path between set pieces. Some people claim that this game's strong points are the elements of exploration in an unfamiliar place. The exploration though, is half-baked at best. It seemed like every time I tried to explore some intersting place in the enviornment, I was blocked by an invisible barrier and forced to slowly mosey across the landscape back to the predetermined path laid out for me.When you finally make it back to your designated walking route, your faceless british narrator will reward you by dryly reciting fragments of a series of letters written by him to Esther. Do you remember the people in high school who thought of themselves as poetic geniuses as they wote about their unique experience of angst. Remember how they tried to use a thesaurus to make sure they used the smartest-sounding words? Dear Esther's writers were clearly impressed with him, and made sure to imitate his style as they wrote this game.One of the things that bothered me the most is that, at no point in the entire game did I feel like I had any agency. I felt like my entire role in the game could be filled by a piece of metal weighing down the W key. There's nothing wrong with non-interactive storytelling, but it's not a very good choice when the very medium you're using has the unique enefit of interactivity. It's like if you went into a movie and fond out that the film you went to see was a motionless black screen with the sound of a british man reading a copy of "Atlas Shrugged." It's certainly "avant-garde," but I wouldn't call it brilliant or enjoyable.I feel like I need to say that I don't hate walking simulators in general, if only to appease those who say I'm just not "patient" or "sophisticated" enough to enjoy the genre. I also feel  that it's ridiculous that some reviewers have turned to these low blows against others for the sake of this game. I don't think that people should have to "prove themselves" before their opinions and criticisms are valid.Dear Esther is not a game to be played and enjoyed. It's a game to smugly discuss and mock those who are just too simple-minded to really "get it."

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Dear Esther is, quite simply, the most beautiful and moving game I have ever played. You can feel the bitter ocean wind from the moment you step on the island. Every step of the journey is masterfully detailed and filled with the depressing personality of the island. The story may be confusing at first, but it's overwhelming and engrossing. The music is brilliant, and the caves are beautiful. The story snippets are also randomized, and there's an alternate ending, so be sure to play it more than once.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Not so much an interactive game as an exploration into tragedy, loss and grief told through one man's journey across a desolate, Hebridean island. Dear Esther is more like a form of slow and very intentional interactive art, akin to viewing a captivating painting where you're suddenly allowed to step inside the frame and experience the scene in its entirity as you desire rather than be confined to just one perspective.The story is conveyed in fractured pieces of spoken memory of old letters - or possible delusion - and left to the player to construct for themselves as different readings are presented at specific points along your journey, the semi-random nature of these readings meaning multiple playthroughs are required for them to be fully imparted to you.Touching and visually captivating in equal measure, Dear Esther is a brief yet nonetheless poignant example of how the medium of gaming is more than capable of producing beautiful and contemplative works that can provoke great emotion, backed by a strong musical score setting the perfect wistful tones to accompany the bleak isolation and inward reflection of the journey. If you have the interest and willingness to explore such things then this will reward you greatly.

												Dear Esther is an excellent demonstration of the immersive storytelling virtual worlds can achieve. It combines magnificent visuals, a subtle, yet powerful soundtrack and stellar voice acting to tell a very touching story that explores darker themes like regret, grief and loneliness. It does so with a certain ambiguity which leaves one to ponder and theorize about the meaning of what has been witnessed long after the end. It is an impressive experience, but one I imagine not everyone can enjoy.

												10/10Unique and contemplative game oozing with atmosphere. If you prefer action, don't buy this, there is no fighting and no enemies.
