number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												IMAGINATION DELUXEIt is not often we gamers are presented with a slow paced adventure story. Most of the time, our games are about blowing up stuff or travelling to other galaxies, in "Dear Esther" we are forced, no - compelled, to follow the path of an unknown protagonist, and it is quite a nice adventure, if you dare to explore your own imagination.As we walk slowly towards a flashing beacon in the distance, we find clues here and there about previous encounters with the island we are on, and the narrative (a male voice), is seemingly addressing a woman who he is quite fond of.Most of the time the wind is our only companion, and the vegetation of the island. Sometimes we feel the presence of "something", but we are not sure what it is, and more often than not, we turn around to see if we are followed, only to realize we have to go on, no matter what..."Dear Esther" is a short, visual novella, that will keep you enticed for an hour or two, but the real experience comes after you are done with the game, and you are left to wonder about three things:1. Is there life after death?2. Can shadows fly?3. What is dream and what is reality?Of course you will never get your answers, but you will still ponder about them.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Dear Esther is an aesthically pleasing, story-rich experience that is thoughtful, beautiful, and intriguing. It's not something that everyone is going to enjoy, as it is less a game and more of an exploratory journey used to deliver a narrative. The term 'walking-simulator' has been dealt out to ths particular genre of games and, while I don't really think that term is useful, it does attempt to give define a tag to apply to these games that offer its players more than just a wandering quest to complete. What Dear Esther offers its players is a contemplative work of art that left me thinking about the game for a few hours after completing it. It's graphics, voice-work, music, and writing all colate into a fine design that is worth taking your time to experience.I think that if I played too many of these games too often, or consecutively, I would grow tired of the genre as a whole, but they are something that I enjoy partaking in on occasion, and it's the same enjoyment that I find in reading a good book. The player awakes on an island and is left to their own devices to explore though there is a 'correct' path that will reveal more of the narrative. There are some interesting hidden elements in the game that are quite creepy, and the package as a whole is very well done.I'd recommend this game for those who want to enjoy an interesting and well told story within the interactive medium of a game. You won't find challenges, or riddles, or enemies to overcome, only a story that you can walk around inside at your leisure, discern yourself, and leave you to contemplate afterwards.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2013
												Well, is this a game? If so, is it worth playing?To be honest: I don't know. Is it groundbreaking...I don't think so.Yes, it is a very nice way to tell a story, the grafics are very nice, the caverns are astonishingly beautiful, then again we are talking about a static world here, so it should look nice. The audio is spot on most of the time, the music, especially the piano is great.The narrator is just awesome.Unfortunately the story he tells is not. Basically Dear Esther is as if someone tells you a story and you can look around in the story he tells you.It is entirely linear, one has no option of interacting with the world whatsoever.It is intriguing and creates a nice atmosphere, but the story remains very very vague, nothing is explained, don't expect that some "truth" is unraveled in the end.Also I did not quite like the poetry-style of the narration, but that is a personal opinion. It does somewhat fit the whole situation though.Summing it up I would say that Dear Esther would have worked very well as the mod as which it started, but not as a full sized game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2012
												Starting off as a humble source-mod in '08, and later evolving into a wonderful and visually stunning gameplay experience. Dear Esther is a thought-provoking poetic ghost story of sorts with a powerful narrative and beautiful scenery that push the source engine to it's full granduer while still keeping the system requirements at a reasonable standard. As your journey across the island continues questions will arise, who is this man giving you such a compelling story? Am I playing as him or the Esther, the game's namesake? Who is that translucent robed figure dissapearing behind the rocks? Eventually these question increase in depth, which I refuse to share here as it would spoil the experience. While it is slow-paced and has a replayability factor of 1 or 2 times, Dear Esther is highly compelling and should not be missed, unless you have the attention span of a gnat, in which case go chase butterflies.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2012
												While I discovered the Half-Life mod that was the original incarnation of this game many years ago, I did not own Half-Life, so I never got to play it. I'm glad I didn't."Dear Esther" is something that must be experienced this way. Stand alone. On its own. With some of the most staggeringly beautiful environments I've ever seen in a game, big names should stand aside: this game is pure visual emotion and poetry.Gameplay within "Dear Esther" is almost completely nonexistent. While some may say this declassifies it as a game, or makes it unenjoyable, I beg to differ. There is gameplay, alright; however, the gameplay is completely existential. To 'beat' the game is to uncover the story of Paul and Esther. To unwind the metaphoric and symbolic clues, to decode what we see and to piece together what we hear from the beautifully-written narration.I knew exactly what this game would be like when I saw it, and I loved every second of it. If you're a 'thinker', you'll love it too.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This is not a game. Not even close. It is pretty much what most generic brown game companies aspire to be, in that there is no gameplay, and the player has no choice in anything. He is put on rails, and walks around a boring, deserted island at a speed a paralysed man would be shocked by its lack of speed. The slow speed combined with at least 2 paths to most places means that more often than not, you end up going back the same way you came, and only notice after 5 minutes of drudgery, as the landscape is essentially the same throughout, apart from a few obvious bits. This 'game' is essentially made by someone who likes making models, and a guy who likes writing stories.Gameplay: -10/10Story: 5/10Ambiance: 2/10Can't really do any other scores, as there is nothing else to this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Recommended.  You should pick this up at some point and play it.Dear Esther is several, wonderful things.  I found it most enchanting as a (fairly limited) exploration simulator, harkening back to my times as an young man navigating and exploring the nearby woodlands.  Further still, it reminded me of many games I had played before (many games of the Zelda series and also Skyrim, for some examples) as the world told a story.  Each item and bit of dialogue was carefully placed to tell a story without words, and this felt like a world that had been lived in.  Conversely, the worlds of Skyrim and Zelda are plagued by gameplay and thus interfere with the exploration and sightseeing.  That's not a bad thing, because those games are not necessarily about exploration.As for the story, I was fairly drawn in.  I think the author(s?) do a great job of being vague and mysterious, giving little bits of information here and there, allowing you to form your own story as you progress.  It was quite entertaining.As a game, though, I have to say Dear Esther really isn't one.  It's an interactive experience, for sure, and it allegedly is slightly different each time (rng) but other than that it's not much of a game.  Regardless, play it.Play it now.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Beautiful game. Absolutely beautiful prose, narration, music, art. If you like literature or are even vaguely artsy, I want you to play this because not enough people understand how beautiful it is. Complex, rich parallel storyline that can be interpreted both figuratively and literally. ~English major intensifies~ Not really an English major... but seriously. It's a work of art, and of the highest quality too. If this was a book, it'd be my favorite book. But it's not, because it's meant to be that way, and it's beautiful that way. The narration, the vagueness, the art -- the interaction of music, visual art and story is what makes Dear Esther great. Really, it's all the beautiful complexity of literature... made interactive. I'd wish for more like it, but I don't see how prose that beautiful can be recreated or surpassed. Sorry. I felt the need to rewrite this review after Steam evidently erased it. This is one of my all-time favorite gifts.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Dear Esther was a title I followed quite closely the minute I had set eyes upon it (this review is quite horridly delayed in it's making and I apologize). It's incredible visuals had me drawn to seeing what it brought to the table, and sadly, it falls into a style of game that will constantly be picked on and labelled, pretentious, trying too hard or as a simple walking simulator. All of this could not be further from the truth. This is the kind of atmospheric game that has to be experienced and sampled. It is not for everyone, and that is completely fine. If lack of game-play makes something bad for you, steer clear of this. The storyline been a bit hazy, is actually done in such a way that makes it powerful and one of it's best qualities. The story conveys itself in a series of audio messages of a person who ended up on this uninhabited Hebridean island, listening to a series of voiced-over letter fragments to a woman named Esther. The narrator's identity is not specified, (Personally his voice reminded me of Richard Burton) though there are many suggestions that he is Esther's husband and that she died in a tragic car accident. He constantly references Esther, Paul, Donnelly and Jakobson and as you continue on it becomes more blurred as the game progresses, the narration moves between topics and relates the characters in different ways. The random selection of voice-over parts causes ambiguity opens up a lot of doors for the player to draw their own conclusions of the how this story ends up playing out. My take on the story is that this un-named protagonist lost all of his companions after somehow ending up on this island, some to infections they simply could not heal, some committed suicide, and some failed at escaping. It's unknown as to who or how many people were there previously, as the structures around the place lead me to conclude that this has happened before or that the people that were constantly refered back to made all of them. The last living piece of the puzzle is Esters husband.. Perhaps he had slowly gone mad and gone to the top of the aerial to kill himself and join his fallen friends. Moving on from that however.. The scenery and the music create such an incredible peaceful feeling. The environment draws you to it with it's beauty, making you stop just to admire it, or at least it did with me. I love the entire feel of this game as a whole, it's something new that we have not seen, forming art into a playable immersive form to lose yourself within your alone time, encompassing you in something you want to go from beginning to end. With it being semi-randomly generated, it does offer replay value of 2+ hours, making passes to places you may have missed before and in doing so end up finding more hidden dialogue as well. The opposing bit to that is that this only offers a max 3 hours of play, is sadly very short, but that by no means makes it bad. It is more of a story than an actual game as it offers nothing interact-able, other than just walking, listening and enjoying the land in which you travel across to get to the end.I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys simply.. enjoying art, story and a stunning environment in which to do that in.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Dear Esther is designed as more of a storytelling experience than a gameplay experience. You walk around, looking at the environment around you and listening to narration. This isn't an inherently bad design, but Dear Esther just moves too slowly. You move slowly and there is a lot of time between narrations where you can only walk forward and look at the only-partially-relevant environment. You end up spending most of your time not doing much of note and just waiting for the next segment to come up. The story, while decent, doesn't manage to pull the whole thing together. The way the story is told makes it hard to get very invested, and the story feels very disjointed because the narration and relevant environments are spread so far apart. Worst of all, the gameplay elements (walking and looking around) don't enhance the story at all because there's nothing to draw you in personally and the only thing the gameplay seems to allow is looking at things from different angles. Overall I found Dear Esther to be extremely dissapointing. It tried to be a story-driven experience that used gameplay elements to enhance the story, but it completely fails at doing so. You're better off doing something else with your time.

												Went into this expecting some kind of Myst ripoff and I got an "interactive" movie instead. The narrator speaks cryptically about everything making what little story there is here very convoluted (randomization doesn't help the situation either). Dear Esther functions on intricate set pieces and music to keep your attention away from all the other problems with the game, like the fact it isn't a game. I'd be OK "playing" this if I got it in some Humble Indie Bundle but $10 for a remake of a 1 hour mod using the Source engine is ridiculous.The only reason I'm not slamming this for being the pretentious hipster garbage that it is is because of the subject matter at hand. Otherwise this game would be totally overlooked and reveiled for being what it is: another overpriced, misleading, pretentious "indie" game.

content:

												Walking simulator is not a game in common sence, attitude is different, you should defenetly play it if you want to walk or meditate in some way, not if you want to intertain yourself.+ Graphics are great. Colors are amaising. World is beautiful and interesting to explore.+ Sounds in game are great too. Wind and water and caves are very immersive.- A drunken electrician was hired to draw meaningless alcohol molecules and electric transformer schemes through the island. There are graphically beautiful sometimes.. but that is so lame.- Level designer need to be emprisoned in a bounding box forever. Immersion is breaked by invisible walls everywhere, you cant explore the world freely, you can only use paths that someone designed for you. - There is no way to shut up faceless storyteller your are forced to hear. He tells you a lot of pseudo-literary ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and a lot of redundant information you do not need to hear at all. It will be much better if this content was optional in form of letters you can read by your own will.- Music is not so great.Soo.. you should defenetly buy and play this game to delight yourself with beautiful world and cold tundra island immersion trying not to be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off by bad game and narrative design decisions at the same time.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Dear Esther is not for everybody. If it was a movie, it would Oscar bait. It's beautifully shot/framed and has great sound editing and mixing. It is not a summer blockbuster AAA type title. Dear Esther is best consumed while in some state of inebriation to add to the experience. The story is haunting and unique, giving it excellent replayability. Yes, it is a 'walking simulator,' and you should know this going into it. However, that is not a negative if you know what you are getting yourself into. If an artistic, atmospheric, story driven walking simulator with a top tier soundtrack doesn't sound appealing to you, don't buy it. If it does, you will not be disappointed.

Complex, rich parallel storyline that can be interpreted both figuratively and literally. ~English major intensifies~ Not really an English major... but seriously. It's a work of art, and of the highest quality too. If this was a book, it'd be my favorite book. But it's not, because it's meant to be that way, and it's beautiful that way. The narration, the vagueness, the art -- the interaction of music, visual art and story is what makes Dear Esther great. Really, it's all the beautiful complexity of literature... made interactive. I'd wish for more like it, but I don't see how prose that beautiful can be recreated or surpassed. Sorry. I felt the need to rewrite this review after Steam evidently erased it. This is one of my all-time favorite gifts.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Dear Esther was a title I followed quite closely the minute I had set eyes upon it (this review is quite horridly delayed in it's making and I apologize). It's incredible visuals had me drawn to seeing what it brought to the table, and sadly, it falls into a style of game that will constantly be picked on and labelled, pretentious, trying too hard or as a simple walking simulator. All of this could not be further from the truth. This is the kind of atmospheric game that has to be experienced and sampled. It is not for everyone, and that is completely fine. If lack of game-play makes something bad for you, steer clear of this. The storyline been a bit hazy, is actually done in such a way that makes it powerful and one of it's best qualities. The story conveys itself in a series of audio messages of a person who ended up on this uninhabited Hebridean island, listening to a series of voiced-over letter fragments to a woman named Esther. The narrator's identity is not specified, (Personally his voice reminded me of Richard Burton) though there are many suggestions that he is Esther's husband and that she died in a tragic car accident. He constantly references Esther, Paul, Donnelly and Jakobson and as you continue on it becomes more blurred as the game progresses, the narration moves between topics and relates the characters in different ways. The random selection of voice-over parts causes ambiguity opens up a lot of doors for the player to draw their own conclusions of the how this story ends up playing out. My take on the story is that this un-named protagonist lost all of his companions after somehow ending up on this island, some to infections they simply could not heal, some committed suicide, and some failed at escaping. It's unknown as to who or how many people were there previously, as the structures around the place lead me to conclude that this has happened before or that the people that were constantly refered back to made all of them. The last living piece of the puzzle is Esters husband.. Perhaps he had slowly gone mad and gone to the top of the aerial to kill himself and join his fallen friends. Moving on from that however.. The scenery and the music create such an incredible peaceful feeling. The environment draws you to it with it's beauty, making you stop just to admire it, or at least it did with me. I love the entire feel of this game as a whole, it's something new that we have not seen, forming art into a playable immersive form to lose yourself within your alone time, encompassing you in something you want to go from beginning to end. With it being semi-randomly generated, it does offer replay value of 2+ hours, making passes to places you may have missed before and in doing so end up finding more hidden dialogue as well. The opposing bit to that is that this only offers a max 3 hours of play, is sadly very short, but that by no means makes it bad. It is more of a story than an actual game as it offers nothing interact-able, other than just walking, listening and enjoying the land in which you travel across to get to the end.I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys simply.. enjoying art, story and a stunning environment in which to do that in.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Dear Esther isn't much of a game, there's no challenge or goals involved. All you do is press forward. Literally. That being said, it's only the surface of things. Dear Esther manages to pull off one thing a good game is supposed to have: the atmosphere and it does that so well. The abandoned island reeks with melancholy and it certainly makes you ponder. There were times I could almost feel the wind hitting my face, it's quite an amazing experience in that regard. The tranquility of the island is further amplified by a beautiful sound track by Jessica Curry, I've slept listening to it numerous times. While the occasional dialogue makes little to no sense as a whole, that doesn't by the least bit turn me off from the experience, rather it makes the experience all the more intense, thanks to the terrific voice over work. Considering it is lacking a lot of fundamental characterisitcs of a videogame, it still remains to be one of the best experiences I've had. To put it in perspective, I have replayed that 4 times so far just so I could get some alone time, where as I can mention a bunch of actual games in my library which I've left without even playing them for an hour, let alone completing them. Moreover, I certainly see myself getting back to it yet again, Oculus Rift support would make that all the more tempting. I've certainly become a fan of Chinese Room after this so I'm looking forward to checking out Everybody's Gone to Rapture.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2013
												Right off the bat, this game is not a game, it's an experience. Or a walking simulator. The idea is you wake up on an island that may or may not actually exist as you travel to a beacon in the centre of the island because it's flashing red so why not. If you're looking for a fun game to play turn the hell back because this game doesn't have any, you walk around listening to the monologue of the player character. The only motivation you have though is curiosity to try and figure out what happened, you won’t be saving the world from the combine or any♥♥♥♥♥♥like that here. I have to give it credit though, I was definitely interested enough to see it through to the end, which took me under one hour to reach so this is more of an interactive art thing than anything else.Nothing in this game is set in stone though, you are left to interpret the events and things you see for yourself, so this game and its plot and meaning are entirely what you make of it. Also, many of the things you see in this game are different each time you play. Some stuff you see or hear may not be in other playthroughs so due to the purposefully fragmented and incoherency it forces you to guess for yourself what're really happening even more."It can take up to 6-8 full runs in order to have seen every object and/or event at least once."The graphics and environments are very pretty though and the soundtrack is nice and fitting, lots of stuff for you to see and wonder what the significant of this thing you're looking at is alright I found most of the writing on the cliff walls hard to read and often found myself not listening to half of what the character said because I was inspecting things I found and the 'ghosts'.It's not a scary game in the slightest, it might be a bit eerie if you're a wuss, especially if you wander into a building, but the ‘ghosts’ people talk about are just vague figures you can see from far away that are obviously humanoid but are gone by the time you get there. They're not spooky or unsettling it's more of a "I want to go to where they were and see what the deal is" feeling of interest and fascination. It's interesting, for sure. I'd say it's worth checking out, but would I buy it at regular price? Nah, probably not, especially since it's under an hour in length. Still though, pretty nifty little thing.

												I wish I could somehow find an inbetween option, something better than LIKE or DISLIKE, but in lieu of that, I will err on the side of DISLIKE. The music and graphics are beautiful. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I've got mixed feelings about this one, but overall I do recommend it simply because the environments you explore are so beautifully crafted. I particularly thought the water in the game looked really good. This game is very atmospheric and I can see now that some of the other walking simulators I have played were trying to tap into what this game accomplished. Heck, I think now that Montague's Mount is sort of a rip off of Dear Esther except it was near monochromatic, was poorly optimized, and had annoying puzzles.Again, I am glad I played this game but I can't say that I loved it. Perhaps if I had played this before some of the other walking sims I have experienced, then I would have been totally enthralled by it. Maybe I just got burned out of all of the games I have played that might have been at least partially inspired by Dear Esther. One can only take so much walking around slowly, listening to creepy music/sounds, and trying to understand dreary, non-linear, ambiguous narrative.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2013
												Is this a video game? Or is it a movie? Is it open-world, or do I just keep making the one, correct decision? Is it a horror game? Or am I just paranoid? Am I alone? Or are there others? Is this a drama? Or a thriller? Am I narrating my own actions, or are they the actions of another person? WHO AM I?! WHY AM I HERE?! WHERE IS HERE?! WHO IS ESTHER???!!!! - This game answers none of these questions, but is still ultimately fantastic. 10/10; it's like a movie for your mind that leaves you wanting more.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Do not be fooled: Dear Esther is not a game, but rather an extended quick-time event involving the W-key and a mouse. Any story or message is ruined thanks to an overly vague monologue and a linear grind through a flowery landscape and cavern complex. I've read that some users managed to glean some meaning from this pretentious pile of philosophical rubbish and consumer regret thanks to scouring the landscape for reflected silhouettes and such. I was unsuccessful in that task; all I managed to feel at the end of Dear Esther was the loss of time and money.The Good:- decent graphics- solid voice actingThe Bad:- severely limited exploration- obfuscated narrative that desperately runs away from the userThe Ugly:- the simple lack of activity; no diaries to read, no notes to decipher, no mysteries to unravel (other than "Why did I buy this")

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This "game" is really interactive art. And by interactive I mean you can wander around, there's not anything in the world you can really interact with. As you wander you occasionally get some vague dialogue tells a little bit more about the story. This dialogue is apparently somewhat randomized, but the main story doesn't change, just some of the unimportant details.The graphics are good, especially in the caves. The levels are mostly linear with few side paths and fewer alternate routes, limiting the sense of exploration. The story is intentionally vague and open to interpretation with an ending that shows that the whole island isn't actually real. It goes right along with the interactive art aspect so it's not a negative for me.The big issue with this game that prevents me from recommending it is the price relative to how short the game is. Look at my playtime, that's how long it took to play through with backtracking to see all the side paths. At least I got this as part of a bundle because it's not worth $10, at most it might be worth $2.50 on a 75% off sale, and even then only if you're into this kind of game.

												tl;dr:    Interesting and provoking thoughts, but NOT a game, NOT worth money.Dear Esther is an artistic work, I cannot deny that, but the creator lost all right for respect and credit when putting this up for sale. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Dear Esther﻿.  I'm feeling sorry for myself so listen to my drivel.  Too soon?  I had heard all these amazing things about the game and had been waiting for a chance to play it.   Finally had some time this evening...Anyway, stop reading now (SPOILER ALERT) if you ever plan to play this game.  Ugh, I know ... I know.... I'm supposed to be moved... and maybe it makes me a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... but quit the pity party.  If your life really does suck so much, go devote your time and energy to making the world a better place ... volunteer at a soup kitchen or something.So disappointing to find a game that initially heartens with beautiful rendering of the British coastline (a place so much like so many places I've hiked) only to find that 45 minutes later I am so utterly disappointed with a glorification of suicide.  Was that supposed to be a surprise ending?The only surprise was that it actually ended so predictably. Sure, it's "original" for a game... but not for poorly written angst that you couldn't get published in book form... about on par with the works I had to read by classmates in the creative writing class I took in college. If only they had enabled SHIFT-W and allowed me to run, then I'd have only wasted as 20 minutes of my evening instead of 45.If it is any consolation, it seems the rest of the team was extremely talented, but if this is what passes for "games as art", we're doomed.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2012
												It is hard to describe Dear Esther within the confines of regular video game conventions. A first-person exploration of a deserted island, snippets of text by a narrator who may or may not be your character, and a goal that defies the established rules of accepted gameplay. You do not play Dear Esther - you experience it. A supremely beautiful work of interactive fiction, at once heart-breaking and heart-warming, Dear Esther is a sublime masterpiece that dares you to come out of the voyage unchanged.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												In this game (where some may not even call it a real game), there's no actual gameplay other than you controlling where the MC walks around the island. While walking, you reach certain checkpoints where the narrator continues the story. It's a very short game (takes about one to two hours to complete, though you can spend a lot more just looking around) as there are only three chapters to the story. In each chapter, a large tower with a red, blinking light at the top is always visable and is seen as sort of a goal to reach in the game. The graphics on the otherhand are amazing. You get to explore crystal cavens and beaches with lanterns as well as many other cool places. I found the game to be very calming and relaxing and while it is very slow paced, it was very enjoyable and time well spent. Another thing: I would wait for Steam to put it on sale. Normally, it's around ten bucks, but I got it half off. While it's an all around beautiful and stunning game, you only receive around five hours (depending how much you actually explore since I clocked in about seven hours) of gameplay, I feel it's not really worth the ten bucks. If you can get it for less though, I would say go for it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												If you go to my profile and check out the list of games I own, then you should know that I love games with stories. If the game itself has more of an interesting plot, than gameplay, there is a good chance I'll take a shot at it. I've played games like Myst and Ether One so I know how these games work. Limited interacting with the environment, "show" more than tell and vague story telling before getting the point of the story.I'm all for that.But Dear Esther, unfortunately, has none of those qualities.And I tried, really I did. You can see above that I've played this game for up to an hour. But unfortunately I just couldn't get into this game at all. The game's plot is that of a man roaming an island moving from one place to the next while a narration plays explaining details of your situation. And that's it.Now that wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing if both what you're watching on screen and what the narrator is saying, corresponded to each other. But the thing is: they don't.At least nothing was there that I could see right off the bat. I'm ALL for deep storytelling, but the writing in Dear Esther is so heavy and so meticulous that it comes across as pompous. You just don't get a feel at all for what's happening to your character or whoever Esther is. I really wanted there to be a "hook" to this game, but there just isn't one. Nothing that grabbed my attention.Another problem comes in with the fact what gameplay you have is very - not limited necessarily - but "unimportant". With most visual games like these, what you "see" is what tells the story. But Dear Esther's island is just ... bland. Nothing here that's unique or at least nothing that you see here gives you any clues at all to what's happening. The house you enter, the cave, the beach, the lighthouse or the plains... all of it has nothing that adds to what is going on and has been done many many times before.Not only that, but the dialogue CHANGES with each play through. So you won't be listening to the same thing every time. I assume that each variation of the script leads to the same place at the end. but after roaming around for a good ten minutes, painfully slow, not finding anything and then deciding to quit for the day, only to replay with a new read of what was happening... was just discouraging.I love these types of games. And I REALLY wanted to like Dear Esther, but I can't recommend it to anyone. The dialogue and game feel so distant from each other, and to reach the ending of either conclusion just never felt like time or energy worth spent.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I only played it for 7 minutes, but not because it was bad.I was physically and mentally unable to continue any longer than that.This is by far one of the scariest horror games I have ever played. The oppressive, eerie atmosphere completely wreaked havoc upon my senses and I was too terrified to go anywhere. I took a few steps in various directions, but I ended up cowering in fear and returning to the start each time. I just mentally couldn't handle going out into the strange desolate landscape that surrounded me. It was a very fascinating and horrifying sensation.Never in my life have experienced that kind of fear before.10/10Probably the best horror game ever made. THIS is how you do horror. You don't rely on cheap jumpscares. You create tension with the environment and suspense, and create an atmosphere in which the player feels absolute terror that they refuse to even move.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												*TL;DR: Gorgeous, eerie, and mesmerizing experience, but not for everyone. Pretty short. Only controls are arrow keys - literally a walking simulator. No manual interaction. However, if you like this sort of thing, it's awesome. I thoroughly enjoyed it. I would say don't play this when you're in the mood to "game." It's more of a passive, story-based experience.*This is a beautiful, story-heavy walking simulator. Some people would argue against it being considered a game. You pick up bits and pieces of a mysterious, unsettling story as you explore a lonely British isle. The scenery is breathtaking, especially in the cave segments. The story is strange and immersive, seeming more convoluted and dark the more you find out. The order of story segments that you hear depends on the paths you take. The game can be replayed, taking different paths until you unravel the story. Encountering certain locations trigger bits of the plot to be revealed. The narration is solid and the soundtrack is haunting.

												A very beautiful game, but a very boring one in my opinion.  I kind of knew what I was getting myself into from what I've heard about the game.  I was hoping to be surprised, but alas, I was not.The game is narrative heavy and is very vague and cryptic. The cavern segments in particular were very pleasant to play through.  And even though I didn't enjoy it, doesn't mean that somebody else won't.  The short length, in my opinion, justifies at least one play through even if this isn't your cup of tea.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												The game starts with some guy (the guy I'm controlling, maybe?) rambling on about a shipwreck. I look around a bit, and I see a house just up the path. As I enter it, the game automatically turns on the flashlight despite having literally no other controls for me to do other than walk and look. Seems like they could have let me do that. Anywho, the house was devoid of anything meaningful. Okay, well, that's just the first place, and I literally just got here. I shouldn't expect them to reel me into something interesting so quickly. You know, like a well-written story.So I continue up the path to a cave, and I start babbling about a legend of some guy in the cave. Awesome, but I wonder why my flashlight did not come on this time. Maybe it's supposed to be dark because something sweet is going to happen. I reach the dead end of cave expecting...something, but alas, the cave, too, is empty. The narrator/internal monologue/crazy guy talking to himself finishes the story with something along the lines of "like everyone else, I suppose he deemed me unworthy." Ha, I get jokes. Well played, game. You totally got me.I turn back to my beachhead, at a casual stroll, of course. There is no run button either. Just walk, look, and what I like to call "squint," because it's kind of like a zoom, only not really. But I leisurely walk down the beach, wondering why there are no footprints in the sand. I guess not only is Jesus not with me today, but also I can levitate. Am I a Jedi? They can fly right? Oh wait, I'm thinking of David Blaine. That guy is legit.I spot was appears to be a drawing in the sand. I study it for a minute, but like most artists, the elusive Sand Blaster is not going to be appreciated in his lifetime. I suspect it is actually a map of sorts, seeing as there is what appears to be an arrow swooping down towards...something...from the main part. I become wistful for a minimap or compass, or the ability to do anything, but I resign myself to pushing onward.Further up the beach, the voices in my head mention finding the ship's manifest amongst some paint cans. I remember seeing those in the house. Did I say the house was empty? Well, I lied. It did have empty paint cans in with all the other debris. I feel terrible for keeping such a vital detail from you. Forgive me? Sweet. You're the best. I <3 you. But the manifest! Surely that will have some pertinent information. I don't have an inventory, nor did I actually pick anything up, but the voices in my head would not leave me hanging...I reach the end of the beach. There is a rocky creek of sorts leading off the beach, but I can clearly see that goes nowhere. I look around in every direction. Another dead end, it would seem. Plus, the voices in my head have gone silent. They didn't even enlighten me as to what was on that rad manifest. Bummer. I guess I should walk back to the start again...Suddenly, I find myself overwhelmed with a desire to walk into the ocean and end this waking nightmare. To silence the demon of boredom in my head. I step into the water and feel a sense of relief. I keep going at my usual sprinter-on-tranquilizers pace. Steadily the water rises to eye level, only to stop. Ah, such are the invisible walls of existence that keep us eye-level with the sky and the texture-less blackness below, with the soothing sounds of dunking your head over and over again. Much like the juxtaposition of my zoom/squint button, I find myself drowning but not drowning.I stare off into the ocean abyss and contemplate the decisions I've made with my life.10/10, would play for 9 minutes and uninstall again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												In recent years, there has been a notable rift in video game styles. Some excel, some flop, and some are financially successful despite their quality. This rift nearly always has to do with "story," which is integral to game success. Story is necessary to establish timeless association, connection with a game. This is why games with good story release well-received and remain well-received.Now, story must be visually presented in a video game. Retro games prove that absolute best resolution isn't necessary for good story. At the same time, however, poor visual presentation will cloud and possibly ruin the story. They must be in tandem. Now to my point. Dear Esther provides both visuals and story in extremely fine beauty, and sets you free to explore it. Set against moody oceanic weather, open to explore the island, and surrounded by Jessica Curry's haunting, exquisite soundtrack, this is an experience you'll never forget. Storytelling comes in a whole new fashion here, and I absolutely loved it.If you don't enjoy first-person exploration games, or narrative-driven games, this might not be your cup of tea, but I would suggest watching the trailer, and if you like what you see, please play. If not, the soundtrack is available separately, and is definitely worth listening to in full.My only criticism of this game would be that it seems too short. I was finished in about 2 hours, and for some it would take just over an hour. There is new narrative to find by replaying, and I will definitely do it again soon, but I wanted to stay immersed in that world much longer.There is no adult content of any sort, that I have run across or heard mention of, or violence. The only reason I'd suggest it for 16+ years is that anyone younger would have a difficult time understanding the story. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												A calm journeyDear Esther is not your typical video game. It is a game that is a clear definition of 'art', not focusing on gameplay but rather other elements such as sound, graphics and story.Story is complicated, yet deep. You play as an individual who is stranded on a mysterious island. As you wonder the island you get to listen to the narrator, who gives some insights about the island and characters. The overall story is left quite vague and can be interpreted in different ways.Gameplay is left to be desired. You start off on a shore of an island with a house in front of you. There is no guide on which direction to explore the island as you basically move from one area to the next. There is limited interactions with objects around you in certain scenarios, however most of the gameplay reveolves around walking and exploring the island. To its defence, the limited gameplay makes the player take in the music and environment around them.Graphics are beautiful. Seriously, when you play this game your going to want to take lots of screenshots. The environment looks incredible (especially the caves) which clearly shows that plenty of care and detail went into creating it.Audio is fantastic. Using orchestrated pieces, the audio creates a calm and relaxing atmosphere, which helps you enjoy the sights. The narrator's voice acting is good as well.If you want to play a relaxing game that is not about winning as it is experiencing, Dear Esther is your game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I hate myself for this, but I can't recommend Dear Esther.  It is undoubtedly gorgeous and atmospheric with achingly beautiful environments and haunting music, but essentially feels very pretentious.To start at the beginning, this is not a game, it is a piece of art.  I am happy with that as a concept and bought it as such.  Sadly, it is limited by both elements of its design.  It is too steeped in its artistry to make a functional game, but also has enough input from you to detract from the artistic experience.  The main problem is that there are some fairly open areas that allow a modicum of exploration - there's nothing to find, or even really see, but it's still exploration - sadly you move incredibly slowly and the path is necessarily linear.  If you happen to walk in the wrong direction, it feels like an absolute chore trying to get back to where you need to be.  I know it's not meant to be "fun", but it it can feel broing.Nonetheless, I wouldn't have minded but the first time I played it I was called away and exitted the game after getting to the second part of the game.  The start screen suggested that I would be able to start from there the next time I played.  No.  I assume you can only choose were to play from once you finish the game.  Well, I only wasted 25 minutes.  Not a problem.  The second time I played, I got into the cave system (an amazing looking part of the experience!).  When I tried to cross a little stream, I got stuck in the scenery.  That was that.  I had to start from the beginning again.  Truthfully, I couldn't sit through it and just Googled a synopsis and watched a video on YouTube.By no means is this experience bad in itself, but I couldn't recommend it to the average gamer.  In fact, I could only recommend it to a very specific type of person, and I don't even know who that would be.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Obtuse and morbid, Dear Ester is not a game for those looking to spend their evening doing anything other than crying into a pet's fur or a friend's shoulder. Initially, the protagonist's ramblings were obfuscating and enigmatic. As you explore the island, however, it is clear that his problems run far deeper than a death wish. If you have any empathy at all, this game will make you mourn. For better or worse, it is essentially a monologue with pretty scenery.Pros:Beautiful sceneryQuirky, poetic protagonistDevastating endingCons:Quirky, poetic protagonist who likes to hear himself talkYou must roll with the protagonist until he starts to make sense (if he makes sense at all)Not a game to play if you've felt depressed at all within living memory

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												I'm not entirely sure what I expected from this game, other than the rather negative reactions I've already seen from it. To start off, I'm not at all against games that are story-driven, though it's as if this game tries way too hard to prevent the player from learning what the story of Dear Esther is. Mystisism can only go so far, and while it worked in games like The Legend of Zelda or Myst, this one is simply dull and uninteresting.There's nothing really motivating you to go on other than the fact that "the game is short and I should beat it because I have an hour and a half to spare". Personally, I just set the walk-speed to Gordon Freeman's speed and lessened the game about a whole hour by doing so - but do you see the issue there? The only thing making this game about an hour and a half long is the walking speed, and it's not worth the trouble. I understand that some games try to be deep and meaningful in their stories, but this is just crap. The Fibonacci spiral has nothing to do with the story, and you're going to be lucky if anyone catches the whole gasoline and alcohol chemical diagrams by the end. If you're trying to be cryptic, then make it so that the average player can understand. This is not exactly something that the common player will know off-hand, and with that, the story of this game becomes null and void.Some games make up for a horrible story with their gameplay, such as Doom, Far Cry 3 and Duke Nukem 3D. All of which work better without a story, as those would drive the game down as a whole. This game, however, has hardly a story to begin with, yet forces the player to simply hold down W for a good hour and a half. There is no gameplay here - and I'm not asking for much. Myst was a heavily story-based game that included logic-based puzzles and a secluded, mysterious atmosphere. The puzzles and exploration are what made that game a game, and it felt satisfying to logically find the answers to said puzzles. This game, has no gameplay whatsoever: no puzzles, no combat, no characters. Nothing. There's nothing motivating the average player to beat this game other than "it can be beaten in two hours", and anyone with a job or an active social life might just be appealed by that aspect alone, though it's two hours that could've been better-spent somewhere else.Much like Gone Home, this game has a great, eerie atmosphere that is gone to waste by the overall boring gameplay. The story isn't very good, and it really doesn't have much of a reason to play it more than once. There's no way I could recommend this game less to anyone.

												I highly reccomend NOT buying this game. I play on a mid-range computer, and by the second chapter it was too laggy to carry on. Despite this, there is nothing to do in this game. It just sends you around a boring island with some graffiti around it with the slowest walking I have found. It also punishes exploration. For every time I said "Hey, can I go there?" the answer never changed from being no. The tone is all over the place, too. I couldn't tell if the island was barren or had been sprawling with life at some point. If you want the story, I'd read it with all the fragments put together, on a Microsoft Word document or something.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2012
												I wish I would trust my pessimistic nature more: It would have saved me ten bucks. If you're looking for a video game that uses exploration and narration to tell a rich and deep story? You won't find it here.While beautifully rendered and wonderfully narrated, Dear Esther just doesn't tell a real story. It uses its environmental beauty to keep you interested on whats a rather short railroad with little actually offered to explore, and attempts to use both scientific symbols and religious references to the journey of Saul to Demascas to make whats a rather straightforward and simple story seem deeper than it really is.A lot of potential wasted here, sadly. Playing Dear Esther will just make you wish it'd lived up to be more than what it was, even given its humble indie background. They just didn't take advantage of what they could have.

The movement speed is painfully slow and there is basically nothing that moves other than a seagull and the environment; think flowing water and grass waving in the breeze. After reading some community feedback and thoughts, there might be more to the game than I realized and certainly there are all kinds of interpretations to make, but there is absolutely zero chance that I'm going to trudge through the four chapters of this game again just to see some extra car parts strewn onto a cliff face and hear a few different lines of dialogue.I can't recommend this game, it was simply too boring to be worth the $10.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												If you like walking simulators that don't let you interact with the environment in any way at all, you'll like Dear Esther. If you want to feel underwhelmed and maybe a little confused when you get to the end of the game, after doing nothing but walk the entire way, you'll like Dear Esther. At the end of the game, I was left bored and a little disappointment. A beautiful environment I could do nothing with except look at it.  It was like a shiny new toy on a shelf, and I am a child that can't play with it. I wanted to explore but there was no reward for doing so. I spent what felt like ages exploring every nook and cranny, all for nothing. It wouldn't have taken as long if I didn't keep getting stuck on the environment.It has a great soundtrack, though.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2012
												Dear Esther is filled with great ideas that would spell success for any major blockbuster, but falls short because only a few of those ideas were clearly thought out, and most poorly incorporated. Among Dear Esther's strong points are the lovely music and the beautiful graphics, some of the best I have ever seen. Howbeit, Dear Esther holds serious mechanical issues. While I am a huge fan of storytelling in video games, this plot is too thick and is impossible to follow. I was intrigued by the store page, but I finished this game more confused than when I started it. I'm still not sure who I (the controlled character) is, not to mention the moody narrator and only slightly Esther herself.  The best I can say is if you want a guided tour through beautiful terrain, this is a good game for you; otherwise, bounce some ideas around with other players on the plot and see what they think. Dear Esther is not a bad game, just shaken, not stirred.

												Just finished this "game" because it was on my list and I'm trying to clear out my backlog. My intention was to not be too harsh when reviewing it, until i loaded up the game page and noticed that price...I wasn't expecting it to be any more than a couple of dollars, and even at that price point i don't think it's worth it. The game itself is pretty much an hour long story. It is absolutely beautiful, and i can tell there was some time put into the design of the game.That's the sad part about the whole thing though. It could have been so much more. I found myself pretty bored the whole way through, with the exception of a few moments where i thought something cool was finally starting to happen. There was a ghost at one point walking off into the distance, with some other little hidden things and references you had to look out for. I thought these parts pretty interesting, and brought me into the game. However, they simply don't happen often enough for it to make the game worth anywhere near the full price of $11.Overall, i feel my hour would have been better spent doing something else, and that doesn't even take into consideration the cost of purchasing the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Dear Esther isn't really a game, it's an interactive story (although there's not much to interact with). You press the WASD keys, follow the obvious path, and listen to your character narrate bits from a letter as you make your way towards the end. That's it, takes a little more than an hour.Now, the narrated lines from the letter are generated randomly, so if you play through the game multiple times, you'll be left feeling something different each time. Which is pretty cool. Unfortunately, the text relies too heavily on crappy metaphors in an attempt to be "deep." (In my only playthrough, the character talked way too much about kidney stones and syphillis). Dear Esther's only real redeeming quality - the absolutely beautiful graphics - are not enough to warrant a second playthrough from me though.In short, I suppose you might like Dear Esther if you don't feel like doing literally anything for 70m other than pressing the W key and listening to a story that tries too hard as an attempt to evoke emotion out of you. The only emotion it evoked in me, however, was an incredulity that I spent money and time on this.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Some people might call Dear Esther a work of art.  I can understand that argument, even if I don't agree with it.  It's certainly beautiful, and has a story to tell that's quite open to interpretation (as good art tends to be).  But at the end of the day, I can't recommend it, because it's not a game.  Input from the player is totally unnecessary, and it could just as easily have been made as a movie.  And despite the beauty, the trip is dull, with very long stretches of slow walking punctuated by occasional input from the narrator.  Don't bother.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I can't warn people off of this game enough.  I bought Dear Esther a while back during one of the Steam sales for $5 after glancing at the Metacritic score on the side which would lead you to believe this is a great game...I've never felt so cheated out of $5 in my life.  I knew I was in trouble when I brought up the options screen to check out the controls and the only things in the list were movement keys and zoom.  I'm pretty sure the only reason zoom was included was to give the illusion of some sort of interaction in the game and it turns out zoom is a joke since it gives all the magnification of having leaned forward 1 foot.  The "gameplay" involves you holding down W pretty much non-stop the entire time you're in the game while listening to a narrator occasionally ramble words at you that you could care less about.  Things would be marginally more tolerable if there was a run button or an auto-walk button.  But if they let you run, the game would only take 20 minutes, and adding auto-walk in there that would free up your hands to strangle the developers for taking your money, so they wouldn't want that.If you're still interested at all in this thing, do yourself a favor and just watch a Let's Play of it.  It shouldn't take long since it's only a couple of hours long.  You'll end up with the same exact experience of having played it yourself without the rage of knowing you paid for it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												I'm not entirely sure what I expected from this game, other than the rather negative reactions I've already seen from it. To start off, I'm not at all against games that are story-driven, though it's as if this game tries way too hard to prevent the player from learning what the story of Dear Esther is. Mystisism can only go so far, and while it worked in games like The Legend of Zelda or Myst, this one is simply dull and uninteresting.There's nothing really motivating you to go on other than the fact that "the game is short and I should beat it because I have an hour and a half to spare". Personally, I just set the walk-speed to Gordon Freeman's speed and lessened the game about a whole hour by doing so - but do you see the issue there? The only thing making this game about an hour and a half long is the walking speed, and it's not worth the trouble. I understand that some games try to be deep and meaningful in their stories, but this is just crap. The Fibonacci spiral has nothing to do with the story, and you're going to be lucky if anyone catches the whole gasoline and alcohol chemical diagrams by the end. If you're trying to be cryptic, then make it so that the average player can understand. This is not exactly something that the common player will know off-hand, and with that, the story of this game becomes null and void.Some games make up for a horrible story with their gameplay, such as Doom, Far Cry 3 and Duke Nukem 3D. All of which work better without a story, as those would drive the game down as a whole. This game, however, has hardly a story to begin with, yet forces the player to simply hold down W for a good hour and a half. There is no gameplay here - and I'm not asking for much. Myst was a heavily story-based game that included logic-based puzzles and a secluded, mysterious atmosphere. The puzzles and exploration are what made that game a game, and it felt satisfying to logically find the answers to said puzzles. This game, has no gameplay whatsoever: no puzzles, no combat, no characters. Nothing. There's nothing motivating the average player to beat this game other than "it can be beaten in two hours", and anyone with a job or an active social life might just be appealed by that aspect alone, though it's two hours that could've been better-spent somewhere else.Much like Gone Home, this game has a great, eerie atmosphere that is gone to waste by the overall boring gameplay. The story isn't very good, and it really doesn't have much of a reason to play it more than once. There's no way I could recommend this game less to anyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												What's my problem with Dear Esther? DE is the lazy version of Myst and Riven. Myst and Riven also had amazing stories and atmosphere. Can you imagine just walking around Myst and Riven while someone narrates the story without solving any puzzles? DE is made by story tellers -- good story tellers -- that refuse to understand how integrating gameplay into DE can actually enhance the experience and story the way it did for Myst and Riven. DE is lazy. DE is half the experience of Myst and Riven that were made basically 2 decades earlier. If you want to know more of why I have discovered that games like Dear Esther and To The Moon are a diservice to "gaming", read below:To The Moon is an example of a devolution in gaming. To The Moon is an example of video games giving less; degenerating into a worse state than what games have been in the past. Unfortunately, many act as if To The Moon is some revolutionary, innovative experience. It is not. It is the exact opposite. To The Moon does tell a very good (not classic, but very good) story. The story is original, which is more than most Hollywood productions can say. The characters are relatable, deep, and funny at the right time. The dialogue is well written. The plot twists are very well done. The music is remarkable. Yet, as I went through the story, I felt empty. I had this same feeling playing through Dear Esther. Everything I said above was also true about Dear Esther (To The Moon is basically the 2D 16-bit version of Dear Esther's approach). Then I realized why I felt empty.Every positive point about To The Moon I said above -- story, characters, dialogue, plot twists, music -- I had already experienced almost 2 decades earlier in Final Fantasy 6 except that -- FF6 actually had gameplay. And everything I experienced in Dear Esther I had also experienced almost 2 decades earlier with Myst and Riven except that -- Myst and Riven actually had gameplay.THAT is the problem. To The Moon is incomplete and lazy game design. To The Moon did what FF6 (and so many other 2D games) already accomplished in terms of story-telling -- which is fine, but the developer of To The Moon was too lazy or too blind to understand that gameplay is an essential part of gaming (and that gameply can actually enhance the story and experience like it did in FF6, Myst, and Riven). Instead of implementing gameplay into To The Moon that could enhance the experience and maybe make the story even more impactful, the developer chose to just have us walk around the world and watch the story unfold. Can you imagine walking around FF6, watching the story unfold without any gameplay? Without any RPG? That's exactly what To The Moon is. Can you imagine walking around Myst and Riven, listening to someone narrate the story wtihout any puzzles that perfectly integrate into the story and environment? That's Dear Esther.These are not games. They're interactive stories. And maybe if they called themselves interactive stories, I wouldn't be so harsh. But they don't. They stomp their feet and yell they are games. But they are not. They are interactive stories told by story tellers that, for whatever reason, didn't want to be bothered with implementing actual gameplay around their story to make it...ya know...a game. To the Moon and Dear Esther are ultimately empty, half-experiences that do half of what Final Fantasy 6, Myst, and Riven did two decades ago. They are an example of the devolutionization of "games" (HINT: because they're not games).

To me, it is almost as if this game is incomplete, as there is no gameplay, and the story is so disjoint and cryptic I'm not sure it can be called a story. Now I now that some people have their things that they get and they like that few others do. to them, I say enjoy this game then, as I do not grasp what you do about this game. For me, it really does oil down to the sarcstic label of "walking simulator." 2/10

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												To sum my review in one word: dissapointment.I was expecting this game to be like Journey (for ps3) but in fact this is just a walking simulator. All you do in this game is walk (slowly) and thats basically all.Key features section of game page is missleading. (1) "Every play-through a unique experience, with randomly generated audio, visuals and events." - there are no events in this game! You just walk - nothing is happening in this dead island and you cant interact with the enviroment at all. (2)" Explore Incredible environments" - you dont explore sh*t because game is fully linear and your job is to follow that linear path, nothing more. (3) "A poetic, semi-randomised story ..." - there is no story in this game. Only piece of information you will get from game is your characters incoherent blabber (unless that was intended to be story).Another problem is game length - it will take you about one hour to finish it.Only positive thing in this game was the caves level. It is one of the most beautiful levels i have ever seen in a video game.I bought this game on 75% discount but even as such i dont think it was worth buying it. There are games that will give you more fun for the same amount of money.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												What's my problem with Dear Esther? DE is the lazy version of Myst and Riven. Myst and Riven also had amazing stories and atmosphere. Can you imagine just walking around Myst and Riven while someone narrates the story without solving any puzzles? DE is made by story tellers -- good story tellers -- that refuse to understand how integrating gameplay into DE can actually enhance the experience and story the way it did for Myst and Riven. DE is lazy. DE is half the experience of Myst and Riven that were made basically 2 decades earlier. If you want to know more of why I have discovered that games like Dear Esther and To The Moon are a diservice to "gaming", read below:To The Moon is an example of a devolution in gaming. To The Moon is an example of video games giving less; degenerating into a worse state than what games have been in the past. Unfortunately, many act as if To The Moon is some revolutionary, innovative experience. It is not. It is the exact opposite. To The Moon does tell a very good (not classic, but very good) story. The story is original, which is more than most Hollywood productions can say. The characters are relatable, deep, and funny at the right time. The dialogue is well written. The plot twists are very well done. The music is remarkable. Yet, as I went through the story, I felt empty. I had this same feeling playing through Dear Esther. Everything I said above was also true about Dear Esther (To The Moon is basically the 2D 16-bit version of Dear Esther's approach). Then I realized why I felt empty.Every positive point about To The Moon I said above -- story, characters, dialogue, plot twists, music -- I had already experienced almost 2 decades earlier in Final Fantasy 6 except that -- FF6 actually had gameplay. And everything I experienced in Dear Esther I had also experienced almost 2 decades earlier with Myst and Riven except that -- Myst and Riven actually had gameplay.THAT is the problem. To The Moon is incomplete and lazy game design. To The Moon did what FF6 (and so many other 2D games) already accomplished in terms of story-telling -- which is fine, but the developer of To The Moon was too lazy or too blind to understand that gameplay is an essential part of gaming (and that gameply can actually enhance the story and experience like it did in FF6, Myst, and Riven). Instead of implementing gameplay into To The Moon that could enhance the experience and maybe make the story even more impactful, the developer chose to just have us walk around the world and watch the story unfold. Can you imagine walking around FF6, watching the story unfold without any gameplay? Without any RPG? That's exactly what To The Moon is. Can you imagine walking around Myst and Riven, listening to someone narrate the story wtihout any puzzles that perfectly integrate into the story and environment? That's Dear Esther.These are not games. They're interactive stories. And maybe if they called themselves interactive stories, I wouldn't be so harsh. But they don't. They stomp their feet and yell they are games. But they are not. They are interactive stories told by story tellers that, for whatever reason, didn't want to be bothered with implementing actual gameplay around their story to make it...ya know...a game. To the Moon and Dear Esther are ultimately empty, half-experiences that do half of what Final Fantasy 6, Myst, and Riven did two decades ago. They are an example of the devolutionization of "games" (HINT: because they're not games).

												Oh I had high hopes for this game. After playing Gone Home and The Stanley Parable, I was looking forward to playing another short game with a great experience. This is not that game. I hate the term Walking Simulator but that describes this game perfectly. Literally no exploration, you just walk along a path as the game narrates some passages from letters written to Esther. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Dear Esther is an interactive adventure that stands on the edge of what can be considered a "game". The entire experience consists of walking around an island, exploring it, and hearing pieces of a story from the narrator.This is absolutely a game for explorers. Much of the appeal of this game is simply taking in the beautiful landscapes and letting your curiosity guide you. This game is incredibly, ridiculously slow. You can only move at a slow walking pace, and for me, the amount of time it took me to get anywhere ended up discouraging me from trying to do much more exploration than what was needed. The music is nice, and it's appropriate for a lonely island.There's a lot to discover with the story, and Dear Esther intentionally leaves many questions unanswered. Personally, I found the story to be too boring to care about, so I had little interest in teasing out the game's many mysteries.This game is absolutely not for everyone. It's an interesting thing to think about and discuss, but there's little fun to be had with the game itself. The people who enjoy this game will love it passionately, though. If you would enjoy a super-slow, thoughtful experience, then maybe you'll like this. Then again, I normally do, and I feel ambivalent about this game. Don't buy Dear Esther unless it's cheap.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I can't warn people off of this game enough.  I bought Dear Esther a while back during one of the Steam sales for $5 after glancing at the Metacritic score on the side which would lead you to believe this is a great game...I've never felt so cheated out of $5 in my life.  I knew I was in trouble when I brought up the options screen to check out the controls and the only things in the list were movement keys and zoom.  I'm pretty sure the only reason zoom was included was to give the illusion of some sort of interaction in the game and it turns out zoom is a joke since it gives all the magnification of having leaned forward 1 foot.  The "gameplay" involves you holding down W pretty much non-stop the entire time you're in the game while listening to a narrator occasionally ramble words at you that you could care less about.  Things would be marginally more tolerable if there was a run button or an auto-walk button.  But if they let you run, the game would only take 20 minutes, and adding auto-walk in there that would free up your hands to strangle the developers for taking your money, so they wouldn't want that.If you're still interested at all in this thing, do yourself a favor and just watch a Let's Play of it.  It shouldn't take long since it's only a couple of hours long.  You'll end up with the same exact experience of having played it yourself without the rage of knowing you paid for it.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Visually Beautiful but Conceptually DivisiveThe debate centers around not the games quality but it's standing as a game at all. Fortunately for a review there is no reason to wade into this but the reasons why there is a debate come down to the fundamentals of what this game is. Skin deep Dear Esther is simply a story told to as you wander around an empty island, exploring abandon structures and glowing caves.It is important to understand this before playing this game, you will not be physically interacting in any way, this is all about the story.So how is the story? Well, frankly I found it a little pretentious and overly vague but those are things that it uses to draw in some people. While I gained very little from the experience others have found much more depth, including some hidden secrets on the island, and this is where any merit this game has will be. Each time you play the game you will get different parts of the story which is an ok mechanic but in Dear Esther it flounders for two reasons. First of the world doesn't really change in any significant way so visually multiple play thrus quickly become rote, despite the impressive graphics. The second, and related flaw is the dismal movement speed which means way to much time is spent walking in silence. I can not recommend modifying the game to allow for increased movement speeds if you decide to play this game (a quick search will give plenty of results for easy ways to do this).If you're the kind of person that loves digging into and trying to find the meaning in vague stories but aren't looking for the interaction seen in most games then Dear Esther will be something you really enjoy. Otherwise you'll probably want to pass.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that the only way to make Dear Esther playable is to increase the incredibly slow walking speed. First off you need to enable the developer console in the options and then while in game press the tilde key and type in de_playerspeed 300This will increase the walking speed by three times and makes it reasonable, however you will have to retype this command many times since the game will default to the slow walking speed each time it loads a segment.However this is absolutely necessary to get any type of enjoyment from the game, since there is absolutely no interactivity in the game the focus is on exploration, but there is nothing to explore here either and the short audio logs that you get from the narrator are so few that most of the time you're just walking doing absolutely nothing.This game makes the worst possible mistake you can make by trying to create a story focused game, it is absolutely short on story, so the question becomes why exactly would you want to spend your time playing a game that fails at its core element?3 / 10 (with increased walking speed)

												This isn't really much of a game; rather, you walk around an island and are occasionally presented with some befuddling voiceovers contributing to a vague plot.  Good points are the music and the stunning scenery, but since you walk so slowly there is no real incentive to explore - not that you are able to stray far from the set path. You can easily complete the "game" in under an hour, but you'd basically get the same experience by watching a video playthrough.
