content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Imagine playing Skyrim, but without the complex skills/attributes system. Now take away all weapons and armor. Next, remove all NPC's and creatures. Lastly, take all items you could maybe have picked up, and glue them firmly to the ground. Maybe even chop off your own arms for good measure.What's left is basically just a decor, in a game verging on the noninteractive. This is the experience you get when playing Dear Esther.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												If you are intrested in this game, just play the free mod or watch it on Youtube.  This game tries way too hard to be deep and metaphorical, and just comes off as cheesy and nonsensical.  Honesty, I've played through it twice, and am still confused as to what is going on in the plot.  I was lured into this game under the promise of exploring a vast island, and while there is exploration, it is very linear.  I do have to praise this game for its visuals; the game looks especially nice in the cave sections.  In my opinion, I really dislike this game, and if you HAVE to buy it, get it for 75% off. Check out the Stanely Parable instead if you're into this 'genre' of games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I want to love Dear Esther. I want to be one of those people that is moved by the story it tells, that is transported to another world while playing it.But I'm not.Here are some of the reasons why:-There's an unnatural slowness forced onto your movement. Walking fifty feet takes about five times longer than it should. I guess this is to force you to appreciate the scenery, but all it did for me was make me impatient.-The story did not register with me. I was interested, but I wasn't invested beyond "Huh, wonder what's going to happen."...That's all I have, actually. It's not a bad game. I'm not even sure it is a game, but if it is, it's not a bad one. I just don't recommend it. Go play Gone Home or Braid if you're looking for a fun indie game that will touch your soul, or go play... Skyrim? Skyrim has some pretty scenery. Yeah, go play Skyrim if you're looking for eye candy.Or, you know, go for a walk outside. But that's just silly, I guess.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												The graphics are beautiful, the music is captivating and the story is intriguing. Unfortunately, these are pretty much the only thing Dear Esther has going for it. And even then, the story something pieced together from random bits of narration and cryptic items that lay out of place in the environment. I spent about 90 minutes playing this game and then had to stop for the night, right before what I presume to be the ending. Upon restarting the game, I found that I was not given the option to skip ahead to the final chapter (although there is a chapter selection screen). The prospect of playing through the game again seemed like nothing more than a chore. I can't recommend a game I can't bring myself to finish, especially one that doesn't even have any sort of challenges.

A game requires interactivity via mechanics and a visual narrative that unfolds before you to communicate a specific feeling or idea. There is none. 												While the story is interesting at first, it becomes a bit convuluted as the "game" goes on. But, do to its lack of any sort of interactivity, the experience becomes a bit of a drag as the game goes on. While there are some beautiful areas at some points, such as in the cave, due to the repetetive nature of the island, the above ground sections can become monotomous. If you have any interest of buying it, wait untill it is on sale. The game can be beaten in a bit over an hour and there is little replay value.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2012
												Dear Esther is unlike any game I have played. It has beautiful scenery, coupled with an intrigueing story. Sadly, that is all it has. There is no game play. You simply walk along trails, view the amazing scenery, and listen to a story.So in short, if you want to hear a masterfully written story for an hour, whist wandering possibly the most gorgeous enviroments the Steam Engine currently has to offer -- buy it.If you expect this game to be more than simply walking around (Ex. Puzzles, mystery solving) you will be let down. My suggestion is you should youtube the whole game. You get the same story, without the cost.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2013
												Firstly, despite the store page telling you it's a game, it's not. It's a relatively linear short story told as you wander rather slowly along a mostly predefined path across an island. It's short, there's basically no interactiveness to it (I mean there are additional plot elements in the scenery but you can't do anything with them, or even see them clearly quite often) and the walking speed is at times painfully slow. Having said that if you just go with the flow, the story is haunting, the atmosphere is captivating. I'm just left with the nagging sensation that it could have been so much more... If you get it in the humble bundle it's worth a play through. If not, I would probably just watch a play through on youtube.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I never really knew what "walking simulator" meant until Dear Esther.  This isn't a "game" by any definition, but more of a "narrated experience".  There is no open world to explore.  The player presses the forward key and travels along a path until arriving at the destination.  While the path may diverge at some point, it will converge a short time later.The game has a nice atmosphere with magnificent graphics, appropriate sound effects, and some well-done music.  However, I didn't find the story or the locations all that compelling.  The whole experience was also incredibly short--a mere 1.5 hours--and because of this I believe the asking price of $10 simply absurd.  There are many other titles that are interactive and replayable that sell for the same or less.  I purchased this game during a Steam sale for $2 and, in all honesty, I still think I may have paid too much.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Beautiful to look at and killer sound track. However, the ending ruins it. Only buy this if you really don't care about good story telling. The amount of love that went into the visual details breaks my heart because they are incredible. I want to be able to explore this island forever. The story starts out really interesting and contains compelling components that just get left unexplored. The music is wonderful and compliments the visuls perfectly.It's just a bad story and the more the game (I use the term loosely because this is more of just a visual story than somethign you play) went on the less i cared about the main character and his story.I wish this was a bit more exploratory and a bit less cheesy. That's all.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This "game" is really interactive art. And by interactive I mean you can wander around, there's not anything in the world you can really interact with. As you wander you occasionally get some vague dialogue tells a little bit more about the story. This dialogue is apparently somewhat randomized, but the main story doesn't change, just some of the unimportant details.The graphics are good, especially in the caves. The levels are mostly linear with few side paths and fewer alternate routes, limiting the sense of exploration. The story is intentionally vague and open to interpretation with an ending that shows that the whole island isn't actually real. It goes right along with the interactive art aspect so it's not a negative for me.The big issue with this game that prevents me from recommending it is the price relative to how short the game is. Look at my playtime, that's how long it took to play through with backtracking to see all the side paths. At least I got this as part of a bundle because it's not worth $10, at most it might be worth $2.50 on a 75% off sale, and even then only if you're into this kind of game.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												tl;dr:    Interesting and provoking thoughts, but NOT a game, NOT worth money.Dear Esther is an artistic work, I cannot deny that, but the creator lost all right for respect and credit when putting this up for sale. There are many modders out there who contribute much greater, albeit different, efforts for free. Whether intentional or not, putting it up here on steam was awfully misleading and tricked many into buying it, believing it is an actual adventure game. At least everyone I know who bought the game, including myself, sprung that trap.It is an insult to all modders out there that this "game" is being sold. The developers of Dear Esther were thrown a lot of money that others deserve more.

												If you buy this, you will want your money back.  It is a video of a location, that's all.  Imaging a video of a deserted island at night, paired with  portions of an audio book, then chop up the audio book into small non-logical sequences.  There is a mystery story with creepy music, a disjointed and non-sensical story.  However you cannot hear the entire story until you have roamed around this island with monotonous backdrops.  The most exciting thing were the mushrooms in the cave which always pointed at you.  DO NOT buy this game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												It's very much my fault for failing to do the proper research on this title. I was lured by the prospect of searching through elder sites, buildings, and even realms, all the while evading or confronting spectral anomalies, personalities, forces. But I walked into a veritable smorgasbord of monotany with this game. Now it may be surprising for some to find that 'walked' is the key word here, oddly enough. For walking is the only aspect of this game which gives it a first-person shooter feel. One stands upright and observes the world in such a manner. But the interactivity of this world ends there. A story unfolds, but it's all recollection by the player's character and meant to evoke through this speech and a host of visuals one must slog through oh-so-slowly.Walking simulator. That's what this is. And I just don't quite jive with this type of play. Because I couldn't stand the stagnancy of this title I can't say if there is a real theme in the game; man vs. man, or is it man vs. nature?Grab it if you like to feel serenity brought on by an environment laced with subtly charming, vocalized story-telling. I for one can just go meditate. Any and all FPS games I play are gonna have to be rambunctious, energetic, whitty, and compell me to fight for something. This does none of that.Forgive me, I meant first-person shooters...which this is not. <sigh> So as I relive my mistake, please take into account the difference and enjoy. ;)

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												This game certainly has some good writing and the graphics are decently done. But the whole thing is just too vague and small. There’s not much reason for the player to really become emotionally involved with any of the characters because you only hear about what happened with small bits of metaphor thrown around the environment. I don’t feel like anything solid forms before it’s over. It's certainly lacking in substance. Honestly, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a much better game if you are looking to explore an environment and be fed a story. It looks ten times better, has a story which you can follow, and has enough interaction to involve the player in the story. You should spend your money on that instead of this.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												I'm kind of torn by having to choose either 'yes' or 'no' to the question whether to recommend this or not. It's not at all a bad game. It looks nice, it's atmospheric in every way I can imagine, and the story can feel touching or deep. However, it's a very short experience, has very little actual gameplay or replay value, and the story is just a bit too messy for my taste. Maybe you'll like it, who knows, and to an extent, even I did. I think it's too vague.I like writing long texts but I really don't know what else to tell about this. I'd really like to recommend this but at best, I can say that you should experience this at least once. Still, I can't recommend buying it due to its short duration and the flaws I mentioned above. Confused? So am I.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This is a very good technical demo : a bunch of great looking scenery, quite well done voice acting and.... that's it. The game is a walking simulator which lasts about an hour and a half (only because the character you are controlling walks at the pace of a sloth). Things that i wouldn't mind if the game wasn't 8 euros.I didn't even mention the awful writing and story, it doesn't have anything really smart to say and feels very pretentious. The best comparison would be the movie "The Tree of Life". I heard peaople comparing this to the Stanley Parable which it has absolutely nothing to do with, this game is less fun, telling it's (really bad) story in a less smart way, more linear and in the end less interesting.If you see this at 80% off buy it and play it whith your own music in the background just for the visuals, otherwise if you want a game with gloomy athmosphere a good story and actual gameplay just buy Alan Wake.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Buggy!I just spent a few hours in my darkened room with this game and got really pulled into it. The overall mood and atmosphere, the emotions behind the unraveling story... I quite enjoyed it and was in fact so gripped that I even forgot to save, since you can't really die anyway.It was bound to happen, I ran into a glitch. I got stuck between a few pebbles on the beach and couldn't get out again. Eventually in desperation I pressed F7 (fast load)... and had to restart from a point where I had been several hours before! No autosave had been happening in between, even though there were transitions between chapters with loading times.This pretty much ruined my experience and left me nothing but frustrated. Maybe I'll start again but not in the near future. I might just just watch a Let's Play instead, that's safer.My advice if you play Dear Esther: Stick to the laid out paths! Don't try to cross or climb things. And always quick save! (F6)

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												tried to appreciate this game as a 'visual novel', but it really wasnt that enjoyable even if you approach it like that.many of the art assets are reused dozens if not hundreds of times despite not being a particularly large map area. the game is about as visually impressive as skyrim, which isn't necessarily a bad thing if you like skyrim. just don't exepct this to impress you with its modeling.the story comes on far too strong. you couldn't get to the end of the game without being painfully aware of the story without playing blind and mute or being five years old. the game shoves the story down your throat without any attempt at letting the 'reader' discover the story through connections in a natural fashion. instead it is plainly showed to you and later said in blunt words. the game's story treats you like a child. apparently portions of the story are different between playthroughs, but i honestly cant find myself caring enough about the story to actually look at the slight variations.this game seemed to have some potential, but it seems it was made far too simple and short for me to really enjoy. if more work had been put into making the island visually unique (not repetitive mushrooms, rocks, grass, dirt, etc..) and the story had seemed less patronizing i would be willing to call this a good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												The first thing that you should know is that this game looks amazing.  The lighting is beautiful, the water looks great, and the environment has a real character.However, into this world, the designers have created 30 minutes of story stretched into 1.5 hour of gameplay for which they charge you as if there's 10 hours of content.  I mean, think of the games that you can get for $10: Gone Home, Limbo, Trine, Terraria, FTL, Braid, Portal, Binding of Isaac, and on and on and on.There are a couple of niggles with the game.  The path frequently bifurcates, and there's usually no clear or easy way to get from one path to the other.  So, if you're a completionist and want to hear all of the naration, there's a lot of back tracking in order to see everything.  Also, there's a lot of stuff painted onto cave walls and like, but the writing is sometimes nearly indecipherable, so I found myself just ignoring off of it, which detracts from the atmosphere of the game.Bottom line: if you can pick this up for a couple bucks, it may be worth it, but I can't say that I got much out of playing it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Dear Esther﻿.  I'm feeling sorry for myself so listen to my drivel.  Too soon?  I had heard all these amazing things about the game and had been waiting for a chance to play it.   Finally had some time this evening...Anyway, stop reading now (SPOILER ALERT) if you ever plan to play this game.  Ugh, I know ... I know.... I'm supposed to be moved... and maybe it makes me a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... but quit the pity party.  If your life really does suck so much, go devote your time and energy to making the world a better place ... volunteer at a soup kitchen or something.So disappointing to find a game that initially heartens with beautiful rendering of the British coastline (a place so much like so many places I've hiked) only to find that 45 minutes later I am so utterly disappointed with a glorification of suicide.  Was that supposed to be a surprise ending?The only surprise was that it actually ended so predictably. Sure, it's "original" for a game... but not for poorly written angst that you couldn't get published in book form... about on par with the works I had to read by classmates in the creative writing class I took in college. If only they had enabled SHIFT-W and allowed me to run, then I'd have only wasted as 20 minutes of my evening instead of 45.If it is any consolation, it seems the rest of the team was extremely talented, but if this is what passes for "games as art", we're doomed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I'll start this review by saying I do really enjoy games with artistic themes, games where symbolism is interwoven with the narrative and gameplay elements. Games like Silent Hill, Amnesia, or even more 'artsy' stuff like To The Moon are all great experiences which manage to couple symbolism and meaning with effective game design.But in Dear Esther's case, there's absolutely zero gameplay, even when compared to most other art games. It's not just that you can't run, jump, or shoot, it's that you literally cannot affect *anything* in your environment.You can't pick anything up, can't touch or examine anything, and the only things to discover beyond the extremely linear path the game devs want you to travel are vast, empty areas, or occasionally, death. The only thing to do in this game is walk along a set path, listening to snippets of disjointed, over-written narrative that at times comes off like a parody of bad poetry. As for the plot itself, it's really not all that deep or meaningful; once you've managed to dig through the layers of purple prose and forced metaphors, the 'big reveal' is about as anticlimactic and cliched as any you'll see in most games.I know this game gets a lot of praise just for trying something different, and I do admire that, but different doesn't always mean good, and in this case, I'd argue that it was a failed experiment.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												First part is agonizing, looks kinda silly, and just flat out "wtf am I doing?"I was ready to just explore this island, and sniff the flowers, without a real goal.It would be fine if the plants weren't just cookie cut 2d pixlated copy-pasta.If they actually put a model for bags, instead of just painting them on the ground.If they gave me the possability to yell out when I heard a wierd sound, or try to climb a rock, to get to a higher place.The game doesn't even reward exploration, it actually makes you feel stupid for trying to explore.It's just liniar, you walk along a beach, as a guy talks.At least that's what happening so far. But then you get to the second part. You fall down the cave.Now it's like "wow, wtf just happened? Everything is so beutiful all of a sudden", go around looking at everything and getting the feeling in of being in this mystical place.Then you get out of the cave, and it's kinda "okay, what now, I walk along the beach again but at night, walk up the hill, wtf is with all the writing on the wall"And then the ending. It just makes you smile. This satisfieing dumb-happy smile.I still dont really get the story though.The way I understood it, was that main character was the one writing all the things on the walls, and putting all the lights.and he had a friend, who was.. the island itself?In the end he was 'set free' as a bird, and symbolic paper ships that represented the people who had died on the island float around.If I could walk faster, I would play through it again..

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Check your video settings before you start. Mine were set to lower-than-native resolution, with poor filtering, no anti-aliasing, and the lowest shader setting. Whether or not the game experience appeals to you, you'll certainly get more out of Dear Esther if it looks as nice as it can.The game experience didn't entirely appeal to me. I couldn't help feeling impatient with the slo-o-ow walking speed - although this became more tolerable later in the game as the narrator's dialogue clips became more frequent, and as there was more visual interest. I was frustrated by invisible walls that stopped me climbing gentle slopes, and I would have liked more ability to climb over rocks and such (at one point I wanted to climb onto a ship wrecked on the beach, and was disappointed to find I couldn't). It's not always clear where you can and can't go in the game - frustrating, given how long it takes to get anywhere. The constraints on my ability to move quickly around the map discouraged me from thoroughly exploring the environment - a pity, since I'm sure I missed a lot of dialogue hidden off the beaten track.The narrative was okay, but not mindblowing. Grief is a little humdrum (unless it's yours). The music was nicely ambient; the environment was very pretty indeed - but I didn't really get immersed in the game. My loss, maybe?

												As many have pointed out already, this is not as much a game, as it is an experience. You don't interact with anything or anyone. You just... walk. And the reason why, is that the story is barely understandable. Maybe I'm just too dumb, but there isn't really any red line through the game (except for the walking part). In other games like this, you can pick up things and explore the enviornment in a more detailed way, which adds to the story. I really like "walking simulators", but one thing they need for me to really like them, is a good story. And Dear Esther simply doesn't have one, atleast not one I understand. If you are comfrtable with a game that effectivly is a game made to take screenshots in because of the beatuiful scenery, then this is the game for you... For me, it's not enough.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game is an immersive poem. The randomized narration is reminiscent of David Lynch\'s Inland Empire; both present a mass of disjointed information to you and allow you to unconsciously connect the dots that have been blasted at you. It\'s a sort of sensory overload. And the haunting visuals and gorgeous audio all make for an incredibly atmospheric experience. It must be stated that this is specifically a walking simulator. Not a jumping simulator. Not a running simulator. Not a picking-up-breakable-mugs simulator. This is a walking simulator, and it\'s a damn good one.For anyone who likes Frost or Whitman, this game is worth the money. And the great graphics are not remotely demanding. My laptop lags when I drop a bomb in Garry\'s Mod on medium settings, yet I can run this game at max settings and not sense a remote dip in fps.There are a few things some players may miss. In the game one can see the silhouette of a person standing on the candlelit edge of a cliff. I assumed this was a statue, but upon reaching and later passing that location, I realized that whomever it was no longer was there.It\'s a wonderful, surreal little poem that presents itself as being full of choices and confusions, when really the path one follows is completely predestined (which is a theme the narrator understands, making the game just the right amount of self-aware). If you combine the visuals and controls of Drizzlepath with the narrative style of Serena, you have the wonderful Dear Esther, a game whose price is the same as my rating for it out of ten.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2013
												I loved this game. It is quite a difficult game to classify because you don't really interact directly with anything, you simply explore the island and as you do the story unfolds through the narration. The narration is great because it just tells you fragments of the story and as the game progresses the narrator's distinction between the parts of the story become more blurred but you start to form a clearer picture of the story. The design of the island is fantastic, it looks amazing, it is filled with many subtle details which tie in with the story and it leads your attention through the level without making you feel railroaded. It has surprisingly good replayablility because the narration is semi random meaning which details of the story you get will vary each time. Also the details of the things you find on the island also vary slightly each time. It is not a long game but it is not like any other game I can think of so it is well worth playing.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Was very disappointed with this game - it really does feel like a walking simulator as there is no ability to interact with objects or examine anything of interest. While the music is beautiful and haunting, and the voice actor is emphatic and engaging, everything else about this really falls flat. I am a big fan of artistic games, but to me, this could have easily been a short film instead since there really is no use for you, as the 'player'. When realizing I couldn't actually examine anything, including all the littered items that are spread out around the island, I lost interest. The role you are left with is simply hitting forward and the occasional "don't drown" button. You don't even have control over your flashlight.I think art in the form of video games can really make an impact - when done right. This, for me, didn't hit that mark.While I appreciated the 'interesting' ending, I spent more time trying to work out if my computer had crashed than pondering whatever sort of philosphical thoughts it had intended to leave me with.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Big caveat to this recomendation: I would honestly recommend it for the right person.  I just don't think there's many "right persons" for this.  I'd give the game a pretty decent rating, but this area of steam is for "recommending", not about "rating" the game.  I'd rate it good if I could, but that doesn't mean I recommend it (if that makes sense).Once I got over my impatience for slow pace and lack of apparent purpose of the game and just let the experience take hold, it was one of relaxation and interest.  The story is vague, cryptic, and ethereal.  I have a guess as to what it all means, but certainly could be wrong.  Kind of like if you look at an semi-abstract painting and attempt to derive meaning; you may well create your own fabricated meaning similar to or distinct from the artists.  Your are doing a virtual hike, seeing sometimes pleasant, sometimes awe inspiring scenes, while the story unfolds.  I would not call it a great story, but it's OK for one of it's style (previously mentioned).  I think this was one of the early story telling game, so give it props for it's innovation.  I see inspriration from the 1993 game Myst in it, but strip out the puzzles, make moving thorough the world akin to a modern day first person 3d environment, and add in a narrative paragraph from time to time as you walk.  But there are much better story telling games out there.  While you can tell a lot of care went into environmental design, and the other nuances, there really would only have been a small fraction of effort put into the development of this game as similarly priced alternatives.  But the fact that there's really no "game" in this "game" meant the developer took a risk, which is respectible.  It took just shy of 2 hours taking my time and exploring quite a few of the nooks and crannies, but not all of them (while eating a meal).  So back to the recommendation:  - It's a good game, but not for everyone - - It's not really a game, and interactive story - - - It's not really a story, it's just a peaceful journey - It's not as deep as the praise would lend it (to my perception, and the perception of many others it seems) - It's peaceful - There's much better, newer, options for this style of game - The game has a good deal of value from game-history, and gaming-trends perspectives, making it better than a newer option from that standpoint - It's far overpriced in my opinion, but cost is relative to a persons situation - Bottom line: I enjoyed it, but I was in the right mood, and believe I got it on sale a long time ago.  I'm happy with it personally.

After just arriving on the desert island it's clear that something is going on unknown to the player.  The narration starts to craft a story around the setting as we drift from location to location pressed ever forward towards the unknown, a flashing red beacon the only hint of answers in the distance.Dear Esther is a narrative driven experience that unravels itself as the player follows the linear path from location to location.  The game's visuals can still be impressive despite its age and the narration stays strong throughout.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												While the environment is wonderfully designed at places, and the voice actor performed well "Dear Esther" is not a game, it is an experiment. Heralded as the genre creator of the "Walking Simulator" Dear Esther is remarkable for it's graphics and little else. My major disappointment was with the disjointed storytelling. While I understand that the "every playthrough is unique" and "vague plot" were actually design intended, I feel they were used ineffectively. I still don't know what was going on besides an initial car crash. Immediately after completing the game I had to websearch for the plot, which is almost never a good thing (Inception excluded). Besides, I don't know how Jacobsin the 18th century goatherd and Paul from Damascas fit into this story at all, but lord knows there is enough said about them. Certainly would not recommend at the current price point: $9.99.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Dear Esther's single most appreciable quality was to me a very personal one, being the first title I played on my new gaming PC, going back to my roots after years of near-exclusive console play. For this reason alone I deeply appreciated the smoothness of its detailed gloomy environments and overall hi-res graphical performance.However, in retrospect and especially after having enjoyed the far superior Vanishing of Ethan Carter, I wish there had been more variety or better memorable moments. Locations remain dark and monochromatic throughout, lifeless if not for the wind agitating the lush vegetation, with thematic variations for each chapter. The feeling of solitude is obviously intended but it makes the world feel lacking in authenticity or significance.I struggled for nearly a whole hour with the concept that there is absolutely nothing interactive in this title. Within two hours the journey was already over. Player agency is limited to wandering around wholly linearly as a nonetheless intriguing narrator tells a sad tale about a man, his wife, an island, a broken love story and probable death.Nothing to decipher or understand is required to progress, and therein lies its most glaring shortcoming. No real choice to make aside from occasionally going up or down a hill and ultimately arriving at the same destination. Your input is entirely limited to controlling the pacing in between bouts of finely delivered monologue. The only effort required is in the player's interpretation of the story, what it really means, what this whole journey was about.The writing, performance and story are all adequately interesting and pleasantly delivered to make this product feel like an augmented short story or poem, with competent audio and visual support. However, calling this experience a game would be highly inaccurate, which in itself is not necessarily bad though it did come to me as a severe disappointment. Intriguing concept and story, yes, even enjoyable to a certain extent, but unfortunately not very satisfying as a whole in the end. I'd rather read a good Neil Gaiman book to get a more fulfilling dose of mysterious melancholy.To say nothing of the music would be a disgrace as it must be the most notable part of the experience. Its soothing arrangements and simple melodies accompany the narrative beautifully. Absolutely brilliant work in context.Dear Esther has every right to exist as a viable product. It deserves an audience. It is even good for what it is. I just wish it had been better sold to me to properly mitigate my expectations. Its decent execution leaves me sufficiently curious to see what else developer The Chinese Room does next, hopefully improving on their art form in all necessary areas, but not enough to play it again or recommend the title as is.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Check your video settings before you start. Mine were set to lower-than-native resolution, with poor filtering, no anti-aliasing, and the lowest shader setting. Whether or not the game experience appeals to you, you'll certainly get more out of Dear Esther if it looks as nice as it can.The game experience didn't entirely appeal to me. I couldn't help feeling impatient with the slo-o-ow walking speed - although this became more tolerable later in the game as the narrator's dialogue clips became more frequent, and as there was more visual interest. I was frustrated by invisible walls that stopped me climbing gentle slopes, and I would have liked more ability to climb over rocks and such (at one point I wanted to climb onto a ship wrecked on the beach, and was disappointed to find I couldn't). It's not always clear where you can and can't go in the game - frustrating, given how long it takes to get anywhere. The constraints on my ability to move quickly around the map discouraged me from thoroughly exploring the environment - a pity, since I'm sure I missed a lot of dialogue hidden off the beaten track.The narrative was okay, but not mindblowing. Grief is a little humdrum (unless it's yours). The music was nicely ambient; the environment was very pretty indeed - but I didn't really get immersed in the game. My loss, maybe?

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Worst thing i have ever experienced (in terms of interactive media) in my life. This is in no way a game, it is however an enviroment with a story. A pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥story, with the worst field of view ever.  Never in my life have i gotten motion sickness from playing a game before. even raising the field of view to the max didn't help. I rage deleted this game once, then felt guilty and read online that it only takes an hour on average to finish, so was like what the hell lets just push through the nausia to see what it offers. and i did. And boy was it lame. This game has some pretty scenes, i'll give it that. Again though the soundtrack is so boring. The voice actor has the enthusiasm of a dead leaf that used to exist. Oh and if you think you have the option to turn off the boring♥♥♥♥♥music and listen to literally anything while you walk on this abysmal desolate island, guess what, no music sound slider, just a freakin master volume... The only way i managed to finish this game without stabbing myself is by singing freakin rap music lyrics by DMX, i say this why, well because i'm a metal head and don't like most rap. Why is this important, well its more important because it tells you something about me which is alot more than this game does. And don't get me wrong, i knew it was a walking sim. I knew. And just for another TMI moment i like walking around Skyrim going from one hold to the next without fast traveling just because, and i really did not like this one bit. I think everyone can find a lot more enjoyment in simply going outside your house/building aand staring at your wall as you walk arround it.Note - If you are visually impared, you can play this. However your experience will vary depending on the type of imparement you have. Specifically issues with blind spots, peripheral vision, and central vision. There are things to read and spot in this envirmonet as well though i am not really sure if they do anything to enhance the experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I think that most of all, I agree with the "most helpful" negative reviews, which appear on the front page.  There's very little else that I can add to their points.  I think I could like this game, but the story needs more clarification, and the pacing needs to be sped up; a relaxing pace is fine, but a TEDIOUS pace, is anything but relaxing.  I kind of believe that they made the character walk as slow as he did, because of the lack of content.  As it stands, it's only a couple hours worth of gameplay.  I guess they anticipated people getting through it in less than an hour, but failed to take into account that most players would be more inclined to look at more aspects of the scenery, if it didn't make them ages to get there.  I MIGHT play it through again one day, tweaking walk speed in the console.  But the various drawbacks of the game left such a bad taste in my mouth, that I'm probably going to feel pretty reluctant about it for a while.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2012
												...also known as "Spelunking: The Game". "Dear Esther" is what comes closest to an existential independent interactive film, a true sensorial and emotional cinematic experience, made up by breathtaking views and the most beautiful bittersweet soundtrack. Be aware though: in this Half-Life 2 mod there is nobody to shoot, and the limited moving option (no running, no jumping - only painfully slow walking) could put some people off. Also, it lasts only around one hour and half. This is not a game: this is interactive art cinema.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This is a story game. The story though is up to a lot of interpretation which may or may not be bad. I was a little disappointed at first since you can't interact with anything in the environment and no objective or goal is presented to you. However, it does have a progression, nice visuals and good narration. Although it looks like you can walk in any direction, this is not the case as the map constantly stops you (you can't jump or move things to progress either). This was a little frustrating. It became apparent I had to stay on a partially hidden path which gives the illusion of being able to walk anywhere. I modded the controls (mod from this discussion: https://steamcommunity.com/app/203810/discussions/0/864969481882137563/ ) in order to walk faster because there are some long branches in the path that forced me to backtrack and it was taking forever (because there was no run option). Overall it was OK. I really enjoyed the visuals (especially the caves they are amazing! :)). I wished it was a more concrete story and that it had either given me more freedom to explore or allowed me to interact with the environment. Game lasts about 2 hours.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												A very brave attempt at doing something a little different. I think it was wrong to villify the Chinese Room for what they did here. I mean, come on. Nobody buys this expecting a racing game or a puzzle game, do they? It is exactly what it is. A semi-interactive story which just happens to use the Source engine as a way of telling itself.It is worth playing through a couple of times, partly because the paths do branch in places, and also because the narration does change slightly. Certain text is removed, other is added, and as you replay you will discover a little more about the characters back story and grasp a little more of what actually happened.Maybe I'm a little biased because I have a growing fondness for Scottish islands, but I think it's refreshing to have something a little different than usual. Movies aren't interactive, but we don't condemn them for that. Why should something like this be held to the same standard as "Gears of War", which it clearly isn't trying to be. It's just a method of getting the story across, much as how "House of Leaves" played with the notion of a book. We don't write off audiobooks on the grounds that CDs are only for music, so why should a game engine only be used for it's original purpose?"Walking simulator"? Please. Is Call of Duty a "gun simulator"? Actually, don't answer that.

												This is a short story that takes about the same time to tell as a feature film. It's poetic and melancholic. content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												In the meanwhile this genre has gotten a name - "walking simulator". Which sounds a bit unfair and rude.On the other hand you could also call it a 3D-"adventure", just without "real" puzzles nor cutscenes (except for the end) like similar games - the awesome "Vanishing of Ethan Carter" or the rough but very interesting "Homesick" for example.In my opinion it's a 1st person 3D-exploration-game with the "goal" to follow the narration clues that were left behind by human hand - to discover or at least guess the story behind this mystery-experience that will lead you across a beautiful, melancholically deserted island, underlined by a fitting wonderful soundtrack that will last in your ears and mind.However - be prepared for a rather sad story! I would not recommend this to depressed people. Yes, this game will merely make you walk SLOWLY (for a reason!) across a landscape to explore one scenery after another (including beautiful caves), will let you find stuff and signs left by.... someone ;) - and will make you listen to bits of the story, one after another, until you will reach the end - very literally. It made me cry.Oh, besides: luckily I did not stumble over any bugs :) This game has been published in 2012 after 2 years of development. So of course in the meanwhile it has gotten a bit outdated. The experience is still overwhelming, but after everything I have been playing ever since I would have wished for a small update-patch later on including at least a few small "real" Myst-like puzzles to solve on the way, a bit more unique details thrown into the sceneries - and the option to walk - or limp - at least a little bit faster. Also the story-bits are sometimes a bit too forcefully "mysterious" and a little off from the start instead of getting more and more confused concomitant to what the notes and narrations say, which I would have clearly prefered... I would not wish for "enemies" to fight though, nor NPCs to talk to on this abandoned place speckled with ruins and rusty remains of people who have long left the place. I also do not miss any stuff to collect nor an inventory at all for this kind of game.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												I just spent 46 minutes playing this game, thinking it was a mere 15-20, and I am amazed.Never before, have I played a game that was so beautifully designed graphically nor story-wise. There is no interacting with anything in this, nor is there any point to doing anything. All you do is walk around, and yet I spent 46 minutes walking around a deserted island, and I'm not even done with the first part.Yesterday (February 16, 2014) I purchased this game - with others - via HumbleBundle, and I have never been so satisfied with the purchase of a game. It's so... I'm grasping for the right word... poetic.I loaded up this game not knowing what to expect, and have been thoroughly surprised by what I received. If I could hug the developers and simply sit in silence with them, I would do so.Before you buy this game, though, make sure you can understand a complex sentence... some things are said in a slightly cryptic manner, and you actually have to pay attention to what is being said, and how it is being said.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game is an immersive poem. The randomized narration is reminiscent of David Lynch\'s Inland Empire; both present a mass of disjointed information to you and allow you to unconsciously connect the dots that have been blasted at you. It\'s a sort of sensory overload. And the haunting visuals and gorgeous audio all make for an incredibly atmospheric experience. It must be stated that this is specifically a walking simulator. Not a jumping simulator. Not a running simulator. Not a picking-up-breakable-mugs simulator. This is a walking simulator, and it\'s a damn good one.For anyone who likes Frost or Whitman, this game is worth the money. And the great graphics are not remotely demanding. My laptop lags when I drop a bomb in Garry\'s Mod on medium settings, yet I can run this game at max settings and not sense a remote dip in fps.There are a few things some players may miss. In the game one can see the silhouette of a person standing on the candlelit edge of a cliff. I assumed this was a statue, but upon reaching and later passing that location, I realized that whomever it was no longer was there.It\'s a wonderful, surreal little poem that presents itself as being full of choices and confusions, when really the path one follows is completely predestined (which is a theme the narrator understands, making the game just the right amount of self-aware). If you combine the visuals and controls of Drizzlepath with the narrative style of Serena, you have the wonderful Dear Esther, a game whose price is the same as my rating for it out of ten.

This is a sort of game set in it's own category due to it's game play, and for sure this game play is NOT for everyone. Not every likes games that just have you explore your surroundings and listen to the story being told. But I'll tell you this is great in the respect of the story and exploration being told! That is what drives this game and it's what the folks over at the Chinese Room are wonderful at doing! So if you like games that involve more play and less story, then this just isn't for you.Now this game itself is about our unnamed player who came to the island to remember things that happend in his past. You get to learn about why he is at this island and about this "dead Esther" whom he speaks so much about. This game will draw you in from the vast island's sceanery and the brilliant dialogue. Soon enough this little "game" will draw you in to where you just want to know the whole story it's trying to give, even if it can be a bit uncomprehensible at a few moments, but you'll soon pick it back up into understanding.All in all, this is a very unique and interesting game and if you really want to play, but feel unsure about it, just wait until it goes on sale (That's what I did), and I'm sure you'll either be satisfied with it or not mad that you spent too much on it.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												I just spent 46 minutes playing this game, thinking it was a mere 15-20, and I am amazed.Never before, have I played a game that was so beautifully designed graphically nor story-wise. There is no interacting with anything in this, nor is there any point to doing anything. All you do is walk around, and yet I spent 46 minutes walking around a deserted island, and I'm not even done with the first part.Yesterday (February 16, 2014) I purchased this game - with others - via HumbleBundle, and I have never been so satisfied with the purchase of a game. It's so... I'm grasping for the right word... poetic.I loaded up this game not knowing what to expect, and have been thoroughly surprised by what I received. If I could hug the developers and simply sit in silence with them, I would do so.Before you buy this game, though, make sure you can understand a complex sentence... some things are said in a slightly cryptic manner, and you actually have to pay attention to what is being said, and how it is being said.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Dear Esther was my very first Steam 'game', and I think it's time to give it a review.First of all, this isn't a game, it's 100% a walking simulator. Some people see that as a bad thing, but this just shouldn't be a game, being a walking simulator fits the best. The narrator has a perfect voice for this experience. As you walk on the island, the narrator tells you a vague story with sometimes long pauses. You really have to pay attention to the narrator to understand the story at the end, he will make you question a lot. Who's the narrator? Who am I? What is our relation? Just try to discover it for yourself during your walk on the beautiful, haunting island. The atmosphere is breathtaking, it's cold, grey, haunting and just beautiful. Just like the visuals and the landscapes. And I almost forgot it, but it's very important: The music, it's beautiful and fits so well! I still listen quite a lot to it because it's so beautiful.If you like a walkingsimulator with a great story and great atmosphere, then this is a must-have! And even if you're not a big fan of walking simulators but you do enjoy a good story and it's on sale, I recommend it for you. If Dear Ester is your taste, you'll get suck into it and you will really think about it.Perhaps it's just because this was my first game ever, but I'll always love and appreciate this experience a lot!

YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Dear Esther 

			Views: 9		

			After just arriving on the desert island it's clear that something is going on unknown to the player. The narration starts to craft a story around the setting as we drift from location to location...		

After just arriving on the desert island it's clear that something is going on unknown to the player.  The narration starts to craft a story around the setting as we drift from location to location pressed ever forward towards the unknown, a flashing red beacon the only hint of answers in the distance.Dear Esther is a narrative driven experience that unravels itself as the player follows the linear path from location to location.  The game's visuals can still be impressive despite its age and the narration stays strong throughout.

That being said, Dear Esther is a gorgeous experience, telling an engrossing story with grandiose visuals without ever leaving the trappings of a smaller, more intimate tale. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Cannot believe this game is only in the 70 percentle. Epic, epic experience. Sadly I think people came in expecting something else and that has tarnished this game's place in history.Basically, the game is just one long screen shot. In the best way possible. Let me explain...This is the epitome of a walking sim people. But in a good way. This is not a game to play when you want to scratch that action/strategy/puzzle solving gaming itch. This is a game to play when your mind is racing from a stressful day, you can't seem to relax, and you just want to shut down for a bit but still be alive...you can either go get a professional massage or play Dear Esther (and this is coming from a massage therapist).I'll start with the soundtrack, which is nothing short of incredible. I could absolutely listen to it all day, and honestly it would be great to play as background music for my work (again, in a good way). Then you have the writing, which is superbly superb. Some of the metaphors used are just...brilliant. Pulitzer winning stuff, honestly. It's a bit over the top at times, but then again, so is Dickens and Shakespeare (big time).  Graphics are...perspective based. If you zoom in on a little leaf on a small vine, it does look flat and pixelated (and I'm fully maxed on graphics). Water is translucent and wishy washy, occasional pop ins but not too bad.. But again, this is not a game to compare to other games. It is not about that. It's like comparing Myst to Call of Duty. It is literally an experience. If you're able to look past the minor details and at the entire picture, the game looks stunning. Anywhere you look, literally, is a picture perfect screen shot. What you see in the images above can literally be taken anywhere. This is what I mean by one long screenshot. It really doesn't matter where you're looking, wherever the mouse ends up, you'll be left with this beautiful and serene island, lost within itself as an eerie expedition into what happens when a dying human conscious becomes lost to mother earth.The story is....well, it isn't really a story driven game, imo. Even though the description and some reviews say so. Again the snippets of writing here and there are beautiful, but it is very fragmented, mostly scattered anecdotes that are triggered and vaguely correlate to what you might be looking at. I do believe it's intentional, so again it's a matter of perspective. Basically it's more of telling you a story of what happened, instead of the story that's happening now. I personally see this game as a stress reliever, so I'd be ok if there was literally no story at all, it's simply that kind of game, but what is given is intriguing enough to keep you interested.But, that pretty much sums it up. Isn't it great? No faulty mechanics, no annoying enemies, no expectations for a story, no camera issues...just pure nothing in the most beautiful way possible. I don't think this game has anything in it other games should emulate (other than good writing and sound design). It has no ground breaking mechanics or visuals. Yet, it is completely unique and if there is a follow up I hope they don't change a thing.Highly recommended....IF THIS IS WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR!!! AGAIN, IF THIS IS WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR!!!9/10 would stare at cave entrance for 10 minutes againPS For those who DID think this was something else, I think you might be more interested in The Solus Project. Very lonesome and surreal, no enemies, but there is a survival aspect involved as well as some light puzzle solving. Also a great game, but it requires you to stay on your toes. Dear Esther simply asks you keep your eyes open, and IF THIS IS WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR, it does not get much better..

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												A very brave attempt at doing something a little different. I think it was wrong to villify the Chinese Room for what they did here. I mean, come on. Nobody buys this expecting a racing game or a puzzle game, do they? It is exactly what it is. A semi-interactive story which just happens to use the Source engine as a way of telling itself.It is worth playing through a couple of times, partly because the paths do branch in places, and also because the narration does change slightly. Certain text is removed, other is added, and as you replay you will discover a little more about the characters back story and grasp a little more of what actually happened.Maybe I'm a little biased because I have a growing fondness for Scottish islands, but I think it's refreshing to have something a little different than usual. Movies aren't interactive, but we don't condemn them for that. Why should something like this be held to the same standard as "Gears of War", which it clearly isn't trying to be. It's just a method of getting the story across, much as how "House of Leaves" played with the notion of a book. We don't write off audiobooks on the grounds that CDs are only for music, so why should a game engine only be used for it's original purpose?"Walking simulator"? Please. Is Call of Duty a "gun simulator"? Actually, don't answer that.

												Dear esther is a nice little artistic game. It wasn't what I was expecting and I'm sad that it was so short.There aren't any puzzles to solve (well directly) and it's really an experince. I could see someone being annoyed at the end when the controls are taken over from you but that's part of the experince too.Shares more in common with stanley parable then any other steam game out there. This is definitly one of those.If your looking for a puzzle/adventure, try something else like anti-chamber instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Before you buy this game, you NEED to understand what it is.  The entire game is just walking slowly and very indirectly towards a blinking light on the horizon.  There are no enemies or puzzles.  That is not going to be everyone's idea of fantastic game design.  If that sounds terrible to you, well.  Then you don't want this game.  That's totally fine.However, the game does tell a story, and a very good one.  As you explore and make your way forward, you will be fed small observations and recollections which you must piece together yourself.  The story is just ambiguous enough to be fascinating.  It's not inscrutible.  You'll probably have a fairly good grasp of the story by the end if you were listening attentively.  And if you don't, a second loop should help you feel more certain.  (And replaying the game is plot-appropriate in a delightfully subtle way.)The game is also beautiful.  If you happen to have a 3D monitor, you are in for a TREAT.  I really can't stress that point enough.  I left it as the last thought in this review only because I know most readers don't want to hear about that.  This game is almost justification enough for buying a pair of active shutter glasses, though.  Stunning if played that way.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												In the meanwhile this genre has gotten a name - "walking simulator". Which sounds a bit unfair and rude.On the other hand you could also call it a 3D-"adventure", just without "real" puzzles nor cutscenes (except for the end) like similar games - the awesome "Vanishing of Ethan Carter" or the rough but very interesting "Homesick" for example.In my opinion it's a 1st person 3D-exploration-game with the "goal" to follow the narration clues that were left behind by human hand - to discover or at least guess the story behind this mystery-experience that will lead you across a beautiful, melancholically deserted island, underlined by a fitting wonderful soundtrack that will last in your ears and mind.However - be prepared for a rather sad story! I would not recommend this to depressed people. Yes, this game will merely make you walk SLOWLY (for a reason!) across a landscape to explore one scenery after another (including beautiful caves), will let you find stuff and signs left by.... someone ;) - and will make you listen to bits of the story, one after another, until you will reach the end - very literally. It made me cry.Oh, besides: luckily I did not stumble over any bugs :) This game has been published in 2012 after 2 years of development. So of course in the meanwhile it has gotten a bit outdated. The experience is still overwhelming, but after everything I have been playing ever since I would have wished for a small update-patch later on including at least a few small "real" Myst-like puzzles to solve on the way, a bit more unique details thrown into the sceneries - and the option to walk - or limp - at least a little bit faster. Also the story-bits are sometimes a bit too forcefully "mysterious" and a little off from the start instead of getting more and more confused concomitant to what the notes and narrations say, which I would have clearly prefered... I would not wish for "enemies" to fight though, nor NPCs to talk to on this abandoned place speckled with ruins and rusty remains of people who have long left the place. I also do not miss any stuff to collect nor an inventory at all for this kind of game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Pros:+ Intriguing story, it can be regarded on multiple levels of the literal-metaphoric spectrum, very thought-provoking+ Beautiful sceneries (especially after entering the cave)+ Very atmospheric music & sounds+ Interesting map design solutions, it plays with the player's direction of viewCons:- The story is honestly confusing af. It's trying so hard to be poetic, that it often comes through as pretentious. The lack of information and the unreliable narrator doesn't help. Though the end result is thought-provoking, so whatever floats your boat :)- Slllloooow walking speed. Fortunately there are ways to fix it, look in the Guides and/or PCGamingWiki. (Unfortunately I only realised it after I played through the game D: )- The ghost sighting are very easy to miss, the only one I found by myself was the obvious one standing on top of the rock after exiting the cave. According to guides/youtube videos, there are tons more I've never noticed O.o- In multiple points of the map the narration segments triggered are selected randomly from a few possibilities, meaning you never hear the whole story just from one playthrough, which seems kind of a bummer. The game isn't so interesting to play it through multiple times just to hear a few more bits of the story, when they are all up on the game's wiki anyways.- Confusing saving system, I accidentally restarted my game around third-way through because of this.

Posted: October 15, 2015
												I could (and have done numerous times in the past) rant for hours about this game. The most pretentious attempt at a story driven indie game 'experience' I've ever seen.In fact I'm pretty sure they just took a 14 year olds B+ graded English poetry essay and had it read aloud to you very slowly as you're forced to walk around in a dismal, repetitive island made in the Source engine.I understand how for some people who like to do everything they can to find meaningful messages in absolutely everything even when there aren't any, this game must be a joy but I just can't say I feel the same way.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												The first thing about this game, is that it isn't a game.  It is a visual novel which unfolds a poetic narrative at certain trigger points you cross as you walk along a fairly strictly linear pathway across an island, through caves and other sights to see along the way.  The artwork in the game is rather nice, which is the only thing I really appreciated about the title.You basically walk around until you figure out where the single exit is from where you are to whatever is next, and you keep doing this while possibly enjoying the visual artwork, but you can't really interact with anything of substance and you just walk along listening to depressing poetry.  The entire title can be completed effortlessly in 90 minutes since all you basically do is walk along, then walk some more and listen to the poetic story being told.  If it were in virtual reality it might have been a more enjoyable experience amping up the art factor another notch, but it's pretty dull overall if one was expecting an actual video game of some sort as it is not a game.I was disappointed overall and wouldn't recommend it to anyone, unless one greatly appreciates visual art and poetry and isn't expecting to be able to play an actual game where you interact with anything.  The entire experience could just as easily been turned into a 60-75 minute long movie to watch more as an art exhibit.  That being said, those who are into art and poetry may very well enjoy this so long as they weren't expecting an actual game.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												I can't think of the words to come up with a proper review for a game like this. I mean, words by themselves would just be a subjective representation of something that should be experienced. Like a fleeting memory of a long lost loved one, or the recurring pain you feel on a winter night, about the past you want to correct, and a future of mistakes. It's reality in your face, in a world that lives in imaginary wonderlands and facades. If humans just took one moment to see what's in front of them, and truly cherish what is most important, the world wouldn't be like it is today.It's not about Dear Esther changing the landscape of gaming, it's not the somber narrative, or the mixed messages you as the player try to interpenetrate. It's more than that, it's everything you want it to be, and nothing. It can be a silly game with no point, or it can be an important piece of literature. To me, it's what I've seen and been through, it's loss, it's regret, it's sorrow and happiness, and most importantly it's freedom. So yes, Dear Esther is an important piece of work, and it just so happens to come in an interactive format.  Laugh if you must, and mock if you will, but game companies can learn from Dear Esther. It's just too bad, that the masses like shooty shooty bang bang, and sparky sparks go flashy flash.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Short answer:What is this game?   It's like going to an art museum; you walk around and look and listen.  In this game, you are here to observe and nothing else.  Honestly I feel like I could just have watched a let's play on it and gotten essentially the same experience.  It's not unique to me or my playthrough.My meandering impression of the game:I finally got to play it months after all the hype has passed.  I went into it knowing what Dear Esther was about, which perhaps ruins some of the experience.What kind of experience was it?   Perhaps similar to Gone Home, except I really went into that not knowing what it was about and I got to interact a lot more with the environment.Yes, interaction...something that I didn't really get from the game.  It just wanted me to sit, watch, and listen, and I'm okay with that because I knew that this is what it was about...but really I wish they had an auto run button since all I did was hold down the W key as I moved forward.I understand what they were trying to do, but the whole point of the medium is to have the player interact with the environment.  What is created here is a very unique art museum.  Sure, you can download it to your computer, play from the comfort of your home, but ultimately all you're doing is walking around looking at the exhibits and hope that you will find something profound that strikes a cord within you.  I didn't get that from this, sadly.

Posted: August 19, 2014
												What can I say about this game? Well a lot actually. when you start the game you think hmmm this seems like it my be some kind of horror game. Better watch my back. As you SLOWLY progress through the game you realize its not. now when I say slowly if you couldn't tell I meant it in the whole sense of the word. Your character walks like like a sloth through tar and you cant run or pick up stuff or solve puzzles because the only controls are WASD and the mouse to look around. Thats it there are no other controls to the game. So If you thought that this might be some kind of mist tribute like some people I know you are sadly mistaken and I am so glad that I could stop them from buying this game just like I'm trying to convince you to do. But I digress. So back to the actuall game. It runs off of the valve source engine so you can expect what kind of graphics to see in the game only they are about 2X worse some how. The game is very slow, very boring, and very pointless. It shouldn't even be considered a game for crying out loud. And are you ready for the real kicker *******************SPOILER ALERT*******************SPOILER ALERT******************SPOILER ALERT************************** IF YOU ACTUALLY ARE PLANNING ON BUYING THIS POOR EXCUSE TO MAKE MONEY THEN DO NO READ ANY FURTHER THEN THIS POINT BECAUSE I AM ABOUT TO SPOILE THE WORST ENDING TO THE WORST PLOT EVER! SO PLEASE IF YOU WISH TO SAVE SOME MONEY DONT EVEN BOTHER USING THE COUPON ON THIS GAME ITS STILL NOT WORTH IT***************** SPOILER ALERT************** SPOILER ALERT*************************SPOILER ALERT******************Okay so if you've come this far aperently you want to save some money. So here we go. The plot is your character wakes up on an island. No real indication on who you are why you are there or why you should give a f****. As you slowly walk through the game the narrator starts talking about a woman named Ester. Also he talks some other random crap I was to bored to care about. So as you walk through the game you reach this raido tower where he talks about Ester some more and how he hurt her. Then..... are you ready for this? He jumps off and Kills him self. Then its game over. there is no new game plus there is nothing interesting that happens after the credits... its just over. You killed your self. Thats it. In short what do I think of this game. Its crap in its purest form. If you took a machine that could convert crap into computer data that data would come out to be this game. Is boring, unintersting and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (and no I will not apologize for using the R word because this is America and I'm intitled to say what ever I want.) DO NOT! I REPEAT! DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! IT IS IN NO WAY EVER GOING TO BE WORTH THE TIME OR MONEYI'm just so glad I got it in a humble bundle so I only spent about $2 on this and like 4 other games because if I had spent the whole $9.99 they are asking for I probably would have driven down to the studio my self and demanded the money back from the person in charge of making this game him/her self. This game gets a 0/10 from me.

content:
Posted: February 24
												I'm not sure what I think of this walking simulator game, nor its genre. The word game implies fun to me, or at least a challenge. This offers neither of those. You press forward, sometimes side to side, and you "progress" through a narrated story. You can sorta die by falling off high ledges and wandering into the ocean, but it is a inconsequential death. There's no way to save your progress, except you can select from a chapters list to pick some parts of the game. In that way, it's more like a DVD except you have to hold down a button to play it and you can look around 360 degrees. If you're someone who is interested in purchasing and using this product, I'm sure my recommendation is as inconsequential as walking into Dear Esther's ocean. However, having now owned this product for a long period of time now and given my repeated efforts of trying to play it, attempting to enjoy it, yet always failing to feel good about opening it or even seeing it in my library, I simply cannot recommend Dear Esther.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												Dear Esther is attempted poetry in video game form, but falls flat in most regards.----These are the things you can expect when thinking about purchasing this game.The good;  A beautiful classical soundtrack (though somewhat poorly implemented perhaps)  Some pretty cavesThe bad;  Lots of excruciatingly slow walking  A mostly uninteresting environment with lots of no reward dead ends  Some dialogue, most of which makes no sense  An obvious story  You cannot interact with anything or do anything other than walk excruciatingly slowly (you can't even jump)----I'm actually quite a fan of narrative driven games and have enjoyed other "walking simulator" games in the past. Unfortunately this one is neither fun to play nor particularly rewarding. It does have some good moments - the ending makes for a nice visual and a few of the dialogue entries do have merit. I particularly enjoyed the caves which filled me with a feeling of tranquil beauty. But as a whole the bad far outweighs the good and it mostly just put me to sleep.Overall, Dear Esther as a video game is terrible. Dear Esther as a visual and auditory poetry experience is passable, if somewhat pretentious and particularly boring in the early parts.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												I tried to like this game, I really did. But... in the end... it is a poor excuse for a video game and it ends up just a pretentious, shallow, boring walking simulator. I mean this game is nothing. Most video games in general give you a story, characters, world, and gameplay, but Dear Esther thinks "wouldn't it be a revolutionary idea to remove all the story, characters, interactive world and gameplay from our videogames?". And if you argue that it is a "piece of art" as if it is therefore above criticism as a video game my response is "So? That is no excuse, all video games are a form of art, and there are tons of games that are far more artistic and better presented such as Life Is Strange." In the end, unless you have literally never played video games before, don't bother with this one. If you have an urge to play this game, or already have played it and still have that itch you want scrathed (and even if you enjoyed it and think you got that itch scratched), go play Life Is Strange and get your fix of what this game is pretending to be.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												A boring walking simulator. If you actually try to go ANYWHERE off the main path, the narrator starts repeatedly saying "go back" every 2 seconds, so theres nothing off of the beaten path, so you just end up playing through the same exact experience if you've beaten the game and gone back.the only thing to actually look for are the "ghosts" the you occasionally see. The "gameplay" is literally just holding W and turning the mouse, the game doesn't even trust you to turn on the flashlight. The story is nice, but half the time the narration is useless drivel that was added in just to sound deep and philisophical, when really it feels more like a 13 year old desperately trying to be a good writer. The graphics look nice, but theres nothing memorable at all from any of the locations, JUst broing abandoned building on a desolate island. If you REALLY want to give this game a try go try out the FREE half life 2 mod that is essentially the same experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												This isn't a full fledged game review as I haven't finished it yet (and I'm not sure if I ever will), but after completing Anna Extended Edition, I guess I was expecting a bit more from Dear Esther. It looked the same on the outside, but while Anna provided tricky puzzles, chilling atmosphere, amazing graphics and intriguing story, Dear Esther doesn't have anything of that. It's literally a walking simulator with some narrated stuff that doesn't seem to have much in relation to the scenery itself. Granted, the scenery is amazing, calling it just breathtaking would be an understatement, especially since it's running on somewhat dated Source Engine. But paying 9,99€ for a "game" with pretty scenery where all (and only thing) you can do is walk around stupendously slowly is simply not worth it. I got it through a cheap deal so it's not that big of a deal, but as it is, it's too expensive. If I'd wanted a non interactive game, I'd watch a movie or read a book...If it had interactivity with objects, reading story by picking up notes and books, puzzles, in a way Anna was made, then I'd be playing it with highest interest. But the way it is presented, it's not even nearly engaging enough to pull me into the game. Sorry, I can't recommend it. You need a very specific taste to enjoy this game and I don't think many people have that kind of taste. And this is coming from someone who loves adventure and/or exploration games.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												The game was visually stunning. I found myself actually taking a couple of screenshots because of how pretty the landscape was. The story was alright, nothing I would really present as anything more than above average though. The voice acting was good... and that's really about it.I would comment on how the gameplay was, but there really isn't any gameplay at all. You can only walk and kinda zoom in a little bit. There is no jumping, no sprinting, nothing. You just walk, zoom in on the pretty landscapes, and listen to this dull sounding guy drone on about Esther.The story had me interested in the beginning, and near the end again, the middle I find myself overwhelmed by boredom though. I could never see myself playing through this again, other than to maybe show someone how pretty the landscapes are and that's about it.Basically what we have here is still technically a game, but I don't think it needed to be. There is no gameplay after all, nothing to do. It would have been better served as a short story in my opinion.

All in all, what the hell did I just "play"?

												To put it bluntly: this is not a game. I repeat this is not a game. It is something between a Tech Demo and a Short Film. There's no interaction, no cast, no nothing. There's just the (beautifully rendered) landscape and a drawn out purposfully confusing monologue. All very dramatic and melanchonic. Actually too dramatic and too melanchonic, it's as if the authors are desperately trying to rub your face in a big pile of doom&gloom while shouting "Be sad! Be sad ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ it!". It's perfect for emo teenagers or for people looking for a depressing monologue. Just don't pay more than 5 bucks for it.
