number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I enjoy interactive narratives like Thirty Flights of Loving, Dys4ia, Passage, Stanley Parable, (I'll even defend the much hated Dinner Date) but I really, really did not enjoy Dear Esther.The main problem I have with it is that I don't feel like my interaction is vital or adds anything to the offered experience. Yes, I can walk around and enjoy the level design on my own terms but how is this reflexive of any sort of narrative theme. Yes, narrative elements are implemented into the environment, and vice-versa, but if this game were on rails with the player only controlling the direction the camera was facing and the speed of progression would the experience really be that different?If I don't feel like my interaction is important, that it is necessary for me to be a participant, then I might as well be a bystander and observer, in which case this is not the proper medium for the piece. If you're going to make something interactive, it needs to be interactive for a reason.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												About an hour in I fell off the pathway and in between a bunch of rocks that left me completely immobile, no way to move in any way. If there was a jump button I would have been able to continue no problem but Dear Esther is a #seriousgame and what kind of #seriousgame allows it's player character to escape a prison of 9 inch tall rocks? The protagonist of Dear Esther is too morose to climb out of such a fiendish obstacle.It's got beautiful visuals and incredible music, and if the writing were worth a damn I'd probably suck it up and play through that hour again but ultimately I think the writing in this is kind of terrible and nonsensical. It's so ridiculously obsessed with being mysterious and grim that even really basic details about the who, what and when of the story are completely obscured. Goes for evocative, mostly comes back inane. So maybe I was only 10 minutes away from the twist ending where it's revealed he invented the atomic bomb or is a ghost or whatever, but I don't care enough to find out.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												As much as people hype up this game, I can't reccommend it. It has some interesting aspects and interesting points to think about, but is it a good 'game'? Eh.TLDR is at the bottome \/Dear Esther is a game where you walk around and explore. . . sorta. As you walk around, little tid bits of who you are (or might be/just a narrator) pop up and give you a vague idea of the story in the form of letters. Well, read aloud letters. It's pretty neat how the story bits can tie in with what you are spectating. However, exploring can get pretty tedious. If you don't walk into a certain area you don't get the dialogue, or if you back track you don't get anything. Since you can't run, there can be long pauses where it's just you walking around trying to figure out where you should go. There are paths that lead you to and fro with a few other paths leading to new bits of dialogue, but attempting to explore much can lead to lots of boring backtracking through large areas. Going as linear as you can is probably more enjoyable.As far as environments go, Dear Esther has some gorgeous locations. The whole 'game' takes place on a small uninhabitated island, so you're gonna get a lot of ocean and some pretty cool caves to. . . well, walk through. I was particularly impressed with the caves and are by far my favorite part of the game.And the narrative. If you haven't heard anything about Dear Esther, be warned - It can get confusing. Each run can give you slightly different audio tidbits. Last time I checked, some of them lead to very different assumptions on what the story actually is/means. That means with each playthrough, every person might hear slightly different things. That by no means makes this replayable though. There is NO replayability in this game unless you desperately want to see what differences you can get. The enviroments don't change, trecking through each area is a bore after awhile, and the ending does not change. This game is only WALKING and LISTENING to dialogue. I swear if you replay Dear Esther, you have to either be crazy or a dedicated Wiki editor.TLDR; Dear Esther is an interesting take on narrative, but the long stretches between that narrative, ruthless lack of nothing if you dare go off the linear path and explore (expect a few meaningless narrative tidbits), and lack of replayability make this a less than par experiance.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2012
												I would say this is a bad game.. but it's not good enough to be considered a "game".I can barely classify it as an interactive experience. BARELY.I can't call it a game because there is no degree of interaction in it. All you do is walk around (literally) with no interaction with anything what so ever. You do so at a blissfully slow speed as well, which makes the whole experience really tedious and boring. (That, and badly designed "exploration"/ counter intuitive scenarios)The story was very confusing and I can't remember anything about it, it wasn't memorable at all and it didn't catch my attention. It's probably because I wasn't paying too much attention in the first place and because I heard it has a dynamic story that changes every time you play, possibly resulting in less effective storytelling, either way I wasn't impressed.The "game" was marketed and praised for it's gorgeous graphics, however I wasn't really blown away by them. I'm a long time PC gamer and I got to play some games  with pretty impressive graphics in the past... This didn't make it in my top 10. It all looks good in carefully captured screenshots but when you get to play it and look at things from up close you can notice the low quality textures and the grass planes rotating towards you... kind of ruined the "realistic immersion" experience they were going for. All in all, I do not recommend this "game" I don't think it's worth it. I would advise people to watch a "Let's play" of it on You tube, they would get the same experience.I was so dissapointed by this game that I personally mailed steam support to remove it from my library even though I paid it's full price. My library feels less tainted now :)

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												"Dear Esther isn’t a story about you. You don’t stem a tide of Islamic extremism with a semi-automatic AR-15 rifle, you don’t save the Milky Way from a Reaper invasion, and you don’t stomp a bunch of Goombas on you way to save the princess. Dear Esther is a mystery. It’s a ghost story. It’s a historical document you unearth. It’s a first-person explorer, as opposed to first-person shooter, set on a Myst-like island where one narrator’s downward spiral is revealed in puzzling vignettes, rather than revealed by puzzling your way around levers and sliding boxes."- Randy Kalista, "Dear Esther vs The Bible"

												Embarrassingly poor writing, and since this is a walking-simulator style game where listening to the writing is all of the game, without even the minimal interactivity of, for example, Gone Home or The Stanley Parable, florid purple GCSE-standard pretentious pontification like this makes the whole game offensively unpleasant. Mercifully brief, though.

I felt like I missed something and was curious so I read some guides, watched videos, etc. I must say I missed a lot what this game offers. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Don't get caught up in semantics. Whether this is a game or not, I found it to be a profound experience, that would not have worked in any other medium. The island is beautiful, and it as if the story itself is streched out to inhabit the space you treverse. This sense of space, of a story as space, is quite the achievement. Furthermore it does not enforce any persona on you, save the sound of footsteps; the player functions merely as a gaze in this thick space, and is told the story through the poetics of the island itself.The story conveyed itself is hauting, however, it is the form of this conveying, that is central to Dear Esther. The design does not answer any more questions than it needs to for the player to fill in the blanks whith his own imagination. It is dreamlike, but not meaningless, it is mysterious, but not a riddle, it is emotional, but not overwrought. To be enjoyed late at night with a single malt and a pensive disposition.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Dear Esther is one of those games that some would argue is not a game. The mechanics are simple: walk. To people who would make such an argument, however, I would contend that Dear Esther is a shining example of how a game with the barest mechanic can deliver an experience wholly unique to this medium. As you explore the lonely terrain, narration adds context and emotion the experience. The player's actions reflect a relationship with these settings and messages. The game leaves you wondering just what things are at play in the lives discussed. The end is superbly executed. Games like this challenge our assumptions of what games are and how we engage with them. I hope to see more like it.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												A superb experimentation in narration and what defines something as a game. This game isn't for everyone, and you may find yourself wondering why it is considered a game in the first place, but it is absolutely beautiful and fearlessly unique. I can't gush enough about how incredible the experience of playing Dear Esther is (and I've played through it a more than a few times by now). If you like good writing--and the writing in this case far exceeds good in my opinion, and I was a English Creative Writing major--you will love this game. Near perfection in its genre.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												I was initally turned off by this game that offered no guidelines, no explanation, just an island, and lots of drowning. Once I figured out where to start walking I became completely engrossed in the story. Dear Esther has done something in this format that few other games achieve: an immersive and haunting experience that lingers with you long after finishing. It's paced well, but I wish it were longer. 10/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Let me get this out of the way, Dear Esther is ploddingly slow and rather short. There is nothing to do but walk (not run or jump) around an island and listen to a story narrated to you in shor snippets. The story is told in a rather abstract and impressionistic manner. However the island is beautiful, the narration is well done, the prose is interesting and the over all experence is quite satisfying. Given how short it is I probably wouldn't reccomend paying full price, but definitely put Dear Esther on your wishlist and grab it next time it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Well... what to say about this one?It's a walking simulator. There's a sort-of story, doled out in semi-random chunks as you go, which gives you an idea of what's going on... but ultimately, there are no puzzles, things to fight (or do) other than walk along a very linear track until you get to the end.So, this is not a game. It's a glorified demo with some moderately nice graphics. It's eerie, certainly. Atmospheric, definitely. There are some real "Wow" moments as you travel across the area you're in... but it's all a bit grim, and a bit slow... and really there's no point in repeating the process, so once you've finished this once, you're probably not going to want to do it again.If it's cheap, and you're into purple prose and don't like having to mash your mouse-button, then this might be the toy for you. Otherwise, I'd say give it a miss.I enjoyed it the first time around, but purely on the basis of how short it is (less than an hour) coupled with an almost total lack of replayability (for me, anyway) I'm going to not recommend this.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												The game is short... very short... I mean rediculously short, if it let you run through the game it would be over in 15-20 min. I can't really classify it as an exploration game simply due to the linearity of the game; even when there's a split in the road it makes no difference as you're still forced onto the same path.   The game tries so hard to bring you into this immersive experience, but when the only real control you have are looking around and walking around it's quite difficult to become immersed. Basically you'll be finding yourself holding down the W-key for about 2-3 hours, might as well have just had an auto-move key and then the game would have been just one long cinematic. It even turns the torch on for you. There's really no interaction with the environment.   Sadly though the camera work is a serious let-down it glides along so smoothly it just doesn't feel like walking and the lack of arms/legs/torso/anything make it feel like you're just a flying camera. So I don't even think it makes a good walking simulator.    If not for the enivironment artists this game would be unplayable, and they were absolutely amazing. One of the most beautifully created environments I've ever seen and the developers did well to keep it interesting throughout the game.The acting in the narration is very well done but without any decent camera work and game mechanics it doesn't feel entirely connected with the gameplay and as such it makes the plot seem unimportant and instead of filling you with deep emotion for the characters really just makes you feel impatient or apathetic towards the whole thing. If you removed the island and just had the narration the plot would not be damaged.     Basically you play a game as a flying camera which moves very slowly and shoots pretty scenery while a man reads letters and talks about the plot. If the developers put more effort into the player character in terms of movement, interaction with the environment and animation/ character visuals the game would have been a lot deeper and I would probably have recommended it. Sadly though it's interesting but in no way is it worth the $10 price tag.

												Dear Esther is the first game made by The Chinese Room, and it is great. While it's not really a game - more of a walking simulator - Dear Esther gives an interesting world to explore with stunning visuals and a great OST. The voice acting is good, too. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												If there's anything about video games that I'm good at, it's In-Game suicide. I've fallen off of bridges, into crevasses, stepped on traps, landed on spikes, drowned, and immolated myself in virtual reality more times than I can count.Enter Dear Esther. Oh, it's beautiful. I want to go to the Hebrides islands now. There's a cave with all this well-rendered bioluminescent stuff on the walls, and I just want to reach out and--click it.But I can't.Because I can't interract with anything in this game.I can just wander around and listen to some story about feeling guilty and personal demons. It seems to get told out of order depending on where on the island I am, and the random audio snippets I get don't really correspond to the location that I'm at.So, bored with not being able to click anything and listening to this guy carry on about regrets, etcetera, I decide to go for a swim. My character can't swim. I get 'resurrected' back on land.After another half-hour of wandering around, and again getting sick of the narrator's personal demons, I find a giant hole in the ground.In the interest of scientific research, I jump into it.And I get resurrected again.It's like one of those stories about a guy who is immortal and he's bored and annoyed, so he tries to end it all, but just ends up being bored and annoyed with gashes in his wrists because he's immortal and doomed to be tormented forever.So, finally, I find out where I'm supposed to be wandering and what this guy is regretting, and as I climb the aerial tower (SPOILERS!), I'm thinking, "finally, this game is going to let me actually have control over *something*."I get to the top of the tower and scripting takes over.And as my character throws himself automatically from the tower the small part of me that was engaged in this story felt like the ultimate failure.My character had absolutely no control over his own destiny. Every time he tried to kill himself, he got dragged back to life: YOU WILL KILL YOURSELF ONLY WHEN IT PLEASES THE SCRIPT! And when it comes time to kiss the cruel world goodbye, he doesn't even get to do THAT himself.Anyway, my character should rest in peace knowing that it wasn't his fault he hit some lady while drink driving. The script made him do it.So yeah. Effective story telling, just not in the way intended.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												While you play "Dear Esther" you get the feeling you are exploring a work of art... perhaps even a painting.  The music is excellent and harmonizes with the scenery.... perfectly setting an atmosphere that is both haunting and beautiful.  The two main problems with this game (it's not really a game but more of a semi-interactive story) is that you never get the feeling that you are really here, walking around and exploring an island...  You can't interact with the world in any way and I noticed, despite the developers attempt at extreme realistic scenery, there are thing out of place... such as no ripples when you walk through the water and perhaps too many textures of trash scattered throughout the island.  I also had a problem getting drawn into some of the details of the story and characters.  I teach video game design and one of the key elements in a good design is getting your customer to love and care about the characters.  I think the design falters here however by the time you reach the end (which is extremely short, took me only a couple hours) and the plot plays out, you do come away with a feeling of understanding.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Dear Esther is a walking simulator that will bore you to death.A walking simulator needs to provide a compelling reason to play it... it must provide a reason for simply exploring with little to no interaction.  It must provide a compelling story, interesting things to discover and an immersive believable environment.  Let me address all 3 of these points.Compelling story: the story is revealed as you progress in the form of text that appears on the screen, read by a gentleman with an english accent.  It resembles journal entries, but the language is thick with metaphores making it difficult to follow at times.  By the end of it I basically understand the gist of the story but I have nothing to pick up or re-read so I can't go back and review something that I have already heard.  So, for me there was little emotional impact at the end, even though I "get" what is really going on.Discovery: there are maybe 3 different area "types" in the game, each providing some interesting things to look at.  Each of these areas though were not very dynamic, meaning after the first 2 or 3 minutes you have pretty much seen everything there is to see.  There are occasional buildings to explore but there is not enough detail in the interior to make it memorable.Immersive environment: This aspect of the game was most disappointing to me.  A walking simulator NEEDS this above all else.  First of all, my walking speed is very slow, so I am naturally inspecting everything I see.  Close up the textures are terrible and low-res.  Although the game can be played in 3d (all walking simulators need to support 3d) I don't recommend it... the textures appear flat and lifeless in 3d.  The ambient sounds were "ok" but the transitions between areas was often abrupt, and the sounds were not directional.  Also where are the birds and other wildlife?  Insects? Even dreams are more interesting than this.  As I'm walking through the environment I can hear my footsteps... but there is no special noise when I walk through the weeds... there are many examples of this.In the end I'm pleased that this game only took an hour because honestly I would rather be doing something else.3/10

number of helpful: 12 of 27 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												The buildings and areas I explored felt empty and without any real substance.The dialogue in this game, though incredibly well voiced, felt as if without any real merit. It left me more confused than informed. It served as flowery filler to bridge the time voids created by way of the laboriously slow world navigation.The game's biggest flaw is it's most obvious one. After moving around at the most sluggish speed I've ever felt in a title, I decided to discontinue my attempt at progressing through this experience.Allowing for more freedom of movement speed, and making the discoveries and dialogue a contiguous whole would have made this "game" slightly more redeemable.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Dear Esther is not a video game; however, quite what Dear Esther actually is I'm not sure. Viewed as a (very) short piece of prose, it's underwhelming and insipid. Viewed as a piece of (barely) interactive art, it's fatuous and incredibly pretentious.Dear Esther has the air of an attempt to raise the medium of video games to high art, but one which falls short of being either. In fact, what your £6.99 gets you is a short (in the region of 45 minutes) walk along a path (from which you may not deviate) in a Hebredian island, while a narrator reads (purple) prose, and you hold down the ‘w’ key.Plenty of great art video games exist, plenty of great walking simulators exist. However, this is not one of them. You’d be far better off getting The Stanley Parable or virtually any other art game instead.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Pretentious and dull, sorry. I can kind of see what they were trying to achieve and I think companies like Ice-Pick Lodge and Tale of Tales do these things better. This one is pretty much linear so not much chance for exploration. It should've been a short film instead. I did like the visuals especially at the midpoint of the game, it was good-looking... but that's all it had going for it. It's horribly dull (even though it lasts only a bit over an hour on average) and not really that atmospheric and the story with only a slight impact doesn't get any better with the cut-up serving. Then again, at least it doesn't have platforming gameplay like they did in Korsakovia which I hated more. This is a prettied-up experimental mod, not a retail game.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												The protagonist has landed on a hebridean island to reminisce about their lost love, Esther. Guide him through the island in slightly different ways and you'll reveal different parts of the dialogue.The fragments of the story are brilliantly narrated, and leave a lot to interpretation, which just draws you in further.As a whole, this is genuinely beautiful; it can barely be described. It takes around 50-60 minutes but you absolutely must not be disturbed during it.. Don't worry about saving, or any typical 'game' stuff. Just experience it, preferably with headphones and no other external stimulus.You will feel that you understand, but what is to be understood?

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												It's hard to call Dear Esther a game, as the player makes literally no interaction with their environment, all they do is simply walk through it and look around.Every once in awhile the narrator will speak about random things when you eventually reach the next trigger (at a tediously slow walking pace I might add). While this is supposed to help you understand the story, the simple fact is that the "story" is left so incredibly vague that it's somewhat pointless to attempt to figure it out, as there's no right answer. Sometimes this works for games, but in Dear Esther's case, the game does a poor job at getting the player invested in the story, and considering nothing about it is for sure, the player isn't able to piece together some kind of answer like in other vague stories, as you can't rule out any possible conclusion. There are also no meaningful, developed characters in it, rather you're told a collection of names and left to come up with who they could be on your own.The writing reminds me of some teenager trying to write "deep" poetry for the sake of being deep. The narration snippets are told in a boring, artificially drawn out fashion, much like the game itself is. You'll dread backtracking from one of the many pointless, long dead ends so much that you'll probably noclip to get back to your previous location faster.So is there anything good about this game? Yeah, it's pretty, and has a good soundtrack, that's about it. Not nearly enough to justify the $10 price tag. I see this game compared to The Stanley Parable often (which made me look forward to trying this out), but the big difference between that and Dear Esther is that the player's actions actually matter in The Stanley Parable. The player has no purpose in Dear Esther, they're pretty much just moving the camera through scenery for the entire game. All I can say is, I'm glad I didn't pay for this "game", even $2.49 would be stretching it to me. You can find equally great scenery and far better story telling in games with actual gameplay.

Its barely an hour long, all you can do is walk around, you can't even sprint or jump or interact with anything.The short time I spent "playing" this, I kept waiting for something to happen, a jump scare, a puzzle, a new feature besides "walk slowly", something, anything, but nothing ever did. number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												I'm leaving this review long, long after I should have. The positive press and reviews this game has received are very misleading.This was marketed as a game. There is nothing game-like about it, save for character movement. You do not interact with anything in the environment, you do not alter or advance the story in any way except for walking, which triggers the narrator to start talking again. As such, it's a story, and an immersive one at that. But do not be mistaken - it is not a game.Visually it's beautiful, and the voice actor/narrator does a good job, but the writing was meh and the lack of interactivity bored me to hell. If you like stories and walking sims, maybe this will resonate with you. But if you like to actually play a game and interact with a world and advance the story by actions, rather than just arriving at the next location, you're better off looking elsewhere. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a much better example of what this genre should be like, in my opinion - interactivity, gripping story, puzzles to solve, and an emotional ending.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2012
												This is a hard game to review or recommend. Not because it is bad - far from it - but rather, because it is so unique. Firstly, it is not a game whatsoever. Secondly, while the experience may stick with you for a lifetime, the actual time investment is only 1 to 2 hours from start to finish. So because of those two factors and taking into account the price, I can't blindly recommend it for everyone. However, I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who is open to new and unique experiences in the digital realm and doesn't mind the asking price to length ratio. As for the game itself, it basically consists of walking a mostly linear path for 2 hours while listening to narration and taking in some amazing visuals. The mysterious story is revealed in bits and pieces as you play, and you will likely need (and want!) to replay the game multiple times to piece it all together. In the end, think of Dear Esther not as a game, but as an amazing piece of interactive art.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												It's been 6 months since I played this game. 6 bloody months and I couldn't stop thinking about how awful this game was; every time I think about it I feel so bad for the time I wasted on it. The main reason I'm writing this review is because every now and then I think about this game and I lose my hope in life even yesterday when I went to sleep It came into my mind like when a child start thinking about the monster who lives in the closet so I must get it out of my system and express how I feel about it.Firs of all there are two kinds of bad games: The first kind is when you discover that the game is bad after 5 minutes of playing it like Uriel's Chasm . The second kind (which is the worst) is when the game keeps feeding you hope that it'll be better if you played it just a little bit more but you eventually discover that its crappy like Dear Esther.This game doesn't have a real good graphics like The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter and you only need WASD to move really really slow and you can't sprint which is really stupid knowing that there are plenty of space to walk through for example you reach a crossroad and you decide to take the left road and after 5 minutes of walking and listening to stupid narration you reach a dead end and you have to get back exactly from where you came but without the narration.I payed 2.99$ for it which is the minimum amount of money the lazy developers should pay people to play this game in fact this game should be used for torturing terrorists and even if you did that and they managed to stay alive until they finish the game you will feel sorry for them for playing it and give them a hug.At the end I'd like to say that I have never gave a game a bad review before but Dear Esther is way worse than just bad; it's the worst game I've ever played and it is the reason why I wish that one day steam users can permanently delete a game from their account and get rid of the shame of playing it. This game has left a scar in me that needs a long time to heal it's a shame on indie games and always will be and I would never forgive myself for playing it for the end.For the developers: I hate you and I wish you bad luck and I hope that you'll never see success in the gaming industry

content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												This is an amazing and surprising game, forgetting the endless discussion about definitions on what a game is. It's not conventional, it have few gameplay elements, it's story-driven - an intriguing, mysterious and very beautiful story, by the way.It starts very boring and confusing. You have to spend some time, wandering around the island - with beautiful graphics - to catch fragments of this story, which are randomly narrated, and may reveal something to you through the journey. But this story will finish with some gaps, leading you to want to play again to catch more fragments and then, possibly understand the full story of Esther and the protagonist, although that story have a lot of metaphoric interpretations too. The journey is full of small well placed elements you can see and add to your interpretation.It lasts three hours to me, and after two more hours i'm still thinking about Dear Esther story, my head full of the images, the thoughts, and the music of this really wonderful game.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Simply put, this game is just far to subtle in terms of what it tries to do. Sure, the fact that this game tries to be artful and refreshing is nice, but still  Dear Esther just falls short of actually engaging your interest and making you really desire to replay it to discover new pieces of information or different slants to them; and overall, really desire to become invested in the narrator's ( guy you play as) story. The game will always end the same way, but with different little changes to the enviroment each time and to the narration, however those changes never go past things like writting on the wall. And there is not really anything significant to these changes either.      *****SPOILER*****(sort of, really just an opinion) All in all, the plot just sums up to being about a guy who is really depressed and sad about his friends having died (Sure if you play the game it goes into some detail about how they may have died, and all the finer details as to the narrator's struggle with depression on the island, and other elements and aspects to his psyche, but I won't try to spoil those). And yes, there is some further evaluation that could be done to the narrator's story, but to be honest, the game is just not involving enough to really spark one's interest to contimplate them all. After one play through, if you are decent at keeping track of the story elements and metaphors/erratic stream of conciousness that is the narrator's narration, you will have found all you really need to know about everything in the game. There is no overarching thesis or argument being said in this game. It is just a simple, hour long story. Which, to say the least, was disappointing.      Also, just to touch on the technical aspects of the game (design and graphics), there is nothing really phenomenal here either. Sure it shows off how awesome the Source engine can be, but it is of course still apparent in the game that the Source engine is in deed an outdated platform. If you are looking for a brilliant or etheral visual experience in this game, you will probably not find one depending on what your evaluation scale for graphical acievement is.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												While I can certainly appreciate the aspects of artistic form, emotional exploration, ambiguity in storytelling, blah, blah, blah, I still feel like I wasted two hours. "Playing" this story as a "game" was unnecessary; it should have just been a 20 minute video. Maybe I just don't have the mental problems or whatever this was designed around. Overall, it reminded me of the show "Lost." Which I hated. If you're giving me a character development drama of detachment and isolation, then fuggin warn me before hand so I don't hate you when you leave without finishing up.If you have absolutely nothing left on your game list, nor any better way to spend your time, then go ahead and rip through this one as fast as possible. Don't bother backtracking and exploring, and definitely don't think too hard or try to figure anything out. Just get it done so you can join the masses of bs diehards blubbering about how it was so moving and powerful, and whatever other adjectives make you gush with disingenuous psychology terms, and feel that false sense of belonging with some exclusive group of self-identifiers claiming only they "truly understand and appreciate." Or don't do that. Yeah, don't do that. Go for a real life walk around some real life ruins instead.Nothing personal against the devs; it is well made and I felt the feels on the way through. I don't like how this content was made to be consumed. It could have been done in a much better way that wasn't wasteful and misleading. And the condescending culture whose skirt it blows up is obnoxious. It's like an angsty teen getting weepy over Catcher In the Rye because of how strongly they "identify with it." Seriously, dude, shut up.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2013
												After completing the main story, I gave Dear Esther some time to settle in my mind in order to determine whether or not I thought the experience was worth the price of entry. The fact that, days later, I am still thinking about the main themes of the game and revisiting the extremely surreal environments has convinced me enough to warrant this recommendation.For me, Dear Esther is my perfect type of journey. I will not discuss the politics of whether Dear Esther should be considered a game, interactive media, or simply a "walking forward" simulator. No, Dear Esther deserves something more than such trivial bickering.How I would describe Dear Esther would be akin to the process of imagination when reading a book, yet I am given the ability to go beyond the text. Where a pathway splits in two, I can choose which path to walk down rather than it be forced on me, left with a longing to know where the other may have taken me.Everything about Dear Esther is perfect. From the sound design to the visuals; from the narration to the subtext; even the time it takes to complete the game is just spot on. Your first playthrough will probably last you just over an hour - one sitting - but that's all you need. There are multiple paths to take revealing certain aspects of the story and I plan on returning many more times in order to unravel the entire plot, but I wouldn't be lying if I said I just wanted to explore the island once more, it's quite a beautiful place.There something quite cathartic about realising that you're not pressured in doing anything you don't want to, unlike with many traditional games. You could spend your entire time standing at the shoreline, listening to the waves crashing in the distance. You make your own goals and go wherever you feel most inclined. I was drawn towards a certain object in the distance and made that my goal.The story resonated with me far more than most others do, more so than most novels or films. The sound design probably had a lot to do with that; the ambience of it all. I'm uncertain as to if the soundscapes are dynamic, but it all flowed so well if that is the case.I'd hate to come off as some elitist but, since Dear Esther can be taken as quite pretentious and pseudo-intellectual (although it does well to hide the fact), it's probably best to avoid a game such as this if you're not prepared, or willing, to experience something more mature and with more depth than you're used to; the themes here are very serious and very real.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												It's very hard for me to recommend this game, because it's not as much a game as it is an experience.You don't get to do much in this game other than walk around down a very linear path and enjoy the beautiful scenery, but that's exactly the point. There's no way to interact with anything you see. A narration vaguely hints as to what has happened and what is to come, but there are no definitive answers.  The entire experience feels more like digital poetry than an actual game. Yes, I get that's what the designers were going for.  It've very high art and high brow, and I can't help help but feel that they designers squandered an opportunity by creating a world but not give us ways of interacting with it. I'm sure academics will love to write about this game, but for those looking for an interactive experience will leave feeling underwhelmed and disappointed that their wallets feel that much lighter. I can't recommend this game at the standard asking price. I got it as part of a bundle and would have felt ripped off paying the $10 that is being asked for it.

												The game was slow, but not boring. Piecing the story together was interesting, although even by the end one cannot know the whole story.But ultimately I found the game to be very depressing. The ending is very dark. There is no real redemption. Basically, the moral of the story is that everything is meaningless and that everything dies, even love, all that awaits is eternal darkness.The game gives a conflicting message, you are basically a soul in limbo whose only purpose is to let go of the hope of the existance of heaven. The game echoes the cruelty of life, the vanity of it all and the ultimate horror that all that you know and love will dissappear.This game represents an atheist perspective on eternity.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I was so happy when the main character ended his life, because it was precisely what I felt like doing once the game was over.This game took me almost 3 years to finish. And I only played it for less than an hour.As someone who has studied literature in Academia, I can tell that most of the metaphors are really going to go over the overwhelming majority of people who play this game. The slow walking pace really hurts how enjoyable this can be (not to mention the lack of time to develop anything so you really can't care). Exploring more rewards you with more dialogue (most of which will probably go over the average persons head unless they're familiar with this style of prose).The narrative isn't that compelling to justify $11 CAD (currently, can't remember what the launch price was).It's great if you're into:Buying games you'll never play again for absurd pricesWalking incredibly slowlyWondering when it will be over.Getting cancer.Aging 43 years within the span of 1 hour.Feeling boredom that can only be measured by the desire to end ones life.I'd give this a better score if it was maybe $2. But a game with no mechanics beyond holding down W, a story any writer with a penchant for surreal metaphors and the prose writers dead for almost a century could have written in 20 minutes, is not worth the asking price. The environments are some what interesting to look at, but only in a passing fashion.Oh, and the little cutscene at the end shows me that the creators don't know how light works. When the light source is in front of you, your shadow should not be in front of you.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												This isn't a game.What it IS, is a virtual novel where the text is narrated to you in pieces as you walk along the 100% linear path you must take through the game world, interacting with quite literally nothing and simply looking at the scenery.What the story is about is virtually irrelevant. Written as a contemplative short story it might elicit some worth, the problem comes in when The Chinese Room tried to pair it with first person movement mechanics. For the most part, the world you're walking through has little to do with the story being read to you, and it's not like there's much more story to uncover by looking through the environment since you can't interact with anything. You're basically shuffling along a track like a theme park ride, except you can stop at any time or even go backwards if you're so inclined.The environments are very pretty and aesthetically pleasing yes, but again, it's irrelevent. Other than a couple of spots where you see something alluded to in the narration, the environment itself is utterly devoid of anything of actual substance. Yes the caves are pretty - why are you in the caves? What is the point of the caves? Are you here to do something interesting in the caves? Uncover some juicy plot bits? No, it's just more disconnected narration. You just walk through caves, because.....preeeetttttyyyyy. Most of the game is like this. You're just walking through a beautiful environment that has virtually no relevence to the narration being doled out to you in paragraphs at a time. The gaps between these bits are enough that the narrative is disjointed and hard to follow and appreciate in its entirety because you don't have an actual book in front of you (and make no mistake, this stuff was clearly wirtten as a short story and copy pasted into the "game" without any modification to fit the medium) and there is no other narrative devices except the narration, so you better be really good at memorizing quicks snippets of someone speaking or you'll miss half the story and the end will feel that much more hollow.Honestly this would be more engaging as a short story with a few watercolour illustrations scattered through it than this rote walking simulator with huge disconnects between the story and the environment and player. If you want to illustrate a story, illustrate it. Don't make it "interactive" and then strip out literally everything that gives interactive media an advantage and reduce the interactivity to "move around", all the while not adapting the narrative in any way for it's new non-printed medium. This non-game feels disjointed, disconnected, cold, and boring. Go read a book instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Dear Esther is an interactive experience in which you navigate the protagonist through various landscapes. While wandering through these more or less linear levels, a story is narrated to you, sometimes tying in to what unfolds before your eyes. Apart from walking though, the gameplay is literally non-existant. The soundtrack and overall audio design serves it's storytelling purpose fine enough and adds to the overall quite relaxing feel. Sadly, there are no collectibles, different paths or endings, so the replay-value is extremely low. Lastly, the experience is extremely short-lived and the story, while ambitious, is nothing to write home about.This product is a prime example of a non-game: Technically you control a character but other factors crucial to game-design (like fail-states) are completely absent. Dear Esther feels more like an art exhibit than a game and would probably be better represented in it's own media form, seperate from video games. I can not recommend it to anyone looking for a game.

												I have never experienced a more clear example of purple prose.  Tragic writing aside, the story is somewhat touching, though nothing special.  Some people are under the impression that because a story is sad and written in obfuscating prose that it must be great. Meh.I don't want to go into great detail on the story because that's really all there is to the game.  Well, except for the caves. They were absolutely stunning. The rest I could have done without.The game is also very short unless you are simply obsessed with examining every pixel. I finished in an hour and 15 minutes and then went back and did the caves again to get my 1 1/2 hour playtime.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I was so happy when the main character ended his life, because it was precisely what I felt like doing once the game was over.This game took me almost 3 years to finish. And I only played it for less than an hour.As someone who has studied literature in Academia, I can tell that most of the metaphors are really going to go over the overwhelming majority of people who play this game. The slow walking pace really hurts how enjoyable this can be (not to mention the lack of time to develop anything so you really can't care). Exploring more rewards you with more dialogue (most of which will probably go over the average persons head unless they're familiar with this style of prose).The narrative isn't that compelling to justify $11 CAD (currently, can't remember what the launch price was).It's great if you're into:Buying games you'll never play again for absurd pricesWalking incredibly slowlyWondering when it will be over.Getting cancer.Aging 43 years within the span of 1 hour.Feeling boredom that can only be measured by the desire to end ones life.I'd give this a better score if it was maybe $2. But a game with no mechanics beyond holding down W, a story any writer with a penchant for surreal metaphors and the prose writers dead for almost a century could have written in 20 minutes, is not worth the asking price. The environments are some what interesting to look at, but only in a passing fashion.Oh, and the little cutscene at the end shows me that the creators don't know how light works. When the light source is in front of you, your shadow should not be in front of you.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												The tide of time beats on every shore but its impact isn’t equal. If there is value in graphical fidelity, it is short-lived. Dear Esther revels in embellishment but only manages to underscore its faults. As if afraid of rejection, it tries to justify itself with a world overladen with reuse and excuse. There is abundance of icons instead of allegories, narration instead of exposition, and stimulus instead of sentiment. Dear Esther is an ostentatious presentation of a fuzzy concept.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												I will try to keep this short… as short as the playtime of this game. Are you wondering why this game doesn’t sport any achievements? That’s because there is nothing to achieve. This game is a pure walking simulator ornate with florid narrations. If you want to have a beautiful read, go grab a classic novel or some poetry instead. The writing here is cheesy beyond compare. See #6 for more on this. Speaking of walking, that is pretty much all you can do in this game. No running (unless you tweak the userconfig.cfg), just creeping along, slowly. The game does all the thinking for you (when to jump, when to turn on the flashlight). There is as much interaction required on your part as there is in making the wind blow. General movement: limited and painful. Not just because of the snail’s speed, but more so due to the fact that you can’t climb at spots that look easily reachable and explorable, you can’t even swim (on an island that features a lot of water, naturally). Whenever you attempt the latter, you are tortured by painful sounds and flashes of the same images repeating until you feel your head is going to explode. After reading various reviews, I realized I missed out on some more or less important "story" details, merely because I was busy being frustrated at my surroundings and how one cannot "conquer" them. Sound volume. This game’s options menu reads like a slimfast diet. This is especially annoying when it comes to sound adjustment. You can’t regulate the volume of speech, environmental sounds and music separately, so whenever the narrator talks the string quartet or piano is giving you yet another headache while you are trying to make out his babbling (if it wasn’t for the close captions, it would have been even more painful to follow the monotonous voice guiding you through the emptiness of this place). Soundtrack: nothing special, don't waste your money on it. Story. What story? I understand that this is not a regular game but supposed to be an "experience", a narration that is "pulling you in" - unfortunately it does nothing for me. I don't play computer games for this purpose, I can read a book instead. When I play a game I expect to get involved (through exploration, interaction and deduction). This game did not evoke the slightest feeling in me, no compassion or curiosity, except maybe impatience fueled by boredom. I was glad when it was over, then I requested a refund (why this game is still not available at a discount is beyond me).If you would like to experience a good game of the genre, you have to check out The Vanishing of Ethan Carter:  - Now there is a brilliant game that will touch you deeply, move you to tears, excite you, and creep you out, all at the same time.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Playing Dear Esther is like being invited to a birthday party where no one likes you or even cares that you're there.Dear Esther is so caught up in what it feels is this deep, emotionally-gripping narrative that it forgets that there's a player or an audience.You walk down a corridor, occasionally getting bits of narration whenever you walk to certain points. That's it. It offers nothing as a piece of interactive entertainment that a book or movie couldn't do just as well. I suppose the enironments are pretty, and the story is vaguely interesting, but it tries way too hard to be deep and emotional without grasping the subtleties.And honestly, I just feel unwelcome. I feel like the game doesn't even want me around; it just wants my money and then to play in it's own little world for a couple of hours.Would only recommend if you're a big fan of art games and don't mind a substantial lack of content or interaction as long as there's some kind of artistic statement. Or if you like pretty environments.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Despite the "Not Recommended" Rating, this is not a bad game. It's just the kind of game that you either get, or you don't.Some people will go into it and get lost in the narritive, the music, the sights and little extra pieces of handiwork that show that the developers put love and effort into it. They will connect with the game, and may even feel emotional when it ends.Others, like myself, will groan "why can't I go faster' after you've held down the W button for 30 minutes and listened to a bunch of well-meaned but at front nonsense that the narrator spouts. They will feel absolutely nothing when it ends, and feel puzzled at any attempt to make sense of the experience. This is not a bad game. If you want to know whether you'd like it, I'd suggest watching 5-10 minutes of a letsplay. Do not buy this game just because people are raving about it; look into it and make sure this is something you 'get'

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												6.5/10Dear Esther is as good as a non-interactive desolate-walking-simulator can be. This doesn't say much, only that I found this game to be more interesting and thought provoking than the similarly-limited Gone Home. Still, I would appreciate actual gameplay and interactivity to be a more prominent part of this game.The game has beautiful graphic design and excellent voice acting. The story is interesting and ambiguous, the kind that make you read the forums and come up with your own theories (warning: this link contains spoilers). This is great. What's less successful is the pace. The walking speed specifically is excruciatingly slow, so much that on occasion I felt like I was falling asleep. There's a configuration file you can edit to make walking optionally faster. I only learned about this option after playing the game for the first time (which took about an hour and a half), then had another playthrough which probably took 20 or 30 minutes. The optimum is probably somewhere in between. Note that I have no issue with the game being short, but I do with the very slow pace of walking. I don't walk that slow in real life, even when I'm just wandering around thinking about life, like the narrator. What could have been a nice addition is "cruise control" mode, where you just watch the game on auto-pilot and disengage this mode if you want to explore stuff around.Controls in general are not great. Beyond the slow walking speed, there's also no way to walk across (let alone jump) over even tiny obstacles (aka the Insurmountable Waist-Height Fence trope).If you get this game in a bundle or in a heavily discounted sale, I would recommended it. It's an interesting and rather unique experience, even if a bit overrated.

number of helpful: 13 of 33 people (39%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												Dear Esther is a first-person ghost story. The focus of the game is on exploration, uncovering the mystery of a lonely island, of who you are and why you are here.You wander the cliffs, caves and sheep-pens of a windswept island. During your walk a voice reads out fragments of letters and through these you gain snatches of information about the island and other people who took a walk similar to yours.Their stories bleed into each other: the travel writer who visited the island in pursuit of a legendary hermit. The shepherd stranded here without friends or family, whose situation reflects the hermit’s. Dear Esther is about heavy subjects: isolation and tragedy tie the island’s visitors together.The only game play mechanic is to guide your character through the story. However, what makes Dear Esther interesting and outstanding is the atmosphere.The enviroment is amazing in every way. It has a deep story accompanied by brilliant music.Dear Esther is not a game, it is better described as an interactive fiction narrative. It is a wonderfully sad and beautiful experience. It is definitely worth every minute, you will not regret it.Sounds 9/10Graphics 10/10Gameplay 3/10Atmosphere 9/10Video of playthrough:

content:
Posted: May 26, 2012
												I would only recommend this game for those who read novels. This game is unique among the genre, could be considered almost like Myst except you move in real time instead of frame to frame. The game plays as if you were reading a novel except that you experience the novel by living it instead of reading it. Which makes it unique, although so be it short. Very short. There are quite a few inspiring scenes to view,pleasant ambiance or atmosphere.You cannot run or interact with the environment or it's objects, there are many clues strewn across the Island, the Island is divided into 4 chapters. Once you finish the game you'll be able to chose to revisit any of those chapters at any time.In order to save, simply hit the F6 key on the keyboard. If you fall to your death of drown you'll come back so you can't really die per say. At it's current price of $10.00 is it worth it? Maybe, Maybe not. Depends on what you like. If it goes on sale for half price, then I suggest you buy this one.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2013
												Would I classify Dear Esther as a game? Absolutely not.  But that doesn't mean it's not an interesting experience. Dear Esther finds you as a lone inhabitant on a seemingly deserted island on a quest to put the pieces of your past together. There's no inventory, NPCs or even anything to pick up. The only thing you seem to have is a flashlight that turns on automatically when you need it. I personally found Dear Esther to be engrossing although you aren't given much to do other than explore a beautifully realized island and listen to the narrator read excerpts from letters to Esther (different playthroughs will lead to diferent excerpts being read to you). The graphical design is top notch as was the music. I picked this up from the Humble Bundle 8 so the cost to me was minimal. The experience is over in less than an hour if you don't take in the sights so it's really up to you how much it's worth. I probably won't ever play through this again but the journey is certainly worth an hour of your time at least once.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												It's a short story with the player walking across the island he describes from the beginning to the end through transcripts of the letters he's written to his love, Esther.  While wandering through the beautiful landscape, sometimes you feel the senses of happiness and sadness, regret, solitude, joy and fear, the feelings are conveyed as if you are reading an old short story from the 18th or 19th century.  It's one of those concept games where instead of having an objective, you are the focus.  The island is also a force.  Just being in a fantastic world and simulating the short story is the point.  Basically, you are playing a short story novel.  I'll recommend it for the complimentary world to the story.  It is short, I only took an hour to complete the letter.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												"Dear Esther" is many things; beautiful, emotional, powerful, and thought provoking. All of these are sought after traits of the highest caliber; why then do I find it hard to suggest "Dear Esther" to most of my gaming companions? That answer is frightfully simple, it's not a "game" in the purest sense of the word. The reason for my inability to recommend it to most gamers is that they simply need some action, some mission, some drive to convince them that the time they spend in the world is worth it. The few people who I've recomended Dear Esther too are the gamers who still appreciate a good book. The world is ripe with it's story, waiting for someone to explore it with open arms and an open mind, to cut away the surface and find the nectar hidden within, and for those who can, it's the sweetest and most emotional tale you can have in a video game. This title shares a place with "To The Moon" in my heart for being stories that touch upon the soul in meaningful ways. The difference being that "Dear Esther" feels like reading a novel while walking through a beautiful island, and that's the way to approach it.  "Dear Esther" is a story of loss and longing, and in a way, those who cannot find the power within it are themselves lost of this gem of a tale. As a side note: The voice of the narrator is perfect. He speaks in a way that is both soothingly natural, and weighed upon by sorrow. His tone and soul truly set the tale alight.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												I wouldn't call this a "game" so much as a self-paced audio tour. It's gorgeously rendered, well scored, and beautiful in every way, but from a gameplay perspective it's pretty much a slow walk in a straight line with no influence on the environment, the ending, the story, or anything else (there are no interaction keys). Takes about 90 minutes start to finish at a slowish explorer's pace. At $2.50 sale price, a definite recommendation for those who like eye-candy and art-house things. If you're the sort who thought Myst was boring or pointless though, you will hate this even more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												There is really no other experience similar to Dear Esther. It's not a game, but more of an adventure. An experience, really; the landscape the player can explore is barren and isolated, much like the story that is read in the backdrop. Everything pieces together, almost perfectly so, yet leaves more questions than when you began. It's really a profound experience that every player can enjoy. Whether you like FPSs or life simulators, Dear Esther will pull you in regardless, and make you feel uncomfortable in all the best ways. The story of Dear Esther is ever changing as you replay it, and can even be played in silence. Without giving any spoilers, the landscape and environment cast a dark shadow on the situation the player finds themself in. Depending on what area you investigate first, the story the narrator is telling changes. It's almost as if Dear Esther is a living, breathing entity with a mind of its own — and what it gives you is closer to magic than anything else. Out of ten, I'd give this game at //least// a fourteen, haha. Even on the lowest graphics setting, you can enjoy this experience wholly. Take risks, explore places you might not in reality, and let yourself be submerged in Dear Esther completely. You really won't regret it. When you're done, sit on it for a few days — then play it again. Like a reoccuring dream, Dear Esther is never exactly the same.

												This is one of the those games thats kind of hard to recommend. That being said I enjoyed it, but its certainly not for everyone. Its a pretty slow paced narrative in which you simply walk around. Landscapes are beautiful, and every playthrough is almost guaranteed to be different because there is so much narrative. Overall, I enjoyed the "story" and the game as a whole, buts its more art than game. All you do is walk to explore and listen. Most people will be offput by the slow pace, but if you enjoy an arty game with a good narrative this is for you. Its really short and although I probably wouldn't play it again, at least for a long while, its not a bad purchase. I honestly thought it would be a little more, but at $2 on sale, this was definitely a bit of a sleeper for me. 7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												"Dear Esther" is many things; beautiful, emotional, powerful, and thought provoking. All of these are sought after traits of the highest caliber; why then do I find it hard to suggest "Dear Esther" to most of my gaming companions? That answer is frightfully simple, it's not a "game" in the purest sense of the word. The reason for my inability to recommend it to most gamers is that they simply need some action, some mission, some drive to convince them that the time they spend in the world is worth it. The few people who I've recomended Dear Esther too are the gamers who still appreciate a good book. The world is ripe with it's story, waiting for someone to explore it with open arms and an open mind, to cut away the surface and find the nectar hidden within, and for those who can, it's the sweetest and most emotional tale you can have in a video game. This title shares a place with "To The Moon" in my heart for being stories that touch upon the soul in meaningful ways. The difference being that "Dear Esther" feels like reading a novel while walking through a beautiful island, and that's the way to approach it.  "Dear Esther" is a story of loss and longing, and in a way, those who cannot find the power within it are themselves lost of this gem of a tale. As a side note: The voice of the narrator is perfect. He speaks in a way that is both soothingly natural, and weighed upon by sorrow. His tone and soul truly set the tale alight.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Let's be clear about this: everything you've ever heard about this game is true. Yes it's pretentious. Yes it's beautiful. Yes, there's literally nothing to do but explore. Yes it is an innovative way to be told a story. Yes, it can be as boring as bat-poop (apologies to the pteropine fecologists out there). It's certainly not a game for everyone, and even having finished it twice, I'm not even 100% convinced it's a game for me.You begin on a boat ramp, outside a small lighthouse, on a small tussocky island buffeted by wind. It's not clear why you're there, or why this lighthouse, much like the entirety of the island, looks completely abandoned. A man on the voice over starts reading letters in little chunks to someone named Esther. What has she got to do with your current predicament, this island, and that particularly ominous looking radio tower? I think the less I say the better, but don't assume I have all the answers!Dear Esther is a game about exploring, piecing together the fragmented story behind it all, and above all, atmosphere. The island is full of detail: if you search hard enough, you'll find a myriad of sights, cues, clues, and visual metaphors. But, at the same time, the island is ominously empty. You see evidence of humans everywhere you look, but you can't find any actual humans. This is one powerful way that Dear Esther fosters an uneasy atmosphere. You can't help but feel, deep down, that whatever happened to everyone else might happen to you. And possibly worse still, if you look really, really hard, you might suspect you're not alone after all.The soundtrack, too, deserves a special mention. It pitches perfectly the kind of haunting, exquisite, melancholic spookiness that the story and setting both convey. It's mostly sparsely arranged, designed so that you can always hear the wind buffeting the cliffs around you. And when things in the story turn, the music is right behind it. Dear Esther would not be half the game it is without it.None of this will be at all effective, if you refuse to let it. Dear Esther is not a game for you to sit back and wait to be impressed. In order to enjoy it, you need to actively participate. You need to listen to the story, find any correspondences you can with the island you're exploring, and above all, let yourself be swept up in it. If you can enjoy it, then you'll really enjoy it. If you can't... well that's shame, but not a surprise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2013
												How do you recommend a game that has nothing but walking and a voice to tell his story? The game is simple, but lovely in everyway, this programmed world has much to see, and a sad but amazing story to tell. The game is easy, you play as someone who is exploreing an island, with a narrorator that expalins his feelings and thoughts about what is in the world around you, and why things are the way they are.This game has an amazing musical soundtrack, it adds to the immersive enviroment  that the developers made. The sounds are perfect, the space you explore and the way they allow you to take your own journey just makes this game hard not to like. I can't say what i like about this game and do it justice, it's just amazing. They put alot of heart into this beautifully artistic game. I can't say this game is worth it's full price, buy it on sale and play it, get lost in it, when you have sixty to ninety minutes to spare play it, let nothing distract you. Dear Ecther has some of the best visuals, music, atmoshpere, everything really. Most people won't like this game simply for the lack of action in every form. This game feels lke playing a living picture, a moment in time where someone is stuck and caught, where they need to figure somethign out, but are to confused by thier own feelings to grasp it fully.This game fights for gameing as an art form, and sells it by the boat load, it's an amazing game that you really need to play in a sitting, i can not say this enough, this game amazed me on so many levels, it really blew my expectations away and really made me feel like i was in another world, this is the most immersive game i have ever played.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												How to write a review for Dear Esther...the task is not simple. First and foremost, I am NOT reccomending this as a game. Let me explain: Dear Esther isn't a game. It's largely an allegory presented through an interactive narrative. As an experience, if you are willing to go in with an open mind, I think you can get something out of it. It is not fun, it is not supposed to be.Now, before people get mad at me, let me be clear: I do not think I am "better" for liking Dear Esther, nor do I feel I'm somehow artistically above people who don't like it (there are many). I don't mean to come across as pretentious. I am only saying that I honestly felt impacted by this game, and I want to share why exactly that is.Dear Esther presents, in its story told through voice overs, a tragic tale of several off screen characters. The narrator weaves his tale slowly, as you move around the island. Piecing together this story is no easy task, and multiple interpretations exist based off evidence here and there.The developers made a design decision that you do not run, but walk at a realistic pace. This is going to massively turn people off out of the gate, but I think it was a valuable decision. The game is meant to be seen and heard at a certain pace. That said, this may downright infuriate many people. But I do think it pays off. I don't think I've ever taken the time to visually appreciate a game in the way I did with Dear Esther.The story is vague and open to interpretation. My honest suggestion is, if you're willing to put in the hour and a half for it, play it, and just try to take things in. After giving yourself time to digest, go online. Art isn't meant to be appreciated by oneself. Find the opinions of others and sharing interpretations breathes life into the work. You aren't lesser for "not getting it" initially. I really think that if you play this game, and then go online and look for other interpretations, you'll appreciate it.If you're looking for a game, stay away. This isn't one. But Dear Esther does provide a fantastic experience if you're willing to be patient with it.

												This richly detailed game has a fantastic sound track and an open-ended storyline that leads you through an island of wonder isolated by the bitter-sweet waves of mystery, amazement, and loss. This is not by anymeans meant for the traditional game player; its more like going on a tour by yourself, and rather than having a map, you have only the fragments of the narroators voice thats played like you're invading someones diary. Seriously, I wish there was a book to accompany this game. The linguistics are powerful. The only problem is this isn't an addictive game you'd want to come back to everyday. You can beat it within an hour or two and not touch it again for a while. This is personally a concept I look for, much like the Myst series. If you see it on sale, it's best to buy it then. I'm looking forward to their second game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Though extremely short, the amount of wordplay, emotion, and tone behind the narrators voice, accompanied with the music, is fitting enough to relay a special emotion in the short story. It's one of those games, nay, calling it a game doesn't even do this title justice, it's an art canvas, that doesn't rush you to beat the game, allowing us to interpret the message of the game and it's ending however we choose to view it. Graphics aren't my biggest focus when it comes to judging a game based upon the amount of salt it holds, but the scenic visuals and the music put together is simply....beautiful, I never wanted to go any further at long intervals, the lighting of the environments coupled with the ambience of the environment at that, instilling a sense of tranquility. Sometimes, I would simply stare off into the distance, and let the music and the moonlit waters reflect into my mind, allowing me to properly formulate how I am truly feeling deep inside of myself. Though it was only one voice actor, Nigel Carrington lured me into the personal journey of exploring the unhappiness of the world around Dear Esther, the emotions that I felt cannot be said in the length of my thoughts on this game, but one thing that I can be certain of, is that games like Dear Esther are a rare gem in the sands. For anyone who wishes to experience an artistic idea upon a blank canvas open for interpretations, then I highly reccomend getting Dear Esther.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												The visuals are stunning and it is enjoyable to see where it takes you. This isn't really a game so much as a 3D rendered short story, because there aren't any game aspects since you're only action is to click where you want to go. If you are expecting any puzzles or items to collect you won't find them here. I think it is a very interesting use of the video game media format and I am very interested in where people will take video game format next. If you are looking for a first person video game interactive novel/short story I recommend Gone Home.  Gone Home isn't as visually stunning as Dear Esther but it has more interaction/game aspects.

												Dear Esther is a very beautiful game. It is soothing, yet there are some disturbing elements. You could see Dear Esther as a story that is told by a narrator, but while the story is being told, you can explore the place on your own pace. It sort of feels like a movie, but in this game you are in the movie, walking around and experiencing what is being told, living the story. The graphics really bring the scenery to live, they are very realistic. The music is very pretty as-well, it changes along with the scenery and helps transferring the mood that accompanies the story.
